State Law reference- Municipalities generally, MCA 1972, § 21-1-1 et seq.; general municipal powers, MCA 1972, § 21-17-1 et seq.; appointive officers, MCA 1972, § 21-3-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Appointment of municipal officers and employees. 
    All or any of such officers or employees, except those of mayor and aldermen shall be appointed by the said municipal authorities of the city. 
(Ord. No. 73-1, 4-3-1973) 
Secs. 2-2-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICIALS 

Sec. 2-21. - City clerk appointed registrar of voters. 
(a)  The city clerk is hereby appointed the registrar of voters in and for the city and, before entering into the duties of the office of registrar of voters, shall take the oath of office prescribed by section 268 of the state constitution. The registrar shall maintain and provide suitable registration books for registration of qualified electors. No elector residing within the city limits shall be qualified to vote in any city election unless he is registered to vote at least 30 days prior to a city election. 
(b)  All elections shall be conducted and governed by the state election law and election commissioners shall be appointed by the mayor and board of aldermen to perform all duties in respect to municipal elections which are prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 73-2, 4-3-1973) 
Sec. 2-22. - Clerk as tax collector. 
    The city clerk is hereby appointed the tax collector in and for the city and shall collect all ad valorem, privilege, licenses, fees and any other taxes due the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 73-7, 4-3-1973) 
Secs. 2-23-2-47. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN 

Sec. 2-48. - Regular meetings. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen of the city shall hold its regular meeting on the first Tuesday of each month. If the day fixed for any regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen falls upon a day designated by law as a legal holiday, such meeting shall be held on the succeeding day not a holiday. 
(b)  All regular called meetings shall be called at 6:00 p.m. until or before 9:30 p.m. All business conducted before 6:00 p.m. or initiated after 9:30 p.m. shall be out of order and not allowed, unless approved by a majority vote of the mayor and board of aldermen present. Any business before the mayor and board of aldermen started prior to 9:30 p.m. shall be considered in order. A motion to continue the meeting after 9:30 p.m. shall state the length of time of the extension and may include one or more unheard agenda items or all remaining as a whole. 
(c)  All recessed meetings and/or special called meetings shall be called at a time as so designated by the mayor or the required number of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § I, 6-5-1990; Ord. No. 95-04-44, § I, 4-6-1995; Ord. No. 06-11-166, § I, 11-7-2006) 
Sec. 2-49. - Recessed meetings. 
    Any first or second regular meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen may be recessed by appropriate board action to reconvene on a day and time fixed by order of the board and duly entered into the minutes of the meeting which is recessed or as outlined in section 2-68. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § II, 6-5-1990; Ord. No. 95-04-44, § II, 4-6-1995) 
Sec. 2-50. - Agenda and docket. 
    All items or business or other matters to be officially considered for action of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be submitted to the city clerk by noon on the Friday before a regular board meeting, whereupon the city clerk shall arrange a list of such business items or matters and furnish the mayor, board of aldermen and city attorney as soon as possible a municipal docket. Every effort is to be made to give the city officials at least 24 hours prior to a meeting said municipal docket, along with copies of all available information pertaining thereto. Any member of the board of aldermen or city attorney may, however, bring before the mayor and board of aldermen any urgent or emergency matter, not on such municipal docket, subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § IV, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-51. - Presiding officer. 
    The presiding officer of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be the mayor, or, in his absence the mayor pro tempore. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular, recessed or special meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen. He shall state every question coming before the board of aldermen, announce the decision of the board of aldermen on all subjects and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the board of aldermen, in which event a majority vote of the board of aldermen shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. Such appeal shall be immediately presented and voted upon by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § V, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-52. - Call of meeting to order. 
    The mayor, or in his absence, the mayor pro tempore shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed for the mayor and board of aldermen meeting, and shall immediately call the meeting to order. In the absence of the mayor or mayor pro tempore, the city attorney or city clerk shall call the board of aldermen to order, whereupon a temporary chairman shall be elected by the members of the board present. Upon the arrival of the mayor or mayor pro tempore, the temporary chairman shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately before the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § VI, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-53. - Roll call. 
    Before proceeding with business of the mayor and board of aldermen, the city clerk or his deputy shall take the roll call of the board of aldermen. The names of those present shall be entered into the minutes. At the conclusion of the roll call of the board members present, the mayor shall announce the members absent. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § VII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-54. - Quorum. 
    A majority of all the members elected to the board of aldermen shall constitute a quorum at any regular, recessed or special meeting of the mayor and board of aldermen. No official business may be transacted by the mayor and board of aldermen in the absence of a quorum. In the absence of a quorum, the mayor will schedule and announce to all present, when the board will meet again 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § VIII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-55. - Order of business. 
    All meetings of the mayor and board of aldermen shall be open to the public. Meetings shall begin promptly at the hour set by law on the day of each regular meeting. The order of business to be conducted shall be typed and called the municipal docket. It shall be at the discretion of the mayor as to what order to conduct the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § IX, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-56. - Minutes. 
    A copy of the minutes of the previous meetings shall be presented to the mayor and board of aldermen on the first Tuesday regular meeting of each month for approval. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § X, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-57. - Record of voting. 
    All actions of the mayor and board of aldermen requiring a vote shall be recorded in the minutes by an individual board member as either aye or nay to the motion being voted upon, except in the vote on ordinances, which shall be recorded as yea or nay vote. The members introducing and seconding motions will also be recorded. The only time an alderman may abstain from voting is if there is a direct conflict of interest, at which time, the conflict must be noted in the minutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XI, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-58. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  The presiding officer and board members may debate and vote as allowed by state statutes. The mayor or such other members of the board as may be presiding may move, second and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are imposed by these rules on all members, and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of an aldermen by reason of his acting as the presiding officer, except as provided by state statues. 
(b)  Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair, and upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(c)  A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order as otherwise provided in this article. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined, and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. The mayor or presiding officer will enforce such procedures as necessary to maintain order in discussion. 
(d)  Debate, discussion or the address of any matter by an individual alderman or citizen will be limited to three minutes per occasion of officially obtaining the floor. Limited extensions of time may be granted to the person who has the floor by the presiding officer upon request. Changes in the time limit on debate may be adopted by proper motion, second and roll call vote of the aldermen at the time. 
(e)  No member shall speak more than once on any subject under discussion until all other members of the board have had the opportunity to speak. 
(f)  A board member may request through the mayor or presiding officer that an abstract of his statement on any subject under consideration by the board of aldermen be entered into the minutes. Any board member shall likewise have the right to have the reason for his dissent or protest against any action of the board entered on the minutes. It shall be the responsibility of the alderman requesting comments to be entered into the minutes, to give the city clerk said comments in writing to be entered into the minutes. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-59. - Citizens addressing the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(a)  The mayor or presiding officer of the board of aldermen shall provide opportunity during the board meeting for discussion by interest persons or their authorized representatives on any alderman bill or other matter before the aldermen, prior to final passage, provided that the preference shall be given to any person, who at least four days prior to the board meeting, shall have requested the opportunity for discussion by written notice directed to the mayor through the city clerk. 
(b)  Any person may direct a written communication to the board of aldermen on any matter concerning the city's business by directing the communication to the aldermen through the city clerk. Any such written communication shall be placed on the agenda of the next scheduled board meeting under the order of business where the item or subject matter is addressed or under public comments, subject to the approval of the mayor. 
(c)  After a motion is made by the board, no person except a member of the board or the city attorney shall address the board, without having submitted the above described written request and properly obtaining the floor through the mayor or presiding officer. 
(d)  The mayor or presiding officer of the board shall, from time to time, make such rules as he may deem necessary to fulfill and carry out the intent of the provisions of this section. 
(e)  The mayor or presiding officer shall at his discretion allow for generalized comments from citizens attending said meeting, provided time allows. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XIII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-60. - Manner of addressing the mayor and board of aldermen. 
    Each person addressing the mayor and board of aldermen shall stand, request to be recognized, and if granted, shall move to the front of the auditorium and give his name and address of residence for the records. Unless further time is granted by the mayor, board of aldermen or presiding officer, the person having the floor shall limit his address to three minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the mayor and board as a body and not to any member thereto. No person, other than the board and the person having the floor shall be permitted to enter into any discussion or ask a question of a board member either directly or through a member of the board, without the permission of the mayor or presiding officer. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XIV, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-61. - Decorum. 
(a)  By board of aldermen. While the board meeting is in session, the members shall preserve decorum and order, and no member, shall, by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the meeting, nor disturb any member while speaking nor refuse to obey the orders of the board or the mayor or presiding officer, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  By other persons. No person shall make personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks, nor otherwise disturb the order and decorum of any aldermen meeting. The sergeant-at-arms, at the direction of the mayor, shall remove any person violating the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XV, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-62. - Sergeant-at-arms; decorum preservation. 
    The chief of police, officer in charge, or such member of the police department as he may designate shall be sergeant-at-arms of the mayor and board of aldermen meetings. He shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the mayor or presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the board meetings. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XVI, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-63. - Special committees. 
    All special committees shall be appointed by the mayor, unless otherwise directed by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XVII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-64. - Standing committees. 
    The board of aldermen shall have such standing committees as it may deem necessary to establish. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XVIII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-65. - Committee meetings. 
    Meetings of all committees may be held at such time and place as the committee shall determine for its convenience. The committee, at its discretion, may determine who, besides its members, may be present. Minutes shall be maintained for all committee meetings, by a person so designated, and upon request, presented to the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XIX, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-66. - Reports of committees. 
    All committees of the mayor and board of aldermen shall make their reports in writing when so directed by the presiding officer. All reports shall be filed with the city clerk and entered on the minutes, upon order by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XX, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-67. - Motions to adjourn. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and shall be decided without debate. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XXI, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-68. - Recessing meetings. 
    The mayor or presiding officer of the mayor and board of aldermen meeting may, at his discretion, recess a meeting, when in his opinion, the meeting is not being conducted properly, or the meeting is not accomplishing the purpose for which it had been scheduled. Upon the meeting being recessed by the mayor or presiding officer, at the time of said meeting being recessed, it will be noted when the meeting will reconvene. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XXII, 6-5-1990) 
Sec. 2-69. - Aldermen's attendance at meetings. 
    Should a board member need to be absent from a meeting, then said alderman shall notify the city clerk, so that it may be noted in the minutes the absence and reason for not attending should an alderman miss a meeting due to any reason other than illness of himself or due to his full-/part-time employment, then said alderman shall not be paid for said meeting. The amount paid to an alderman will be figured on the monthly fee divided by the number of meetings held in that month. This will establish a per meeting fee. 
(Ord. No. 90-06-11, § XXIII, 6-5-1990) 
Secs. 2-70-2-96. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CHIEF ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICER 

Sec. 2-97. - Establishment. 
    As required by MCA 1972, § 21-3-25, the position of chief administrative officer ("city administrator") is hereby established. The chief administrative officer shall be a full-time employee of the city and shall serve at the discretion of the mayor and board of aldermen. The chief administrative officer shall be chosen solely on the basis of experience and administrative qualifications. The chief administrative officer may hold one or more other appointive positions in the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 05-02-144, § I, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 2-98. - Duties. 
    The chief administrative officer shall have such administrative duties and functions as shall be delegated to him by the mayor and board of aldermen. Members of the board of aldermen shall have no administrative powers or duties which are delegated by ordinance and/or the job description to the chief administrative officer. 
(Ord. No. 05-02-144, § II, 2-15-2005) 
Secs. 2-99-2-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FINANCE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-125-2-146. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT AND EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 2-147. - District area designated and established. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen hereby find that areas zoned general commercial (C-3), planned commercial district (C-4), and all commercial areas within planned unit development districts (PUDs) and planned business parks (PBPs) according to the city's zoning map, as it may be amended from time to time, are the areas within the city in which commercial or mercantile activity is or has traditionally occurred and will continue to occur hereafter. Therefore, the areas zoned general commercial (C-3), planned commercial district (C-4), and all commercial areas within planned unit development districts (PUDs) and planned business parks (PBPs) according to the city's zoning map, as it may be amended from time to time, are hereby designated and established as the central business district of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-183, § II, 2-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-148. - Grant of exemption. 
    Whether to grant an exemption under MCA 1972, §§ 17-21-5 or 27-31-31, as well as the determination of the duration and amount of any such exemption, shall be determined by the mayor and board of aldermen on a case by case basis. This determination may take into consideration the nature of the use proposed for the structure; the location of the improvement; the potential for the generation of tax revenues from the property other than ad valorem taxes assessed against the improvement; the need for economic development or redevelopment in the specific area; the total monetary value of the project under consideration; aesthetic and/or historical value of the improvement or renovation; or any other factor specific to the property being improved. The adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall not be construed as a guarantee of an exemption or the grant to any person or entity of a property right in an exemption. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-183, § III, 2-5-2008) 
Secs. 2-149-2-179. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PUBLIC RECORDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Mississippi Public Records Act of 1983, MCA 1972, § 25-61-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-180. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public records shall mean all books, records, papers, accounts, letters, maps, photographs, films, cards, tapes, recordings or reproduction thereof, and any other documentary materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, having been used, being in use, or prepared, possessed or retained for use in the conduct, transaction or performance of any business, transaction, work, duty or function of any public body, or required to be maintained by any public body. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § I, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-181. - Exceptions and/or exemptions. 
    Exceptions and/or exemptions are the same as the exceptions or exemptions to the Mississippi Public Records Act of 1983 found in MCA 1972, §§ 25-61-9 and 25-61-11, as amended, which Code sections are reprinted below and incorporated herein. All other exemptions and exceptions will also be those as designated by any federal and/or state law, city ordinance, rules or regulations and the Federal Privacy Act. 
(1)  Section 25-61-9. Trade secrets and confidential commercial or financial information. 
a.  Records furnished to public bodies by third parties which contain trade secrets or confidential commercial or financial information shall not be subject to inspection, examination, copying or reproduction under this article until notice to said third parties has been given, but such records shall be released within a reasonable period of time unless the said third parties shall have obtained a court order protecting such records as confidential. 
b.  If any public record which is held to be exempt from disclosure pursuant to this article contains material which is not exempt pursuant to this article, the public body shall separate the exempt material and make the nonexempt material available for examination and/or copying as provided for in this article. 
c.  Trade secrets and confidential commercial and financial information of a proprietary nature developed by a college or university under contract with a firm, business, partnership, association, corporation, individual or other like entity shall not be subject to inspection, examination, copying or reproduction under this article. 
d.  Misappropriation of a trade secret shall be governed by the provisions of the Mississippi Uniform Trade Secrets Act, sections 75-26-1 through 75-26-19. 
e.  A waste minimization plan and any updates developed by generators and facility operators under the Mississippi Comprehensive Multimedia Waste Minimization Act of 1990 shall be retained at the facility and shall not be subject to inspection, examination, copying or reproduction under this article. 
f.  1.  Data processing software obtained by an agency under a licensing agreement that prohibits its disclosure and which software is a trade secret, as defined in section 75-26-3, and data processing software produced by a public body which is sensitive must not be subject to inspection, copying or reproduction under this chapter. 
2.  As used in this subsection f., the term "sensitive" means only those portions of data processing software, including the specifications and documentation, used to: 
(i)  Collect, process, store, and retrieve information which is exempt under this article. 
(ii)  Control and direct access authorizations and security measures for automated systems. 
(iii)  Collect, process, store, and retrieve information, disclosure of which would require a significant intrusion into the business of the public body. 
(2)  Section 25-61-11. Records exempted or privileged by law. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to conflict with, amend, repeal or supersede any constitutional or statutory law or decision of a court of this state or the United States which at the time of this article is effective or thereafter specifically declares a public record to be confidential or privileged, or provides that a public record shall be exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § II, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-182. - Purpose and response. 
    Municipalities must, according to MCA 1972, § 25-61-5(1)(a), (b), make a public record available to any person within seven working days, from the date of the request, provided a written policy is established. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § III, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-183. - Request applications. 
    All requests must contain the date; the specific record requested; the name, address and telephone number of the individual and/or organization making the request; if the request is for inspecting a public record or if a copy is requested; and the manner of delivery if the request is for a copy. All requests are to be clear, concise and shall be directed toward only one subject matter per request. Any omissions or errors by the requesting party shall be corrected before the city will consider the request complete. The city will permit inspection of or provide the requested public record within seven working days of receipt of the application or corrected application. If a public record is unable to be produced by the seventh working day after the request is made, a written explanation to the person making the request stating that the record requested will be produced and specifying with particularity why the records cannot be produced within the seven-day period. Unless there is mutual agreement of the parties, in no event shall the date for the production of the requested records be any later than 14 working days from the receipt of the original request. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § IV, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-184. - Cost. 
(a)  The following listed costs are the reasonable expected costs, but the city is not limited to the estimated cost and may collect the actual costs incurred as set forth hereinafter: 
Copies of any police reports, to include, but not be limited to, offense reports and accident reports, unless specifically listed elsewhere in this article. Cost First page $10.00 Subsequent pages $2.00 each Fingerprinting service-one or two cards $10.00 Additional cards $4.00 each Voter registration listing (complete listing) $200.00 Per ward $50.00 each Privilege license listing (business listing) $50.00 Utility deposit listing $100.00 Court dockets (each page-plus search fee) $2.00  
(1)  Computer printouts not specified above will be charged at $2.00 per page, provided said printout is available and currently stored on the computer, plus search fee. 
(2)  Any other requested reproduction of records will be at a cost reasonably calculated to cover the cost of the actual cost of searching plus a fee of $1.00 per page reproduced on a copy machine. This section shall apply to, but is not limited to, ordinances and minutes. 
(3)  Cost for copying information onto a disk will have the same charges as does the cost for paper copies. 
(b)  In addition, if there are other costs for hand copying, postage, or other actual expenses involved, they also shall be included. 
(c)  All requests, which entail search time, will be assessed at a cost of $16.00 per hour with a minimum $16.00 charge per request. A minimum $16.00 search fee deposit shall be required with each request. 
(d)  All requests to inspect any public records at city hall will be assessed for search time and time to retrieve, produce, and replace said records after inspection at a cost of $16.00 per hour with a minimum $16.00 charge per request. A minimum $16.00 search fee deposit shall be required with each inspection request. 
(e)  Such fees shall be payable in advance. This charge shall be an estimate of the actual cost. In the event of lower actual cost, a refund will be made. In the event of the actual cost exceeding the estimate, the balance shall be due prior to examining or receiving copies of the public record. Any delay in receiving this fee may result in an extension of the seven working day time limit specified in section 2-183. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § V, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-185. - Denial of request. 
    Denial by the city, mayor, board of aldermen, city attorney or city clerk of a request for a public record, according to MCA 1972, § 25-61-5(3), must be in writing and must contain a statement of the specific exemption relied upon by the public body for the denial. A file will be maintained of all denials of requests for public records for not less than three years from the date of the denial. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § VI, 6-1-2010) 
Sec. 2-186. - Exemptions. 
    Pursuant to MCA 1972, § 99-43-8, upon request, the victim has the right to receive, free of charge, a copy of the initial incident report of the victim's case, subject to any confidentiality requirements provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 10-06-198, § VII, 6-1-2010; Ord. No. 12-07-205, 7-3-2012) 
Chapter 4 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Alcoholic beverages, MCA 1972, § 67-1-1 et seq.; intoxicating beverages offenses, MCA 1972, §§ 97-31-1 et seq., 99-27-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Enforcement. 
    The ordinance from which this chapter is derived shall take effect from and after its adoption and shall be enforced by any lawful officer of the city or county. 
(Ord. No. 73-11, § 4, 5-15-1973) 
Sec. 4-2. - Retail sale of beer and light wine. 
    It shall be unlawful in the city, for the holder of a permit authorizing the sale of beer and wine at retail: 
(1)  If the permit is for off-premises consumption, to sell or give away any beer or light wine before 7:00 a.m. or after 1:00 a.m. daily. 
(2)  If the permit is for on-premises consumption, to sell, give, dispense or permit to be consumed in or upon the premises any beer or light wine Monday through Saturday before 10:00 a.m. or after 12:00 midnight the following day; and on Sunday before 11:00 a.m. or after 11:00 p.m. 
(3)  To sell or store beer or wine within 400 feet of any church, school, kindergarten, or funeral home; however, if the permitted retailer is located within an area zoned commercial, such minimum distance shall not be less than 100 feet. The distance shall be measured from the actual location of the business to the building housing the church, school, kindergarten or funeral home. 
(4)  To permit the consumption of beer or wine on the premises of any retail establishment unless such establishment is regularly and in a bona fide manner used and kept open for the serving of meals to guests for compensation and which has suitable seating facilities for guests and has suitable kitchen facilities connected therewith for cooking an assortment of foods and meals commonly ordered at various times of the day; the service of such food as sandwiches and salads only shall not be deemed in compliance with this requirement. No place shall qualify as a restaurant under these rules and regulations unless 50 percent or more of the revenue is derived from meals and not from the sale of alcoholic beverages; provided, however, this subsection (4) shall not apply to a club organized not primarily for pecuniary profit, but for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space in a building of such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its members and their guests and having no member, officer, agent or employee of the club paid directly or indirectly in the form of a salary or other compensation for any profit from the distribution or sale of alcoholic beverages to the club or to members or guests of the club beyond such a salary or compensation as may be fixed or voted at a proper meeting by the board of directors or other governing authority. 
(5)  Each retail establishment where the sale of beer or wine for consumption on premises is permitted shall have the burden of proving that 50 percent or more of the revenue derived from such place shall be from the serving of meals as aforesaid and not from the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(6)  It will be the duty of every such retailer of alcoholic beverages to keep and preserve for a period of three years, records of the gross income, gross receipts, or gross proceeds of the sales of the business, including all invoices of merchandise purchased, all bank statements and cancelled checks, and all other books or accounts as may be necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. 
(7)  Retailers engaged in sales for on-premises consumption shall use an accounting method to separate alcoholic beverage sales from food sales. Said records shall be adequate in substance to conform to generally accepted accounting practices and all such records shall be written in the English language. All records shall be open for examination at any time by the city clerk, police chief, mayor or any other person so authorized or designated by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 10-04-197, § 2, 4-20-2010; Ord. No. 14-05-220, 5-20-2014) 
Secs. 4-3-4-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OPEN CONTAINER REGULATIONS 

Sec. 4-25. - Purpose. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen have determined that it is necessary to promote the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens to adopt an ordinance to prohibit the possession in public of alcoholic beverages in an open container. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-151, § 1, 9-6-2005) 
Sec. 4-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage means any distilled spirits, liquor, beer, wine, or alcoholic mixture. 
    Open container means any container that is open; any container which the seal has been broken; or any other cup, glass, etc. which has an alcoholic beverage in it. 
    Public place means any state, county or city highway, roadway, street or sidewalk, or any public premises, parking lot, or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, recreation or other lawful purposes. 
    Vehicle means any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-151, § 2, 9-6-2005) 
Sec. 4-27. - Prohibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drink or have in his possession any open container of alcoholic beverage, while such person is in any vehicle or public place, except those premises duly licensed for the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages on said premises. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-151, § 3, 9-6-2005) 
Sec. 4-28. - Exemptions. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the right to exempt any special event from the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-09-151, § 4, 9-6-2005) 
Secs. 4-29-4-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALCOHOL AND PUBLIC PROPERTY 

Sec. 4-60. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic beverage means any distilled spirits, liquor, beer, wine, or alcoholic mixture. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-165, § I, 8-15-2006) 
Sec. 4-61. - Sale, distribution, possession, and consumption on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, distribute, possess, or consume any alcoholic beverage in or upon any public street, sidewalk, alley, ground, building, park, or place owned, maintained, and/or operated by the city, except at a group function for which a permit has been obtained from the chief of police as provided herein. 
(b)  A person seeking issuance of a permit required by subsection (a) of this section shall file an application with the chief of police on forms provided by him. An application for a permit shall be filed with the chief of police not less than 30 days before the date on which the proposed activity is to take place. 
(c)  The application for a permit required by subsection (a) of this section shall set forth the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person seeking the permit. 
(2)  The name, address, and telephone number of the local headquarters of the organization or association requesting the permit and of the authorizing and responsible governing body or board of such organization or association. 
(3)  The name, address, and telephone number of the person who will be the chairman and who will be responsible for the conduct of the activity. 
(4)  The date when the activity is to be conducted. 
(5)  The specific location of the activity proposed. 
(6)  The approximate number of persons who will participate in the activity. 
(7)  The hours when such activity will start and terminate. 
(8)  A general description of the activity, including whether such activity will include rides, games, music (live or recorded), or other loud or disturbing noises. 
(9)  The alcoholic beverage to be distributed at the activity, and specifically whether the applicant intends to distribute light wine and beer of an alcoholic content of not more than five percent by weight and/or whether the applicant intends to distribute an alcoholic beverage or more than five percent of alcohol by weight A copy of the appropriate permit issued by the state tax commission shall be attached to the application. 
(10)  Proof of liability insurance, including alcoholic beverage distribution coverage, in an amount not less than $1,000,000.00. Such insurance shall name the city as additional insured. 
(11)  Detailed security measures for the activity in general, including measures that address the prohibition of minors consuming beer, wine or alcoholic beverages. 
(12)  Any additional information that the chief of police shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued. 
(d)  The chief of police shall act upon the application for a permit required by subsection (a) of this section within five business days after the filing thereof. If the chief of police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the applicant within five business days after the date upon which the application was filed a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the permit. Any denial of a permit may be appealed to the mayor and board of aldermen by filing a written appeal within ten days of date of the denial and setting forth the reasons why the denial should be reversed. 
(e)  If the location of the proposed activity is a public park owned, maintained, and/or operated by the city, then the application for a permit required by subsection (a) of this section shall also be subject to the approval of the director of parks. Further, the applicant must submit any and all additional applications that may be required by the director of parks for the use of any public park. 
(f)  Any permit issued pursuant to this article shall constitute an exemption to the city's open container ordinance, as provided for in section 4-28 and shall be deemed to comply with the permit requirements of chapter 14, article II. 
(g)  Any permit issued pursuant to this article is personal to the applicant said permit shall neither authorize nor allow any person or entity, other than the person or entity set forth in the permit, to sale or distribute alcoholic beverages at the activity. Therefore, it shall be unlawful for any person or entity (including those associated with the activity) to sell or distribute any alcoholic beverage at the activity without a permit issued pursuant to this article. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person attending the activity (including those associated with the activity) to possess or consume any alcoholic beverage at the activity, not sold or distributed by the permit holder at the activity. 
(h)  The sale, distribution, possession, and consumption of alcoholic beverages as authorized in this article shall be subject to compliance with all applicable laws and regulations of the state and all other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 06-08-165, § II, 8-15-2006) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, except Homo sapiens. 
    Animal control division means the review and enforcement authority under the supervision of the police department and empowered to administer this chapter. 
    Animal control officer means any person designated by the city as an animal control officer or a police officer, who is qualified to perform such duties under the laws of this state. 
    Animal shelter means any facility operated by a humane society or municipal agency, or its authorized agents, for the purpose of impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this chapter or state law. 
    Feral dog means a dog that has escaped from domestication and becomes wild, dangerous, or untamed. 
    Owner means any person, partnership, or corporation owning, keeping or harboring one or more animals. An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered. However, an individual who harbors or otherwise provides sustenance to a stray animal(s) for a period not to exceed three or more consecutive days shall not be deemed the owner for the sole purpose of releasing the stray animal(s) to the city animal shelter, which stray animal(s) shall be immediately impounded by the city animal shelter; additionally, said individual shall not be required to pay the relinquishment fee(s). 
    Performing animal exhibition means any spectacle, display, act, or event, other than a circus, in which performing animals are used. 
    Pet means any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. 
    Pet store is any place of business, which sells birds, fish, reptiles, or mammals intended for use as pets; however, the term "pet store" shall not include commercial and hobby breeders. 
    Public nuisance means any animal which: 
(1)  Molests passers-by or passing vehicles; 
(2)  Attacks other animals; 
(3)  Trespasses on school grounds, city parks, or private property; 
(4)  Repeatedly runs at large; 
(5)  Damages private or public property; 
(6)  Barks, whines, screams or howls in an excessive, continuous, or untimely fashion; 
(7)  Defecates or frequently urinates on public property or private property of one other than its owner; or 
(8)  Is allowed by its owner to become a nuisance to people or other animals. 
    Restraint means the condition of securing any animal, by leash or lead of less than six feet, within the fenced real property limits of its owner, or by tethering such a way that the animal is within the real property limits of its owner. 
    Running at large means any animal not under restraint. 
    Serious injury means any combination of bites, scratches or abrasions which may require suture or other medical treatment. 
    Severe injury means an injury that includes any of the following: 
(1)  Broken bones; 
(2)  Lacerations that require multiple sutures; 
(3)  Disfiguring lacerations; 
(4)  Lacerations which require cosmetic surgery; or 
(5)  Multiple lacerations. 
    Veterinary hospital means any establishment maintained and operated by a licensed veterinarian for surgery, diagnosis and treatment of diseases and injuries of animals. 
    Vicious animal means any animal, except dogs, that constitutes a threat to human beings or other animals. 
    Vicious dogs means: 
(1)  Any dog which has shown a propensity, tendency, or disposition to attack when unprovoked, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals. 
(2)  Any dog which, when unprovoked: 
a.  Bites, inflicts injury, assaults, or otherwise attacks a human being or domestic animal on public or private property; or 
b.  Chases or approaches a person upon the streets, sidewalks or on any public grounds in a menacing or terrorizing manner or apparent attitude of attack. 
(3)  Any dog which is owned or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of dog fighting or any dog trained for dog fighting. 
(4)  Notwithstanding the above, a dog may not be considered a vicious dog if an injury or damage is sustained by a person who, at the time of such injury or damage was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the dog, or was teasing, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. A dog may not be considered vicious, if the dog was protecting or defending a human being, within the immediate vicinity of the dog, from an unjustified attack or assault. 
    Wild animal means any raccoon, bear, fox, poisonous snake, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx, or any other warm blooded animal which can normally be found in the wild state and is not ordinarily domesticated by man, whether raised in captivity or in the wild. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 1, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 16-08-239, 8-2-2016) 
Sec. 6-2. - Police department, animal control officer to enforce chapter; interfering with prohibited. 
(a)  The civil and criminal provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the division of animal control and the police department. 
(b)  Any officer or animal control officer having probable cause that a person has violated a section of this chapter may, in lieu of obtaining a misdemeanor warrant for arrest of such person, issue to said person a written citation requiring said person to appear at a date and time in the municipal court to answer to the charge or charges specified in the citation. 
(c)  It shall be a violation of this chapter to interfere with an animal control officer in the performance of his duties. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 2, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-3. - Cruelty to animals, fighting animals, etc. 
    No person shall beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate, promote or permit any dogfight, cockfight, bullfight, or other combat between animals or between animals and humans, unless otherwise permitted by law. The animal control officer shall have the authority to take an abused animal into protective custody pending disposition of charges of cruelty or abuse against the owner. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 4, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-4. - Exposing to poisons. 
    No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same may be eaten by any animal; provided that, it shall not be unlawful for a person to expose on his own property common pest control poison mixed with only vegetable substances. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 5, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-5. - Chopping dog's ears or performing other surgical procedure. 
    No person except a licensed veterinarian shall crop the ears of any dog or perform any surgical procedures on animals. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 6, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-6. - Leaving unattended animals inside motor vehicles; authority to remove from vehicle. 
    It shall be unlawful to leave an animal unattended inside a motor vehicle when such action is potentially harmful to said animal. The division of animal control or any police officer shall have the authority to remove an animal from such a vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 7, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-7. - Operator of vehicle striking animal to report accident. 
    Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal shall at once report the accident to the police department, the division of animal control or to the local humane society. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 8, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-8. - Keeping of animals within city limits. 
(a)  Keeping animals, fowl near residences prohibited; exception for dogs and cats. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any chickens, ducks, geese, turkeys or other domestic fowl of any kind, or any sheep, cattle, mules, goats, horses or any other four-legged animal of any kind, within 250 feet of any building or structure in the city used as a residence. The provisions of this section shall not apply to keeping and maintaining cats and dogs. 
(b)  Swine prohibited; exception for dealers. It shall be unlawful for any person to raise or keep hogs and pigs within the corporate limits of the city; provided that this section shall not apply to dealers in hogs and pigs who are hereby permitted to maintain hog and pig pens in areas zoned for such; provided, however, that such pens shall meet the sanitary requirements of the state health department. 
(c)  Number of animals limited. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow, or harbor more than four domesticated animals, over the age of three months, at any residence or in any one yard or open premises of a residence, at any one time. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to permit, allow, or harbor more than 12 domesticated animals, ages three months and under, at any residence or in any one yard or open premises of a residence, at any one time. Said animals shall at all times be leashed or enclosed in a fence and shall not be permitted to run at large in violation of other provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 9, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 07-03-173, § 1, 3-6-2007) 
Sec. 6-9. - Molesting birds, bird's nest prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to kill, wound, or injure in any manner whatsoever or to fire or shoot with a gun, pistol, arrow or any other deadly weapon or to throw any stone or other missile at or to catch or capture, or to set traps, or spread nets or snare, with intent to catch or capture any birds of any kind whatsoever, within the corporate limits of the city. It shall also be unlawful for any person to break, tear down, or destroy any bird's nest or the eggs or other contents of the nest. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 10, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-10. - Domestic fowl running at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who may own or have in his possession or control, any chicken, duck, turkey, goose, or other domestic fowl to intentionally, knowingly, carelessly or negligently permit any such domestic fowl to run at large within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 11, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-11. - Livestock running at large or allowing on streets or sidewalks prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who may own or have in his possession or control any horse, mule, ox, cow, yearling, sheep, goat, or hog to intentionally, knowingly, carelessly or negligently permit such animals to run or be at large at any time within the corporate limits of the city. It shall also be unlawful for any person who may own or have in his possession or control any animal mentioned in this section to stake or tether such animal on any vacant property in the city adjacent to any street or sidewalk or so near thereto as to allow or permit such animal to be or go upon any sidewalk or street within the corporate limits of the city. Horses used by the police department shall be excluded from this prohibition. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 12, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-12. - Keeping of wild animals. 
(a)  For display or exhibition. No person shall keep or permit to be kept on his premises, or in any roadside zoo or pet store, any wild animal for display or for exhibition purposes, whether gratuitously or for a fee. This subsection (a) shall not be construed to apply to zoological parks, petting zoos, performing animal exhibitions, or circuses. 
(b)  As pets. No person shall keep or permit to be kept any leopard, cheetah, lion, tiger, panther, cougar, bear, coyote, wolf, alligator or crocodile or any wild animal in any area zoned residential (with the exception of the AR zone). Wild animals, harbored as pets, may be allowed in areas zoned A and AR where such is authorized by state or federal law. 
(c)  Exotic animals. No person shall keep or permit to be kept on his premises any exotic animals, such as, potbelly pigs, ferrets, wolf hybrid, fainting goats, snakes, mini horses, etc., in any area zoned residential (with the exception of the AR zone), without first securing a special permit. The permits shall be obtained from the division of animal control. The supervisor of the division of animal control or his designee shall first inspect the premises and cages to be used for housing the animal. The fee for a permit under this section shall be $10.00. 
(d)  Enforcement. The supervisor of the animal control shall have the power to release, order the release, or seize any wild animal being kept in violation of this chapter, federal law or state statue and shall notify the state department of wildlife. 
(e)  Special permit. Any owner of any wild animal that has owned and kept within the city limits for two years or more, to continue to lawfully keep such animal must, within 90 days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, apply for a special permit from the supervisor of animal control, who shall, before issuing said permit, inspect the premises where such animal has been kept to ascertain if special precautions and confinement and proper care facilities are present and functioning and have been so present and utilized during said two-year period and, if the premises meet with the approval of the supervisor and the owner agrees to continue such precautions which are in effect and submit to inspection upon two days' written notice from the supervisor, said special permit shall be issued. In this regard, the animal control supervisor shall establish regulations for the confinement and proper care of any wild animal. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 13, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-13. - Keeping of vicious animals or vicious dogs; penalty. 
(a)  A vicious dog shall be securely confined indoors or confined in a securely enclosed and childproofed locked pen or structure upon the premises of the person owning or harboring same. Such pen or structure must have secure sides and a secure top. If the pen or structure has no bottom secured to the sides, the sides must be embedded in the ground no less than two feet. 
(b)  No person owning or harboring or having the care of a vicious dog shall suffer or permit such dog to go beyond the premises of such person unless such dog is securely leashed and muzzled, except that a vicious dog shall not be required to be muzzled when shown either in a sanctioned American Kennel Club show or upon prior approval of the animal control supervisor. Such dog may not be leashed to inanimate objects, e.g. trees, buildings, etc. and the muzzle must be sufficient to prevent such dog from biting persons or other animals. 
(c)  No vicious dog may be kept on a porch or patio or any part of a house or structure that would allow the dog to exit such building on its own volition. In addition, no such animal may be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or doors are the only obstacles preventing the dog from exiting the structure. 
(d)  All owners, keepers, or harborers of vicious dogs with the city shall, within ten days of the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, display in a prominent place on their premises a sign easily readable by the public using such words as "Beware of Dog." In addition, a similar sign shall be posed on the kennel or pen of such animal. In addition, the owner shall conspicuously display a sign with a warning symbol that informs children of the presence of a dangerous dog. 
(e)  The owner or harborer of any dog, which according to the records of the animal control division, seriously injures a person without provocation or which has aggressively killed a domestic animal shall be required to provide public liability insurance in a single incident amount of $50,000.00 for bodily injury to or death of any person or persons or for damage to property resulting from the ownership, keeping or maintenance of such dog. Such insurance shall contain a provision that the same may not be cancelled until 15 days' notice of cancellation has been given to the animal control division. 
(f)  Every vicious animal shall be confined by the owner within a building or secure enclosure and shall be securely muzzled or caged whenever off the premises of the owner. 
(g)  The persons having the enforcement duty under this chapter may enter the premises where a vicious dog or animal is kept for the purpose of inspection of the premises to ascertain whether such complies with the provisions of this chapter. Such inspection shall be made only after notice to an adult occupant of the premises. 
(h)  This section shall not apply to dogs kept by law enforcement agencies. 
(i)  In addition to any other penalty the municipal court may impose upon a person convicted of a violation of this section, the court shall impose a mandatory fine of $250.00 for violation of this section or any part thereof, of which no portion of the fine may be suspended. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 14, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-14. - Responsibility of owner. 
(a)  No owner shall fail to: 
(1)  Exercise proper care and control of his animals including, but not limited to, dogs or cats; 
(2)  Prevent them from becoming a public nuisance as defined in section 6-1, or private nuisance; or 
(3)  Comply with the standards set out next below and all other provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any lot or stall or stable, or other place where animals are kept, to be in an unclean, filthy or unsanitary condition. All lots, stalls, stables, pens, yards and other places where cattle, horses, mules, hogs, dogs, cats or other animals are kept for any purpose whatsoever, anywhere in the city, shall be kept clean and wholesome by removal of all offensive matter and by suitable cleansing and disinfecting as often as may be necessary, which care is hereby required and made the duty of every person having, owning or controlling such places. 
(c)  The owner of every animal including, but not limited to, cats and dogs, shall remove any fecal matter deposited by such animals on public walks, streets, recreation areas, or private property of another. It shall be unlawful for the owner of any property to allow unsanitary or malodorous conditions to develop on his property due to the keeping, maintaining, owning or harboring of animals. Yards, pens, premises and animals shall be kept free of insect infestations. 
(d)  Animal pens or enclosures shall be large enough to provide reasonable freedom of movement to the animals contained therein. 
(e)  No owner of an animal shall abandon such animal or fail to maintain such animal in a healthy condition or to provide appropriate veterinary treatment immediately, if ill. 
(f)  No owner shall fail to provide his animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather and to generally provide humane care and treatment. 
(g)  If probable cause exists that any animal or animals including, but not limited to, dogs and cats are kept under such conditions as to constitute a nuisance in violation of this chapter, a petition for abatement shall be filed in the municipal court, specifically noting the offending conditions, a copy of which shall be served on the owner or harborer of said animals, with a notice to appear in said court at a specific time and place to show cause if any why an order of abatement should not be entered against him. If evidence establishes that the offending conditions, or any combination of them are present, the court shall order the same abated with 15 days and assess court costs against the party responsible for said conditions. In lieu of petition for abatement, the animal control division may issue a written warning of offending nuisance conditions. If a previous abatement order has been entered against a person within 12 months of a second charge of violation of this section, and the same or similar offending nuisance conditions are found on the premises cited, then a mandatory fine shall be assessed against said person in the amount of $100.00 and the condition again ordered to be abated. Upon a third offense, the person responsible shall suffer a minimum mandatory fine of $250.00 if convicted of failing to meet the standards of responsibility established by this section. Neither mandatory fine shall be suspended. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 15, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-15. - Vaccination of dogs and cats against rabies. 
(a)  Required. Any person owning, keeping, harboring, or having custody of any dog or cat three months of age or older within the city shall have that animal vaccinated against rabies with the approved dosage of an approved antirabic virus (vaccine) properly administrated by one legally authorized to do so; it shall be unlawful for any person to own or have in his possession any dog or cat not so vaccinated. Every dog or cat must be vaccinated in accordance with the Compendium of Animal Rabies Vaccines as prepared by the National Association of State Public Health Veterinarians, Inc. 
(b)  Tag bearing vaccination serial numbers to be worn. The owner of any dog or cat shall see that the animal wears a securely braided metal tag with the serial number of the vaccination and the year in which the animal was inoculated stamped thereon and shall see that the collar and tag are worn by the animal at all times. 
(c)  Penalties for violations. The failure to comply with this section shall constitute a misdemeanor, and the offender shall, on conviction thereof, be fined $50.00 for the first offense, $75.00 for the second offense and $100.00 for the third and any subsequent offense. It shall be the duty of the division of animal control to enforce this section. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 16, 5-20-2003) 
State Law reference- General requirement concerning rabies inoculations, MCA 1972, § 41-53-41 et seq. 
Sec. 6-16. - Permitting to run at large. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner of any animal to permit it to run at large within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Animals running at large may be impounded as provided elsewhere herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 17, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-17. - Giving away as prizes, inducements to trade, etc. 
    No person shall give away any live animal, fish, reptiles, or bird as a prize for, or an inducement to enter any contest, game, or other competition, or as an inducement to enter a place of amusement; or offer such vertebrate as an incentive to enter into any business agreement whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade, unless and except such person or organization shall have first obtained a permit for such activity from the supervisor of animal control. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 18, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-18. - Pet stores. 
    Pet stores shall be subject to inspection on demand by the supervisor of animal control. This inspection, among other things, shall examine the premises to determine if the animals are being kept under sanitary and humane conditions and in a reasonable state of health and are being provided with sufficient amounts of fresh, clean, wholesome food and water. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 19, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-19. - Performing animal exhibitions or circuses. 
(a)  No performing animal exhibition or circus shall be permitted in which animals are induced or encouraged to perform through the use of chemical, mechanical, electrical, or manual devices in a manner which will cause or is likely to cause, physical injury or suffering. 
(b)  All equipment used on a performing animal shall fit properly and be in good working condition. An animal control officer shall be authorized to inspect the premises at any time upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 20, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-20. - Elimination of animals; when authorized. 
(a)  Vicious animal or feral or vicious dogs. When an animal is determined by the supervisor of animal control to be a vicious animal or feral or vicious dog, that animal may be immediately destroyed by the supervisor of animal control, or his designee, providing two of the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The animal is running at large or not properly confined or muzzled as described herein. 
(2)  There is no vaccination tag around the animal's neck. 
(3)  Attempts to peacefully capture the animal have been made and proven unsuccessful. 
(b)  Any animal that aggressively attacks and causes severe injury or death of any human shall be immediately confiscated by animal control, placed in quarantine for ten days, and thereafter be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. The provisions of this subsection (b) shall not apply if, at the time of such injury or death, the human was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the animal; or was teasing, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the animal; or was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(c)  Incurably injured or diseased animals, etc. It shall be the duty of the police and duly authorized animal control officer either to humanely euthanize with an injection, or to discharge a firearm, in order to mercifully end the life an of animal suffering from an incurable injury or disease or as the sole effective means of controlling a public nuisance or health hazard. Including, but not limited to, rabbits, squirrels, snakes, feral or vicious dogs and vicious animals. Reasonable efforts not to exceed two days shall be made to first locate the owner of any such injured animal. 
(d)  Any dog already classified as vicious which attacks any human or domestic animal and causes any type injury shall be immediately confiscated by animal control, placed in quarantine for ten days, and thereafter be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. The provisions of this subsection (d) shall not apply if, at the time of such injury, the human or domestic animal was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises occupied by the owner of the dog; or was teasing, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the dog; or if the human was committing or attempting to commit a crime. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 21, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-21. - Impoundment-Generally. 
(a)  Authority to seize; confinement period. An unrestrained dog or an animal constituting a public nuisance shall be taken by the police or animal control officers and impounded in an enclosure or animal shelter kept for that purpose, to be provided and maintained by the city, and there confined in a humane manner. Such an animal shall be kept for at least five days unless sooner claimed by the owner; impounded dogs and cats not suffering from an injury or infectious disease shall be kept for not less than five days. 
(b)  Immediate seizure. Any vicious dog shall be immediately seized by the division of animal control if the owner: 
(1)  Does not secure the liability insurance coverage required under section 6-13(e) within 30 days of enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived; 
(2)  Does not maintain the dog in a proper enclosure; or 
(3)  Willfully or negligently permits the dog outside the dwelling of the owner or outside the property enclosure and does not have the dog muzzled and under personal physical restraint of the owner. 
(c)  Notice to the owner; redemption. If by a tag or other means, the owner of an impounded animal can be readily identified, the animal control officer shall, upon impoundment, notify the owner by telephone or mail. Within five days, the rightful owner of any animal held under this section may, provided the animal is properly vaccinated, licensed and tagged, obtain the animal upon the payment of a pound fee; however, if an unvaccinated animal is claimed by the owner, the owner must make arrangements for the vaccination of said animal satisfactory to the supervisor of animal control. An owner reclaiming an impounded animal shall pay a fee as established by resolution or order of the governing authority. 
(d)  Unclaimed animals. It is not the intent or the desire of the animal control division or the city to become responsible for unclaimed dogs, cats, or other animals. If a dog, cat or other animal is impounded by the animal control division and the owner fails to claim the animal as provided in this section, the animal control officer or police officer shall issue the owner an affidavit for violation of this section. 
(e)  Disposition if not reclaimed by owner; waiver of waiting period. Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within five working days shall become the property of the city and shall be placed for adoption in a suitable home for a fee as established by resolution or order of the governing authority, or humanely euthanized with an injection; provided that, if an unclaimed animal is adopted, the adoptive owner must make arrangements for the vaccination of said animal satisfactory to the supervisor of animal control. The five-day waiting period is waived for a vicious or feral dog or cat, or for any animal suffering from an infectious disease. Pursuant to MCA 1972, § 97-41-3, an injured or neglected animal may be humanely euthanized without any waiting period. 
(f)  Additional proceedings against owner authorized. The owner of an impounded animal may also be proceeded against for any violation of this chapter. 
(g)  Fee established. An owner shall pay a relinquishment fee as established by resolution or order of the governing authority for any animal relinquished to the animal shelter. The owner must be a resident of the city in order to relinquish an animal to the shelter and must provide proof of vaccinations providing available space. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 22, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 12-02-204, § 1, 2-7-2012) 
Sec. 6-22. - Same-Livestock; claiming and redeeming procedure. 
    Any hog, cow, bull, sheep, goat, horse, or mule found straying or running at large shall be captured and impounded in an enclosure provided and maintained for such purpose by the division of animal control. Within five days of its capture, the rightful owner or owners of any animal so impounded may claim and obtain the release of the same by payment of an impoundment fee in the amount of $25.00 and a boarding fee in the amount of $5.00 per day for each day, or fraction thereof, during which the said animal has remained impounded. If any such animal is not claimed and redeemed by its owner within the five-day period, the same shall be sold at a lawfully constituted public livestock auction in satisfaction of all fees and expenses, with any surplus revenue kept by the city for one year for possible claim by the owner of said animal; thereafter said sum is to be transferred to the general fund for the city. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 23, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-23. - Same-Animals attacking, injuring persons; destruction of rabid animals. 
    In case of an attack by an animal resulting in injury to any person, such animal, unless otherwise provided herein, shall be impounded or caused to be confined by the animal control division for observation for a period of ten days, or the owner thereof may, upon notification to the animal control division, have such animal impounded for ten days with a private veterinarian licensed to practice veterinary medicine within the state. If at the end of said period of time, or any time prior thereto, it is determined that said animal has rabies, such animal shall be immediately destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 24, 5-20-2003) 
Sec. 6-24. - Conflict of provisions. 
    If any provision herein is deemed to conflict with any other provision of an ordinance of the city, the provision more restrictive shall control. 
(Ord. No. 03-05-122, § 27, 5-20-2003) 
Secs. 6-25-6-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADOPT-AN-ANIMAL PROGRAM 

Sec. 6-52. - Time frame. 
    All animals must be held for a minimum of five working days, unless sick or injured. 
(Ord. No. 90-04-07, § I, 4-24-1990) 
Sec. 6-53. - Cost and license requirement. 
    Any person adopting an animal will have ten days in which to purchase a license for said animal. The adoption fee will be as established by resolution or order of the governing authority. To receive a license, the city will require proof of vaccination. If the animal is less than six months old, then the new owners will be exempted from the ten-day rule, but must have the animal vaccinated as soon as the animal is old enough to receive said shots. 
(Ord. No. 90-04-07, § II, 4-24-1990) 
Sec. 6-54. - No city liability. 
    The city will not be responsible for the health of any animal, nor will the city be responsible for administering or paying for shots to any animal adopted. It will be the responsibility of the new owner to have the animal vaccinated. 
(Ord. No. 90-04-07, § III, 4-24-1990) 
Chapter 8 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority generally, MCA 1972, § 21-1-21; authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCA 1972, § 21-19-25. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Truss marking; general requirements. 
(a)  Definition. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Truss type construction means a fabricated structure of wood, cables or steel, made up of a series of members connected at their ends which may form a series of triangles to span a distance greater than would be possible with any of the individual members on their own. The term "truss type construction" shall not include individual wind or seismic bracing components which form triangles when diagonally connected to the main structural system. 
(1)  An approved emblem must be permanently affixed to the latch side of the main entrance door. Placement shall be on the address side of the structure within 18 inches of the face of the door frame and between the height of four feet and six feet. Structures without main entrances or with multiple doors must affix the emblem at all doors facing the address side. Structures with double leaf main entrance doors shall affix the emblem to either side of the doorway. Structures with breezeways shall affix an emblem at each breezeway on the address side of the structure. 
(2)  The city has authority to require additional emblems to be affixed to structures because of construction configuration or size. All locations should be approved by the appropriate representative of the city prior to affixing emblems. 
(3)  The emblem shall meet minimum specifications as follows in text. Truss construction identification emblem technical specifications: 
a.  Overall size. 
1.  Height: Three inches. 
2.  Width: Six inches. 
3.  Shape: Isosceles triangle. 
b.  Design. 
1.  Border: One-quarter-inch reflective red. 
2.  Background: Reflective white. 
3.  Text: Reflective red lettering in one-inch-tall bold Arial font. 
4.  Truss designations: 
(i)  R designates roof trusses. 
(ii)  F designates floor trusses. 
(iii)  F/R designates floor and roof trusses. 
c.  Emblem decal materials. 
1.  Printed on reflective 3M adhesive or equivalent. 
2.  Laminated for superior outdoor durability. 
d.  Emblem backer materials (for installations other than glass). 1/16 -inch-thick aluminum to prevent rust. 
e.  Application. 
1.  On glass: Apply emblem decal directly to glass with built-in, peel and stick adhesive. 
2.  On surfaces other than glass: Apply aluminum backed decal to surface using construction adhesive equivalent to "F-26" (not included.) 

(4)  The emblem must be in the shape of an isosceles triangle measuring a minimum of six inches horizontally and three inches vertically; and the emblem must have conspicuously printed on it the following letters, as appropriate, based on the type of truss construction used in the building being identified by the emblem: 
a.  "F" to signify a floor truss construction. 
b.  "R" to signify a roof truss construction. 
c.  "F/R" to signify both a floor and roof with truss construction. 
(5)  Along the base of the triangle shall be printed the words: "Do Not Remove By Order Of the Local Fire Inspector" in letters no smaller than one-quarter inch. 
(6)  The emblem shall not be removed or obstructed and shall be maintained by the owner of the building in a visible state at all times. 
(7)  The municipal official responsible for fire code enforcement shall be responsible for the enforcement of this chapter. 
(8)  Failure to affix and maintain a truss marking emblem to a structure as required herein shall be a violation of this chapter. 
(9)  This chapter shall not apply to a building with truss construction that is a detached one- or two-family residential structure. 
(b)  Penalty. 
(1)  A violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both. The minimum penalty for a first offense violation of this chapter shall be $100.00. 
(2)  Each day any violation of any provision of this chapter shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(3)  The penalties provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other remedies available to the governing authority through the institution of an action or proceeding in any court, including, but not limited to, an action or proceeding to enjoin any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-11-194, §§ 1, 2, 11-3-2009) 
Secs. 8-2-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNSAFE BUILDINGS 

Sec. 8-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Designated representative means any one of the following: planning director, code enforcement officer, or public works director. 
    Owner means a person, firm, partnership, association or corporation holding legal title of the said property or residing on said property or both. 
    Unsafe property environment includes any property which has more than six inches of grass in height, dilapidated buildings or any other unsafe item as determined by the governing authority or their designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 02-08-116, § 1, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 8-22. - Cause for citation. 
    Any unsafe property environment in the city for a period of more than 48 hours shall be cause for any representative of the city planning department to issue a citation. 
(Ord. No. 02-08-116, § 2, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 8-23. - Warning is permissible. 
    The department issuing a citation may provide to first offenders one warning of violation of this article, but are not obligated to issue said warning. 
(Ord. No. 02-08-116, § 3, 8-20-2002) 
Sec. 8-24. - Penalty. 
(a)  The owner of any unsafe property environment as defined in section 8-21 shall pay all expenses of removing or cleaning said property in accordance with MCA 1972, § 21-19-11, including, but not limited to, the cost of all damages to any equipment, as well as the following fines: 
Minimum Maximum 1 st Offense $100.00 $  200.00 Plus court costs 2 nd Offense  200.00    500.00 Plus court costs 3 rd and Subsequent offenses  300.00  1,000.00 Plus court costs  
(b)  A separate citation may be issued each 48 hours in which the violation is still occurring. 
(Ord. No. 02-08-116, § 4, 8-20-2002) 
Secs. 8-25-8-51. - Reserved.
