Sec. 8-52. - Adoption of codes. 
(a)  Adoption of 2012 edition of the International Building Code. A certain document, three copies of which are on file or electronically accessible in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Building Code, 2012 edition, including Appendix chapters E, F, G, I and J as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the building code of the city, regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, buildings and structures; by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use; and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition of such structures as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said building code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 8-53(a).

(2)  Section 109. Fees. 
Section 109.4. Work commencing before permit issuance. Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system before obtaining the necessary permits shall be subject to a fee established by the building official that shall be in addition to the required permit fees. Such fees shall be established as double the permit fee required. 
(3)  Section 113. Board of appeals. 
Section 113.1; General. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The board of appeals shall be the governing authority and shall hold office at its pleasure. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business. 
Section [A] 113.3; Qualifications. The board of appeals shall consist of members who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to building construction. 
Owners or occupants that wish to appeal a decision by the building code official made pursuant to this article or the International Fire Code or Building Code may do so by filing a written appeal to the mayor and board of aldermen within ten days of the code official's decision. The provision of this article shall not be held to deprive any federal and state agency, or any applicable governing body having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived or of any remedy then existing for enforcement of its order, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law.

(7)  Chapter 9. Fire protection systems; general sprinkler requirements. An approved automatic sprinkler system shall be provided for in the following new buildings and those undergoing substantial improvement as defined in this article and the ICC. 1.  Where a Group F-1 fire area exceeds 8,000 square feet. 
2.  Where the combined area of all Group F-I fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 16,000 square feet.

1.  Where a Group S-I fire area exceeds 8,000 square feet. 
2.  Where the combined area of all S-I fire areas on including any all floors mezzanines, exceeds 16,000 square feet. 
j.  Section 903.2.9.1. Repair garages will read: 
1.  Buildings two or more stories in height, including basements, with a fire area containing a repair garage exceeding 6,700 square feet. 
2.  One-story buildings with a fire area containing a repair garage exceeding 8,000 square feet. 
k.  Section 903.2.9.2. Bulk storage of tires will read: Buildings and structures where the area for the storage of tires exceeds 13,400 cubic feet shall.... 
l.  Section 903.2.10. Group S-2 will read: An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout all buildings containing a Group S-2 occupancy where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  Where a Group S-2 fire area exceeds 8,000 square feet; 
m.  Section 903.4.2. 
1.  Alarms. Add: All buildings that are required to have a fire sprinkler system shall provide in each tenant space visible/audible warning device(s) that actuation of the sprinkler system or fire alarm system will activate the device. 
2.  Firewalls. For the purpose of fire sprinkler separation footage, only four-hour rated firewalls with fire rated assemblies protecting all openings will separate building occupancies (Firewall). A four-hour fire-resistant wall that meets these requirements: 
(i)  Structural stability. Firewalls shall have sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall for the duration of four hours. 
(ii)  Horizontal continuity. Firewalls shall be continuous from exterior wall to exterior wall and shall extend at least 18 inches (457 mm) beyond the exterior surface of exterior walls. 
(iii)  Vertical continuity. Firewalls shall extend from the foundation to a termination point at least 30 inches (762 mm) above both adjacent roofs. Openings in the roof shall not be located within four feet (1,220 mm) of the firewall. 
n.  General truss marking requirements are in accordance with section 8-1.

(2)  Section 105.1. Add: Fees are established by city Ordinance No. 10-09-200. 
(3)  Section 108.1. Board of appeals established. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The board of appeals shall be the governing body and shall hold office at its pleasure. The fire code official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the fire code official. 
(4)  Section 108.3. Qualifications. The board of appeals shall consist of members who are qualified by experience and training to pass on matters pertaining to hazards of fire, explosions, hazardous conditions or fire protection systems. 
Owners or occupants that wish to appeal a decision by the fire code official made pursuant to this article or the International Fire Code or Building Code may do so by filing a written appeal to the mayor and board of aldermen within ten days of the fire code official's decision. The provision of this article shall not be held to deprive any federal and state agency, or any applicable governing body having jurisdiction, of any power or authority which it had on the effective date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived or of any remedy then existing for enforcement of its order, nor shall it deprive any individual or corporation of its legal rights as provided by law.

1.  Buildings having two or more stories above grade plane, including basements, with a fire area containing a repair garage exceeding 6,700 square feet.

1.  Where a Group S-2 fire area exceeds 8,000 square feet. 
2.  Mixed occupancies. All buildings 8,000 square feet or greater fire area not separated by the approved four-hour firewall set forth in this article shall have a fire sprinkler system. 
3.  Multi-tenant occupancy. 
Every other potential occupancy space shall have a monitored sprinkler cutoff valve and waterflow switch installed for accurate response from fire department personnel and to eliminate potential hazard from the entire building being disconnected from water system during construction of future tenant spaces. 
l.  Section 903.4.2 Alarms. Add: All buildings that are required to have a fire sprinkler system shall provide in each potential tenant space visible/audible warning device(s) that actuation of the sprinkler system or fire alarm system will activate the device. 
(8)  Commercial/industrial sprinkler service. 
a.  All fire service mains or hydrants that are part of a commercial/industrial fire suppression system fire loop shall be installed by a licensed sprinkler contractor who shall install the underground portion of the fire suppression system beginning at the city connection with approved materials. Fire loop hydrants shall be located not less than 40 feet (12.2 m) from the buildings to be protected. Hydrants shall be installed so that the steamer cap opening is facing the street and clears the finished grade by 18 inches or more in height. 
b.  Any building larger than one story, requiring a sprinkler system, shall have the fire department connection placed away from the building. All fire department connections shall be a five-inch Storz connection on a 30-degree elbow, placed no less than 11/2 times the height of the building away, in an area approved by the fire code official. The fire department connection shall be placed within 100 feet of a hydrant. 
(9)  For the purpose of this article, occupancies shall be classified in accordance with International Building and Fire codes. Any change of occupancy or change of hazard or class of hazard will require compliance with this code. 
(10)  For the purpose of this article, any building undergoing substantial improvement shall be brought to current code. The term "substantial improvement," for the purpose of determining compliance with this article, means any repair, alteration, addition or improvement of a building or structure, the cost of which equals or exceeds 50 percent of the accessed tax value of the structure, before the improvement or repair is started or the work area exceeds 50 percent of the gross floor area. If the structure has sustained substantial damage, any repairs are considered substantial improvement regardless of the actual repair work performed. 
(11)  Any addition to an existing building which brings the gross floor area above the applicable square footage listed in the above sections shall cause the entire building to meet the requirement of that section. 
(12)  Where these requirements conflict with the city building code, state, federal standards or local requirements, the most stringent shall apply. 
(13)  Firewalls. For the purpose of fire sprinkler separation footage, only four-hour rated firewalls with fire rated assemblies protecting all openings will separate building occupancies. (Firewall) A four-hour fire-resistant wall that meets these requirements: 
a.  Structural stability. Firewalls shall have sufficient structural stability under fire conditions to allow collapse of construction on either side without collapse of the wall for the duration of four hours. 
b.  Horizontal continuity. Firewalls shall be continuous from exterior wall to exterior wall and shall extend at least 18 inches (457 mm) beyond the exterior surface of exterior walls. 
c.  Vertical continuity. Firewalls shall extend from the foundation to a termination point at least 30 inches (762 mm) above both adjacent roofs. Openings in the roof shall not be located within four feet (1,220 mm) of the firewall. 
(14)  General truss marking requirements are in accordance with section 8-1. 
(15)  Section 506. Key boxes. 
d.  Section 506.1 Where required. Where access to or within a structure or an area is restricted because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for life-saving or firefighting purposes, the fire code official is authorized to require a key box to be installed by the property owner in an approved location. The key box shall be of an approved type and shall contain keys to gain necessary access as required by the fire code official. Manufacture specifications shall be used to determine number of keys to be allowed to be stored in box. Due consideration shall be given to box size needed. 
e.  Section 506.1.1. Locks. An approved lock shall be installed by the property owner on gates or similar barriers when required by the fire code official. A two-position electric override key switch shall be installed by the property owner for emergency access to gated communities, apartment complexes, parking garages and industrial gated areas and to control electrical equipment vital to emergency operations.

a.  Section 5704.2.9.6.1. Geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited: M1, M2, PBP per zoning ordinance. 
b.  Section 5706.2.4.4. Geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited: M1, M2, PBP per zoning ordinance. 
c.  Section 5806.2. Geographic limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers is prohibited: M1, M2, PBP per zoning ordinance. 
d.  Section 6104.2. Geographic limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas: M1, M2, PBP per zoning ordinance.

(4)  Section R112.1. General. In order to hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the building official relative to the application and interpretation of this code, there shall be and is hereby created a board of appeals. The building official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board of appeals shall be the governing body and shall hold office at its pleasure. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the building official.

(6)  Section P2603.6.1. Insert: 14, 14. 
(7)  Section R313.2. 
a.  One-family dwellings automatic fire systems. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall be installed in one-family dwellings that are 5,000 square feet aggregate or more under roof. 
b.  Multiple family and two-family dwellings automatic fire sprinkler systems. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall be installed all multiple family dwellings. 
c.  Lodginghouses, roominghouses, boardinghouses and bed and breakfast. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall be installed in all lodging, rooming and bed and breakfast establishments. 
d.  Exception. An automatic residential fire sprinkler system shall not be required for additions or alterations to existing buildings that are not already provided with an automatic residential sprinkler system unless alterations or additions exceed the outlined sections below: 
1.  Alteration is any construction or renovation to an existing structure other than a repair or addition and shall not require the installation of a residential fire sprinkler system. 
2.  Repair is the restoration to good or sound condition of any part of an existing building for the purpose of its maintenance and shall not require the installation of a residential fire sprinkler system. 
3.  Addition. An extension or increase in floor area, number of stories, or height of a building or structure that brings the total aggregate area of the building to less than 5,000 square feet under roof shall not be required to install a residential fire sprinkler system. Additions that bring the total aggregate area equal to or greater than 5,000 square feet under roof shall be provided with an automatic residential fire sprinkler system.

(6)  Section 506.3.2.5 Grease duct test. Prior to the use or concealment of any portion of a grease duct system, a leakage test shall be performed. Ducts shall be considered to be concealed where installed in shafts or covered by coatings or wraps that prevent the ductwork from being visually inspected on all sides. The permit holder shall be responsible to provide the necessary equipment and perform the grease duct leakage test. A smoke test shall be performed to determine that all welded and brazed joints are liquid tight. A smoke test shall be performed by sealing all intakes and exhaust ducts at their termination points and dropping smoke emitters with enough smoke to positively charge the ducts with smoke. A test shall be performed for the entire duct system, including the hood-to-duct connection. The duct work shall be permitted to be tested in sections, provided that every joint is tested. For listed factory-built grease ducts, this test shall be limited to duct joints assembled in the field and shall exclude factory welds.

ARTICLE IV. - MOVING STRUCTURES ON CITY STREETS 

Sec. 8-80. - Permit required. 
    No house or other large structure shall be hauled, towed, or moved on any city street until the person moving such house or structure shall first obtain a permit as hereafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 74-19, § 1, 1-17-1974) 
Sec. 8-81. - Permit forms. 
    Permit forms shall be obtained from the city clerk upon payment of a fee of $5.00. The permit forms, before being used, must be signed by the city engineer before the city streets may be used for the purpose of moving any house or large structure. 
(Ord. No. 74-19, § 2, 1-17-1974) 
Sec. 8-82. - Designation of route and time. 
    The city engineer shall designate the route and time for moving the house or structure so as not to hinder, delay or inconvenience the traveling public more than reasonably necessary. The owner of the vehicle moving or hauling the house or structure shall be liable to the city for all damage which occur to the streets, bridges, or approaches to bridges, and shall bear all expense of moving wires, lines, trees, or other items in the road right-of-way. No permit shall be issued to any person who violates any provision of this article or who fails to pay within ten days after demand is made any claim of the city for damage to streets, bridges, or approaches to bridges caused by moving houses or other structures under a previous permit. 
(Ord. No. 74-19, § 3, 1-17-1974) 
Sec. 8-83. - Guarantee in event of damage. 
    The mover shall file with the city a surety bond, cashier's check, or a certified check of not less than $10,000.00 upon a solvent bank as a condition which will guarantee that all damage to any public property is repaired at the mover's expense, and further that all the work required to be done to complete the relocation and reconstruction of the building, pursuant to the conditions of the building permit granted by the city, is satisfactorily completed within the time specified by the city engineer and the building official. 
(Ord. No. 74-19, § 4, 1-17-1974) 
Sec. 8-84. - Regulations. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Leave unattended at any time any vehicle blocking any street or bridge while same is being used to move houses or other large structures. 
(2)  Move any house or other large structure onto a street which cannot be traveled with the load without interruption. 
(3)  Stop with the load so as to block normal passage of traffic longer than reasonably necessary. 
(4)  Fail to provide such labor and equipment as necessary to safely make the move without unreasonable interruption. 
(5)  Fail to provide such labor and equipment as necessary to raise or move any utility wires and promptly replace same if broken or damaged. 
(6)  Violate any direction or instruction of the city engineer designating the route and time for moving the house or other large structure. 
(Ord. No. 74-19, § 5, 1-17-1974) 
Secs. 8-85-8-111. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SEWER PIPE INSTALLATION AND INSPECTION 

Sec. 8-112. - Installation. 
    All sanitary sewer pipes from the sewer mains to the premises served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, the owner of the property to be served or the applicant of service. 
(Ord. No. 80-64, § 1, 5-6-1980) 
Sec. 8-113. - Inspection. 
    The city building inspector shall have the responsibility for the inspection of the sewer service line from the connection at the sewer main to the clean-out at the building/residence. This inspection shall be accomplished by the building inspector and approved in writing prior to covering and backfilling the sewer line. 
(Ord. No. 80-64, § 2, 5-6-1980) 
Sec. 8-114. - Sewer pipe requirement. 
(a)  The requirements for materials and installation of sanitary sewage service line shall meet or exceed the latest edition of the adopted International Plumbing Code and International Building Code. 
(b)  All joints shall be watertight. Cement mortar joints will not be acceptable. Watertight transition fittings and/or molded rubber reducers shall be used for connection to a different type or size of pipe. 
(Ord. No. 80-64, § 3, 5-6-1980) 
Sec. 8-115. - Excavations. 
    All excavations for installing sewer pipes or repairing the same will be made in compliance with the following procedure: 
(1)  When the sewer service line has been completed and tied to the sewer main, it shall be backfilled up to approximately one-half the diameter of the pipe and compacted in order to prevent movement and disjoining of the pipe during final backfill operations. Joints and connections shall not be backfilled prior to inspection. The pipe shall be laid in such a manner that any indentifying numbers will remain on top of the jointed pipe and be clearly visible after backfill to the spring line. When the sanitary sewer service line is completely installed, the city shall be contacted and the building inspector shall be requested to perform his inspection. Any request for inspection shall be made at least one day in advance to ensure the availability of the building inspector. 
(2)  Upon approval of the inspection, the contractor shall be given one copy of the inspection approval and the building inspector shall retain one copy for the city. 
(Ord. No. 80-64, § 4, 5-6-1980) 
Chapter 10 - BUSINESSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - State law regarding local privilege license tax, adopted by reference. 
    The Local Privilege Tax Law, MCA 1972, § 27-17-1 et seq. is hereby adopted, levied and imposed as the privilege tax code of the city. 
(Ord. No. 73-6, 4-3-1973) 
Secs. 10-2-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND DEALERS 

Sec. 10-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Secondhand dealer means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind which to any degree buys and sells secondhand articles. The term "secondhand dealer" shall not apply to a private citizen who has a garage and yard sale, a nonprofit organization, or any antique dealer. 
(Ord. No. 91-05-17, § 1, 5-16-1991) 
Sec. 10-22. - Requirements. 
    Every junk dealer, pawn broker and secondhand dealer in the city of horn lake is hereby required to make a written report to the chief of police upon forms furnished and paid for by the city. Said reports shall be made available within 48 hours of receiving a sold or pawned article, shall show the name, description, address, date of birth and identification number of each person selling or pawning any article, and shall give a complete description, serial number and identifying marks of the sold or pawned article. 
(Ord. No. 91-05-17, § 2, 5-16-1991) 
Sec. 10-23. - Penalty. 
    Every person, firm, or corporation, their agents or employees, who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, shall upon conviction thereof, be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and may be fined a sum of not more than $1,000.00 for each offense, and at the discretion of the court, may be imprisoned for a period of time not to exceed 90 days. Upon any such conviction, the license of said brokers may be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 91-05-17, § 3, 5-16-1991) 
Secs. 10-24-10-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTRACTOR LICENSING 

Sec. 10-50. - License required. 
(a)  No permits shall be issued nor shall any work be performed which is regulated by the plumbing code, electrical code, mechanical code and the administrative ordinances adopted by the city until the person desiring to perform such work obtains a master license from the city to perform such work. This master license shall be obtained in accordance with the subsequent sections of this article. The work items listed below shall be exempt from the above stated license requirements: 
(1)  Repairs or replacements of existing plumbing fixtures, washing machines, dishwashers and disposals; 
(2)  Servicing and repair of mechanical systems; 
(3)  Replacements of internal components of mechanical systems; 
(4)  Electrical repairs-replacements of ballast in light fixtures, change out fixture in the same location as removed from, and any electrical repair where no additional wiring and moving of conduit or wiring are involved. 
(b)  Not to be confused with the exemptions in subsection (a) of this section are replacements of any electrical wiring, panel boxes, residential or commercial sewers, hot water heaters, condensing units, furnaces, and refrigerated cases and freezers for display and sale of merchandise. 
(c)  Regardless of whether a license and permit is required, nothing in this section shall preclude the necessity of all work, replacements, servicing and repairs being performed in accordance with the codes adopted by the city, nor shall it preclude the necessity of obtaining a city privilege license or any other license required by any other law. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-51. - Qualifications. 
    Before any master license shall be issued, the applicant shall prove to the license commission that he has at least four years of experience acquired by active and continuing work in the trade for which he is applying for a license. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-52. - Examinations. 
    In order to receive a master license, a person must submit an application with the information requested on the form. The master application fees shall be established by the governing authority by resolution. The applicant shall be given a written examination administered and authorized by the state board of contractors. The master license examination shall be sufficient to test the ability of the applicant to determine the proper quantity, size and type of piping, wiring, equipment and other apparatus, and to properly install the same. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-53. - Homeowner exemption. 
(a)  Any person who wishes to perform plumbing, electrical or mechanical work in a house or an addition to a house which he is constructing for himself and which he owns and will live in or in a residential accessory building to be constructed on his own residential lot is hereby exempt from the regulations contained in this article unless otherwise specifically stated. Such homeowner shall sign a statement certifying he will be performing the work and will not hire anyone to perform the work. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall preclude the necessity of the homeowner obtaining the required permits, performing the work in accordance with the construction codes and obtaining the necessary inspections. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-54. - Supervision of work by license holder. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the master who has received the permit for the job to at least supervise the job if he does not actually perform the work. The master shall be responsible for the work being performed in accordance with the applicable codes. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-55. - Bonds. 
(a)  Before any permit is issued to a master license holder, the applicant shall provide a bond in the amount of $5,000.00 issued to the city. This bond shall be written to expire December 31 of each year. A $5,000.00 bond shall also be required for builders, sign, fence and pool contractors. 
(b)  The homeowner exemption regarding licenses shall also apply to bonds when the homeowner is performing his own building work. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-56. - Renewal of license. 
    All licenses shall expire on the last working day of each calendar year and may be renewed by submitting a renewal fee, as determined by the mayor and board of aldermen. The master license holders shall also submit a new bond drawn up to expire the last working day of each calendar year. Bonds for new master license holders drawn up during the year will expire the last working day of that calendar year. Renewal fees and bonds received after the last working day of each calendar year may render the license null and void and the applicable examination may have to be retaken for the reinstatement of the license-this shall be at the discretion of the city based on the particular circumstance of the delay in delivering the renewal fees and bonds; however, any credential allowed to lapse for one year or more, without application for renewal, shall be required to retake the applicable examination for the reinstatement of the license. Appeals to any decision shall be brought before a body to be appointed by the mayor and board for such reviews, as required. If renewal is granted without reexamination, a penalty not to exceed double the original renewal fee shall be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-57. - Identification on vehicles. 
    The vehicles used by plumbers, electricians and mechanical contractors in the conduct of their business within the city shall have affixed or printed on both sides of the vehicle, a sign giving the name of the company and the license number of the license holder, in letters and numbers no less than two inches high on the top line and no less than 11/2 inches on the second line. Such letters and numbers shall be of contrasting colors so as to be visible on the vehicle. After notification, the license holder shall have 14 working days in which to comply with this section. Failure to comply with this section shall result in the withholding of permits until such time as the license holder meets the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 10-58. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person licensed with the city to perform work as regulated by this article who violates any provision of this article shall be penalized as follows: 
(1)  First offense: Penalty in the amount of the permit fee or $50.00, whichever is greater. 
(2)  Second offense within one year: Penalty in the amount of the permit fee or $250.00, whichever is greater. 
(3)  Third offense within one year: Penalty in the amount of the permit fee or $500.00, whichever is greater. 
(4)  Fourth offense within one year: The person's license shall be suspended for a period of six months, and there shall be imposed a $100.00 license reinstatement fee. 
(b)  In addition to the prescribed penalties in subsection (a) of this section, any person licensed within the city to perform work as regulated by this article who violates any provision of this article may be issued a citation to appear before the municipal court and upon conviction of the misdemeanor offense shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed the sum of $1,000.00 and/or to serve six months in jail. 
(c)  Continuing violations without reasonable effort on the part of the person to correct the same shall constitute a separate offense each day the violation continues. 
(d)  A penalty in the amount of $50.00 for the first offense will be imposed on any contractor who does not call for routine inspections during the construction period. After 30 days from the completion of the job, if a final inspection has not been called, the penalty will be imposed. 
(e)  Any person who is not licensed in the city, other than a homeowner performing work under the homeowner exemption clause contained in this article, who violates any provision of this article, including the requirements for license holders and contractors, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed $1,000.00. 
(f)  The penalties for violation of the provisions of this article committed by homeowners performing work under the homeowner exemption clause contained in this article shall be in the amount of the permit fee. 
(g)  If a person's master license is suspended, he shall be allowed to complete the jobs for which he already holds a permit; however, he shall not be issued any additional permits during the period of suspension. Any suspension may be appealed to the license commission. The action of the license commission may be appealed to the mayor and board of aldermen. The suspension period shall not commence until the final decision is rendered. 
(h)  If a violation of the city's construction codes is not corrected within ten calendar days of the date the permit holder was notified of the violation, no further permits shall be issued to the offender until the violation are corrected. The building official may grant an extension in time to correct the violation if he deems it appropriate for the amount of time necessary to physically correct the violation. 
(i)  The building official, in his discretion, may call, collect or otherwise demand the proceeds of the license bond from the bonding company of any license holder who refuses or otherwise does not correct any violation of this article or the city's construction codes after having been given adequate time to correct the violation. The license shall automatically be revoked upon the calling of the bond. The person shall not be granted another license in the city until after one year from the date of revocation of his former license, and, furthermore, the license shall not be granted until the person satisfies the examination exemption clause of MCA 1972, § 27-17-457, as amended. 
(j)  The government authority shall also have the authority to suspend or revoke licenses upon repeated violations committed over a period in excess of one year as contained in subsection (a) of this section. The license shall not be revoked until after the alleged offender has been given the opportunity to defend his actions. The city may also take any other legal action prescribed by law to uphold the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-169, 11-21-2006) 
Secs. 10-59-10-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRANSIENT VENDORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of transient vendors, MCA 1972, § 21-19-35; transient vendors, MCA 1972, §§ 75-85-1-75-85-19. 

Sec. 10-90. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Transient vendor, transient business, and person shall have the same definition and meaning as set forth in MCA 1972, § 75-85-1, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-184, § I, 2-5-2008) 
Sec. 10-91. - Compliance with statutes. 
    A transient vendor may not transact business in the city unless there has been full compliance with all applicable provisions of MCA 1972, §§ 75-85-1 through 75-85-19. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-184, § II, 2-5-2008) 
Sec. 10-92. - Penal bond requirement. 
    A transient vendor shall, prior to any solicitations or conducting any business, furnish to the city a good and sufficient penal bond in the amount of $2,000.00 conditioned that if such transient vendor shall comply with all provisions of this article such obligation shall be void, otherwise to remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-184, § III, 2-5-2008) 
Sec. 10-93. - Litter containers; operation from conveyance; hours. 
(a)  Each transient vendor shall furnish upon the premises used for the business no less than one 30-gallon waste litter container. 
(b)  A transient vendor transacting business from an automobile, truck, or any other type of conveyance must also meet the following conditions: 
(1)  Only allowed to operate in an area zoned commercial or office; 
(2)  Must be at least 50 feet back from the curb or right-of-way; 
(3)  A minimum of eight off-street parking spaces must be available in addition to the spaces required for any other businesses on the property; 
(4)  Sanitary toilet facilities must be available, usable and within 150 feet of the temporary business; 
(5)  If any food or foodstuffs is sold or dispensed to the public, the necessary sanitary facilities shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of the county health department. Official documentation shall be provided to the municipal tax collector or his designee along with the application. 
(c)  Permissible hours of operation for a transient vendor shall be between the times of 30 minutes after official sunrise and 30 minutes before official sunset. These times are as published by the United State Naval Observatory. An applicant may apply to the mayor and board of aldermen for a waiver of the stated hours of operation imposed by this subsection. Upon good cause shown, such waiver may be granted with other time limitations imposed if the applicant can show that this exception will cause no harm to the peace and welfare of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-184, § IV, 2-5-2008) 
Sec. 10-94. - Penalty. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of MCA 1972, §§ 75-85-1 through 75-85-17 shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined and/or be imprisoned in the county jail in accordance with MCA 1972, § 75-85-19, as amended. Any person convicted of a violation of any other provision of this article shall be fined in an amount not exceeding $1,000.00 or be imprisoned not more than 90 days, or be both fined and imprisoned. Any person found guilty of a second or subsequent violation of MCA 1972, §§ 75-85-1 through 75-85-17 and/or this article shall be fined a minimum of $250.00 for each such violation and/or be imprisoned as set forth herein. In case of continuing violations without reasonable effort on the part of the person to correct the same shall constitute a separate offense each day the violation continues. 
(Ord. No. 08-02-184, § V, 2-5-2008) 
Secs. 10-95-10-116. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ICE CREAM TRUCKS 

Sec. 10-117. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ice cream truck means a motor vehicle utilized as the point of retail sales of prewrapped or prepackaged ice cream, frozen yogurt, frozen custard, flavored frozen water or similar frozen dessert products. 
(Ord. No. 13-08-208, § 1, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 10-118. - Licensing procedures. 
(a)  In addition to obtaining a city privilege license, ice cream truck vendors must apply for and obtain a license under this article and abide by the regulations provided herein. 
(b)  Applications for licenses under this article shall be submitted to the planning department on forms provided by the city schedule of license, permit and application fees established by order of the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Licenses issued under this article shall be valid for no more than one year and shall expire on September 30 of each calendar year. 
(d)  Licenses issued under this article may be suspended or revoked by the board of aldermen after notice and hearing for a violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 13-08-208, § 2, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 10-119. - Regulations applicable to article. 
(a)  Permitted sales location. Sales from ice cream trucks shall occur only on public ways with a speed limit of 30 miles per hour or less located within residential districts under the city zoning ordinance or on private ways with the consent of the owner or owners of the private way. 
(b)  Prohibited location. No ice cream truck shall make any sales within 1,000 feet (measured from the property line) of a restaurant, retail store selling prepackaged food items or a fixed place of business having a business license (excluding home occupations) issued by the city. No ice cream truck shall make any sales within 1,000 feet (measured from the property line) of any public school or any city park. No ice cream truck shall stop at any time for the purpose of making sales in any area where parking is prohibited or in any area posted as a no parking zone by the city. 
(c)  Length of stop. No ice cream truck shall stop for the purpose of making sales for more than 15 minutes in a single location. 
(d)  Manner of stops. Ice cream trucks shall pull as far as practicable to the side of the right-of-way when stopping for the purpose of making sales and shall operate four-way flashers when so stopped. In no event shall an ice cream truck, stopped for the purpose of making sales, prevent the passage of other motor vehicles on the right-of-way. 
(e)  Rubbish receptacle required. Each ice cream truck shall provide a rubbish receptacle for use of its customers. Prior to leaving each stop, the operator of the ice cream truck shall remove any litter left at the stop by customers. 
(f)  Hours of operation. Ice cream trucks may stop for the purpose of making sales only between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m., central time. 
(g)  Insurance required. Each ice cream truck shall be insured under a policy of public liability insurance in an amount of not less than $500,000.00 with the city named as an additional insured on the policy. A certificate of coverage shall be provided to the city. 
(h)  Limits on products sold. Only prewrapped or prepackaged food items may be sold from an ice cream truck. Non-frozen items such as prepackaged soft drinks, candy, chewing gum and snack food may be sold from an ice cream truck provided the principal product sold is ice cream and/or similar frozen dessert products. 
(i)  Noise. Any noise produced by ice cream trucks must be at a level that is in accordance with the noise ordinance of the city. 
(j)  Health department licensure. The applicant must provide the proper documentation provided by the county health department prior to any sales and must maintain compliance with any such permit required and issued by the department. 
(Ord. No. 13-08-208, § 3, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 10-120. - Exemption from zoning. 
    An ice cream truck licensed under this article and operated in compliance with this article shall not be considered a land use subject to regulation under the city zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 13-08-208, § 4, 8-6-2013) 
Sec. 10-121. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates any provision of this article commits a civil violation punishable by a civil penalty of up to $1,000.00 or by imprisonment not to exceed 90 days, or both, per violation. Each violation of any provision of this article committed by the same person during the same day shall constitute a separate violation. Additionally, each day a violation occurs or exists constitutes a separate violation. Further, the license may be suspended or revoked as provided for in section 10-118. 
(b)  The penalties provided for in this section shall be in addition to any other remedies available to the board of aldermen through the institution of an action or proceeding in any court, including, but not limited to, an action or proceeding to enjoin any violation of an ordinance or adopted code. 
(c)  This article shall be enforced by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 13-08-208, § 5, 8-6-2013) 
Chapter 12 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Mississippi Emergency Management Law, MCA 1972, § 33-15-1 et seq.; local organization of emergency management, MCA 1972, § 33-15-17; emergency use of personnel authorized, MCA 1972, § 33-15-49. 

Sec. 12-1. - Title. 
    This chapter may be referred to or cited as the "emergency preparedness or civil defense ordinance of the city". 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 1, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-2. - Intent and purpose. 
(a)  Due to the existing and ever present possibility of occurrence of calamities or emergencies resulting from enemy action, natural and manmade disasters and in order that adequate preparations to deal with such disasters, intent of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Create a city emergency preparedness council that will ensure the effective and efficient utilization of all of the city's resources to prepare for and combat emergencies arising from the forenamed disasters. 
(2)  Invest the emergency preparedness council with the responsibility of coordinating all disaster planning and operations by joint efforts with each department having an emergency role or responsibility the disaster plan or basic plan will be the instrument through which the mayor and aldermen may exercise the authority and discharge the responsibilities vested in them by the Mississippi Civil Defense Act of 1952, as amended, and this chapter when approved by the governing body. 
(3)  Confer upon the executive heads or governing bodies of the municipality the emergency powers provided herein. 
(4)  Provide for rendering of mutual aid between the municipalities and countries of the state, the state, and with the federal government with respect to the carrying out of emergency preparedness functions. 
(5)  Authorize the establishment of an emergency preparedness council and the taking of such steps as are necessary and appropriate to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  It is further declared to be the purpose of this chapter and the policy of the city that all emergency preparedness functions of the federal and state governments, including their various departments and agencies and of private agencies of every type, are employed to the end that the most effective preparation and use may be made of the city's manpower, resources, and facilities for dealing with any disaster. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 3, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-3. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief administrative officer means the mayor of any municipality. 
    Coordinator or director means the executive head of the emergency preparedness council under the direction and control of the chief administrative officer. 
    County means the unincorporated area that lies outside the city or town limits of municipalities geographically located within said county. 
    Curfew means a prohibition against any person or persons walking, running, loitering, standing, sitting, lying or motoring upon any ally, street, public property or vacant premises except by persons officially designated to duty with reference to said emergency or those lawfully on the streets as defined hereinafter. 
    Disaster means occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, earthquake, windstorm, wave action, chemical spill, or other water contamination requiring emergency action to avert danger or damage, volcanic activity, epidemics, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, civil disturbance or hostile military or paramilitary action. 
    Emergency forces means the employees, equipment and facilities of all city departments, agencies, boards, institutions and commissions; and in addition, the term "emergency forces" includes all volunteer personnel, equipment and facilities contributed by, or obtained from volunteer persons or agencies. 
    Emergency preparedness means the preparation to carry out the basic governmental functions of maintaining the public peace, health and safety during emergencies and to prevent, minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters as defined in this section. These functions include written plans and without limitations, firefighting, law enforcement, emergency medical and health services, rescue, warning, communications, radiological, chemical services and other special weapons defense, evacuation of persons from stricken areas, emergency welfare and transportation services, plant protection, temporary restoration of public utility services and other functions related to civil defense, together with all other activities necessary or incidental to the preparation for and carrying out of the foregoing functions. The term "emergency preparedness" does not, however, include any activities that are the primary responsibility of the military forces of the United States. 
    Emergency preparedness or civil defense council shall be used interchangeably and shall mean the organization authorized to coordinate emergency functions. 
    Enemy attack or action means a direct or indirect assault against any city, county, state of this country or the nation itself by the forces of a hostile nation or the agents thereof, chemical or biological warfare, or sabotage. 
    Regulations includes plans, programs and other emergency procedures deemed essential to disaster preparedness and operations. 
    Riot or unlawful assembly means any use of force or violence disturbing the public peace, or any threat to use such force and violence, if accompanied by immediate power of execution, by two or more persons acting together and without authority of law. 
    Volunteer means contributing a service, equipment, or facilities to the disaster preparedness organization without remuneration. The term "volunteer" also means any person duly registered, identified and appointed by the coordinator of the emergency preparedness council and assigned to participate in the disaster preparedness activities. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 5, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-4. - Organization. 
(a)  The mayor is hereby authorized to create an organization for disaster preparedness and operations utilizing to the fullest extent the existing agencies within the city. The mayor, as chief administrative officer shall be responsible for the organization, administration and operation of the disaster preparedness emergency forces of the city. The mayor and aldermen will designate a line of succession for that body to ensure that the necessary responsibility for direction and control can be exercised in event of absence or inability of the chief administrative officer to act. 
(b)  The council shall consist of the following: 
(1)  An office of disaster preparedness under the direction and control of the chief administrative officer. This shall be the primary control center to serve as a command post or emergency operations center during disasters. 
(2)  There shall be an executive head of the office of disaster preparedness who shall be known as the coordinator, and such assistants and other employees as are deemed necessary for the proper functioning of the council. 
(3)  All employees, equipment and facilities of the city departments, agencies, boards and commissions, will participate in disaster preparedness activities. Duties assigned to an element shall be the same or similar to the normal duties of that element. 
(4)  Volunteer persons and agencies offering manpower, services or equipment or supplies and which are accepted by the council. 
(c)  A coordinator will be appointed by the chief administrative officer with the advice and approval of the mayor and board of aldermen. The coordinator shall be well versed and trained in planning and operations before or immediately following appointment so that the most effective program to protect the public health, safety, and welfare may be established without delay. The coordinator will act as an advisor to the chief administrative officer during emergencies. 
(d)  The sheriff and/or chief of police who is the chief law enforcement officer of the county and/ or city will serve as principal advisor to the chief administrative officer on the implementation of the provisions of emergency powers under this chapter during non-wartime emergencies or disasters. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 7, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-5. - Emergency powers. 
(a)  The chief administrative officer may exercise the emergency power and authority necessary to fulfill his general powers and duties under this chapter and his judgment shall be the sole criteria necessary to invoke emergency powers provided in this chapter and those invested by state statutes listed in MCA 1972, § 33-15-17. The board of supervisors and/or aldermen may convene to perform its powers as the situation demands, and receive reports relative to disaster preparedness activities.) 
(b)  The chief administrative officer may promulgate such regulations, during any period when disaster threatens or when a disaster has struck, as he deems necessary to protect life and property and preserve critical resources. Examples of those regulations, but they need not be limited to those that follow, are: 
(1)  Regulations to prohibit or restrict the movement of vehicles in order to facilitate the work of disaster forces or to facilitate the mass movement of persons from areas that are hazardous or vulnerable to disasters or critical areas within the council's jurisdiction. 
(2)  Enter into contracts, incur obligations, employ temporary workers, rent equipment, purchase supplies, levy taxes, appropriate and expend public funds without regard to time-consuming procedures and formalities normally prescribed by law. 
(3)  After determining that a civil emergency (disaster) exists and has been declared in writing and a copy filed with the chancery clerk and/or city clerk a curfew may be declared as authorized in MCA 1972, § 45-17-7. (Closing retail liquor stores, discontinuance of sale of intoxicating liquor and/or beer, discontinuance of manufacture of, transfer, use, possession of Molotov cocktail or explosives, discontinuance of sale of firearms.) 
(4)  The mayor and board of aldermen, by ordinance, may provide that any person violating the provisions of this chapter or the orders issued by the chief administrative officer pursuant to this authorization during a proclaimed civil emergency (disaster) be guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished by fine not to exceed $300.00 or six months imprisonment, or both. 
(5)  Issue other such orders as are necessary for the protection of life and property. 
(c)  Under the supervision of the board of supervisors and/or aldermen through the chief administrative officer, the coordinator shall be responsible for, but not necessarily limited to the following duties: 
(1)  The coordinator shall be responsible for all phases of disaster preparedness and operations activities, which shall be in the written form of a basic plan, with warning, alerting, and lines of succession for each department having an emergency responsibility. This plan will be a joint effort of the coordinator and the head of each department. The coordinator shall maintain liaison with the state and federal authorities to ensure the compatibility of the planning and programs in emergency preparedness. The coordinator shall act as an advisor to the governing body and the chief administrative officer in matters concerning emergency preparedness and operations. 
(2)  The recruitment of volunteer personnel and agencies to augment those of the political subdivision and areas not assigned to personnel and agencies of the political subdivision. 
(3)  Negotiating and concluding with the owners or persons in control of real estate or other property for use of such for sheltering the public during emergencies and/or disasters and to designate such as public shelters. 
(4)  Establish a public information program which will inform the people of the actions required for the protection of their persons and property in case of disaster. 
(5)  The coordinator will be responsible for practice alerts, tests and exercised to ensure the efficient operation of the council's disaster forces and the coordinating of all other public and private agencies activities engaged in any disaster preparedness activity. 
(6)  To assume any other such authority and conduct any such other activity as the governing body and/or the chief administrative officer may direct to promote and execute the disaster preparedness program. 
(7)  To be prepared to give the governing body a status report of the degree of readiness of the council no less than annually or as directed by said body. 
(8)  Some of the duties ascribed to the chief administrative officer may at his discretion be handled by the coordinator, but the responsibility and authority stems from and remains with the chief administrative that portion of the basic plan pertaining to his emergency assignment so that the most efficient and effective use may be made of the council's resources. Line of succession of three persons will be established and maintained. This line of succession will be in order with the best capable of carrying out all assigned duties and functions. Each head shall be responsible for maintaining their portion of the basic plan and the line of succession in a current state. Each department will prepare, and keep current a list of resources, and keep said list on file in the emergency preparedness office. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 9, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-6. - Peace officers. 
(a)  With the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen and the chief of police of the municipality, the municipality may confer upon members of their civil defense auxiliary police units, the powers of peace officer, subject to such restrictions as shall be imposed. 
(b)  Any civil defense auxiliary police officer having these powers conferred upon him may arrest without a warrant any person violating or attempting to violate in the officers presence any order, rule or regulation made pursuant to this chapter. This authority shall be limited to those rules and regulations which affect the public generally. 
(c)  Any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter or any rule, order or regulation made pursuant to this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed $500.00 or imprisonment for not exceeding six months or both. 
(d)  Neither any agencies of this council, its employees, nor representatives engaged in any emergency preparedness activities, while complying with or attempting to comply with this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, shall be liable for the death of or any injury to persons, or damage to property, as a result of such activity, except in cases of willful misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 11, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-7. - Council and private liability. 
(a)  Neither the city nor agents and representatives of said county and/or city while acting in good faith without willful misconduct, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provision of this chapter, shall be liable for any damage sustained to persons or property as the result of said activity. 
(b)  Neither any person owning or controlling real estate or other premises who voluntarily, and without compensation, grants the county and/or city the right to license, inspect, designate or use of the whole or any part or parts of such real estate or premises for the purpose of sheltering persons during an actual, impending or practice enemy attack or during the occurrence of natural or manmade disasters, shall be civilly liable for the death, injury to, any person on or about such real estate or premises by virtue of its use for civil defense purposes, or loss of or damage to, the property of such person, except in case of willful misconduct. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 13, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-8. - Funds, matching funds, gifts, grants, donations, loans, services. 
(a)  For the purpose of paying any expenses of its local emergency preparedness organization, the governing body of the city authorizes the expenditure of any available funds from the general funds of said jurisdiction. 
(b)  Any governing body of the emergency preparedness organization may enter into agreement with the federal government with the approval of the state director of civil defense for matching funds which may be made available from the general funds or such other funds as may be available to the governing body, for the purchase of equipment by such county and/or city in conjunction with any federal matching program and funds for civil defense purposes. 
(c)  Whenever the federal government or any agency or officer thereof shall offer to this political subdivision services, equipment, supplies, material or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of emergency preparedness, the political subdivision, acting with the consent of the governor and through its governing body of such political subdivision, may authorize any officer of the political subdivision to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds on behalf of the political subdivision, and subject to the terms of the offer and the rules and regulations, if any, of the agency making the offer. 
(d)  Whenever any person, firm or corporation shall offer to the political subdivision services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of emergency preparedness the political subdivision, acting through its governing body of the political subdivision, may authorize any officer of the political subdivision to receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials, or funds on behalf of the political subdivision and subject to the terms of the offer, if any. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 15, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-9. - Violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter or of the regulations or plans issued pursuant to the authority contained herein, or to willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member or members of the disaster forces in the performance of their emergency assignments. 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 17, 5-7-1974) 
Sec. 12-10. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter, upon conviction, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and be punished by a fine or imprisonment or both as provided by in section 12-5(b)(4). 
(Ord. No. 74-24, § 19, 5-7-1974) 
Chapter 14 - ENVIRONMENT 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOISE 

Sec. 14-19. - General provisions. 
(a)  Declaration of policy. It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of this article to assess complaints of noises alleged to exceed the ambient noise levels. Further, it is declared to be the policy to contain sound levels in the city at the present levels with the ultimate goal of reducing such levels. 
(b)  Liberal construction. This article shall be liberally construed so as to effectuate its purposes. 
(c)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Plainly audible means any sound that can be detected by a person using his unaided hearing faculties; however, words or phrases need not be discernible and said sound shall include bass reverberation. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § I, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-20. - General noise regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make or continue to cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise which disturbs the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or which causes discomfort or annoyance to any reasonable person of normal sensitiveness present in the area. 
(b)  The standards which may be considered in determining whether a violation of the provisions of this section exists shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  The sound level of the objectionable noise. 
(2)  The sound level of the ambient noise. 
(3)  The proximity of the noise to residential sleeping facilities. 
(4)  The nature and zoning of the area within which the noise emanates. 
(5)  The density of the inhabitation of the area within which the noise emanates. 
(6)  The time of day or night the noise occurs. 
(7)  The duration of the noise and its tonal informational musical content. 
(8)  Whether the noise is continuous, recurrent, or intermittent. 
(9)  Whether the noise is produced by a commercial or non-commercial activity. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § II, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-21. - Specific unlawful noises. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of the article to the contrary, the following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing noises in violation of this article, but such enumeration shall not be deemed too be exclusive, namely: 
(1)  Engine noises. Any noise made by the engine of any automobile, truck, tractor or motorcycle, not reasonably required in the operation thereof under the circumstances which shall include, but not be limited to, backfiring and racing the engine. 
(2)  Horns and signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any automobile, truck, motorcycle or other vehicle on any street or public place of the city, except as a danger warning; the creation by means of any such signaling device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; and the sounding of any such device for an unnecessary or unreasonable period of time. The use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the use of any horn, whistle or any other device operated by engine exhaust; and the use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up. 
(3)  Yelling and shouting. Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling, singing or blowing of horns on the public streets, particularly between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. or at any time or place so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any office or in any dwelling, hotel, motel, apartment or of any persons in the vicinity. 
(4)  Tools. The use of or operation between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of any power saw, planer, or other powered tool or appliance or saw or hammer, or other tool, so as to disturb quiet, comfort, or repose of persons in any dwelling, hotel, motel, apartment, or other type of residence, or of any person in the vicinity. 
(5)  Blowers. The operating of any noise creating blower or power fan or any internal combustion engine, the operation of which causes noise due to the explosion of operating gases or fluids, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled and such engine is equipped with a muffler device sufficient to deaden such noise. 
(6)  Radios, tape players, etc. Any noise emitted from a radio, tape player, tape recorder, record player, or television outdoors or in any public place, including, but not limited to, public parks, when such noise is plainly audible 30 feet or more from said device. The operation of a sound amplification system including, but not limited to, a radio, stereo or other like equipment in a motor vehicle in such a manner that the noise is plainly audible 30 feet or more from the vehicle or, in the case of a motor vehicle on private property, beyond the property line. 
(7)  Music. The playing of music by a live band or other instruments or devices utilizing sound amplification equipment in any manner so as to disturb the peace and quiet of any person in the vicinity thereof. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § III, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-22. - Exemptions. 
    The following activities shall be exempted from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  School bands, school athletic and school entertainment events that are conducted from 7:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight, Monday through Saturday and 12:00 noon to 8:00 p.m. on Sunday. School entertainment events shall not include events sponsored by student organizations. 
(2)  Outdoor gatherings, public dances, shows and sporting and entertainment events provided said events are conducted pursuant to a discretionary license or permit by the city. 
(3)  Activities sponsored on park and public playgrounds, provided such parks and public playgrounds are owned and operated by the public entity and activities occur between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight. 
(4)  Any mechanical device, apparatus or equipment related to or connected with an emergency or emergency work. 
(5)  Noise sources due to the erection (including excavation), demolition, alteration or repair of any building structure between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday and 9:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. on Sunday; provided that the operation of an internal combustion engine shall not be exempt pursuant to this subsection (5) if such engine is not equipped with suitable exhaust and intake silencers which are in good working order. The director or planning may permit work to be done during hours not exempt by this subsection (5) in the case of urgent necessity and in the interest of public health and welfare for a period not to exceed three days. Application for this exemption may be made in conjunction with the application for the work permit or during the project period. 
(6)  Noise sources associated with agricultural operations provided such operations take place between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m.; provided that the operation of an internal combustion engine shall not be exempt pursuant to this subsection (6) if such engine is not equipped with suitable exhaust and intake silencers which are in good working order. 
(7)  Any mechanical device, apparatus or equipment which is utilized for the protection or salvage of agricultural crops during a period of adverse weather conditions or when the use of mobile noise sources is necessary for pest control; provided that the operation of an internal combustion engine shall not be exempt pursuant to this subsection (7) if such engine is not equipped with suitable exhaust and intake silencers which are in good working order. 
(8)  Noise sources, which are associated with maintenance of streets, trees, and residential area property; provided said activities take place between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
(9)  Tree and park maintenance activities conducted by the city. 
(10)  Church bell and chimes between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. 
(11)  Any noise associated with public safety vehicles, equipment or operations. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § IV, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-23. - Enforcement. 
    The enforcement of this article shall be the responsibility of the chief of police or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § V, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-24. - Special condition permits. 
(a)  The chief of police may grant special condition permits for a period not exceeding three days when the general purpose and intent of this article can be carried out by the granting of the special condition permit. The special condition permits can be renewed for periods not exceeding three days at the discretion of the chief of police. 
(b)  Application for issuance of a permit. Any permit issued pursuant to this article should be issued only upon receipt of a written application, which shall provide the following: 
(1)  A description of the premises for which the permit is to be issued. 
(2)  The dates and times for which the permit is to be issued. 
(3)  The name, address and telephone number of the person applying for the permit. 
(4)  Any facts, which would show that the activity for which the permit is sought would not disturb the peace of any family or person within the area into which the noise would carry. 
(5)  The applications shall designate a responsible person to be present during the activity. The person designated shall be responsible for conducting the activity in compliance with the provisions of the permit and must be present at all times. 
(6)  Other such information as the chief of police shall deem necessary and proper. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § VI, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-25. - Issuance of permits. 
(a)  The chief of police shall issue a permit only upon a showing that the activity will not significantly disturb the peace of any family or person within the area in which the noise will carry. A permit shall be issued or denied within 15 days of receipt of a completed and signed application. The chief of police shall consider the following factors in considering whether to grant such a permit: 
(1)  The anticipated noise or disruption that will be caused by the activity. 
(2)  The time of day the activity is to take place. 
(3)  The proximity of the activity to residential areas, schools, churches, and other meeting places. 
(4)  Prior complaints from residents as a result of other similar activities. 
(b)  In the event the permit is denied, the applicant may appeal the decision to the mayor and board of aldermen. Appeals must be submitted to the city clerk within ten days of the denial of a permit by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § VII, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-26. - Revocation of permits. 
    The chief of police shall have the authority to revoke any permit issued on the finding of any of the following conditions: 
(1)  The activity is being conducted in a manner inconsistent with the permit, including the description of the activity as set out in the application. 
(2)  The activity is causing a disturbance of the peace of families or persons within the area into which the noise carries. 
(3)  Any misrepresentation of the activity on the application for the permit. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § VIII, 5-20-2008) 
Sec. 14-27. - Violations and penalties. 
    It shall be a misdemeanor to conduct, participate in, or permit any activity in violation of the provisions of this article or to conduct, participate in, or permit any activity that violates the conditions of a permit issued pursuant to this article. Any person convicted of violating the provisions of this article shall be punished by a fine of not more than $1,000.00 and/or 90 days in jail. A continuation of a violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 08-05-188, § IX, 5-20-2008) 
Secs. 14-28-14-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TREES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-56. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Tree Ordinance for the City of Horn Lake." 
(Ord. No. 06-11-168, § 1, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 14-57. - Statement of purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, and to enhance the economic, environmental, and aesthetic qualities of the urban surroundings by preventing the unwarranted clear cutting of urban forest for the purpose of expediting development. 
(b)  The goal of this article is to protect through preservation, to promote the establishment of, and to maintain a 40 percent urban tree canopy cover in the city. 
(Ord. No. 12-02-89, § 1, 12-7-1989; Ord. No. 06-11-168, § 2, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 14-58. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Caliper means the diameter of the plant stem six inches above the ground, for trees with a caliper of four inches or less. Trees possessing a caliper in excess of four inches are measured 54 inches above the ground. 
    Clear cut means cutting more than 60 percent of the tree canopy cover on any commercial, industrial or residential tract of land. 
    DBH (diameter at breast height) means the diameter of a tree trunk measured in inches at a height of 41/2 feet above the ground. If a tree splits into multiple trunks below feet 41/2 feet, then the trunk is measured at its most narrow point beneath the split. 
    Existing tree means all trees located within the boundaries of a parcel of property to which this ordinance applies, except the following: 
(1)  A tree demonstrated to be dead or dying; 
(2)  A tree that is diseased and likely to die; 
(3)  A tree that is damaged or injured to the extent that it is likely to die or become diseased; 
(4)  A tree that is an unsafe tree; or 
(5)  A tree that is listed on the "undesirable" list in the city's tree board manual. 
    In-lieu fund means a city fund established to provide that trees may be planted on a site such as a school, public park, public use land, or public right-of-way, where the owner/developer shall donate funds and the city shall plant the required trees when it is not feasible to plant the required trees within a site's project area. 
    Forested land means includes areas that are predominantly covered with trees and woody vegetation and may be open or closed-canopy, deciduous wooded areas or wooded areas dominated by pine and other coniferous tree species. 
    Forestry activities means any activity on merchantable forest land associated with the reforesting, growing, managing, protecting or harvesting of timber, wood, or forest products, including non-game species. 
    Merchantable forest land means any land in the city devoted to the growing of trees or the commercial production of timber, wood, or forest products where the land is classified by the county with a forestry designation or an agricultural crop designation and is being used as forest land in the performance of forestry activities. 
    Mitigation tree means a new tree planted to replace the loss of existing tree canopy cover pro-rated at 20 trees per acre of existing tree canopy cover per site. An acceptable mitigation tree shall be a minimum of two inches in caliper and have a minimum height of ten feet. Acceptable tree species can be obtained from the Trees for Mississippi Homes booklet located at the urban forester office for the city. 
    On-site mitigation means planting trees within the boundaries of the project applying for a tree removal permit to replace trees which are to be permitted for removal from the tree canopy cover, including any and all protected trees. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Property owner means the person owning such property according to the land records of the county. 
    Protected trees means any woody perennial plant with a single trunk that has reached a diameter of eight inches or 25 inches in circumference when measured 54 inches above the ground and multi-trunked trees that are five inches in diameter or 16 inches in circumference when measured 18 inches above the ground which is not an undesirable tree listed in the city's tree board manual. 
    Small trees means those with a mature height of up to 40 feet. 
    Tree canopy cover means the boundaries of the area or areas surrounding trees which must remain undisturbed to prevent damage and loss of trees which are to be retained on site during the development and building process. This area is to be measured at the drip line of a tree or group of trees. 
(Ord. No. 06-11-168, § 3, 11-21-2006) 
Sec. 14-59. - Applicability to zoning areas. 
    This article applies to the following zoning areas: 
(1)  Commercial: Applies to all commercial zoning classifications. 
(2)  Industrial: Applies to all industrial zoning classifications. 
(3)  Residential: Applies to all residential zoning classifications. 
(Ord. No. 12-02-89, § 2, 12-7-1989; Ord. No. 06-11-168, § 4, 11-21-2006)
