Total regular sanitation cost not to exceed $35.00 per container per single family residence for household garbage and recycling, if available. 
Multiple family residence Cost negotiable based on availability. Small business or institutions Cost negotiable based on availability Large business or institutions Cost negotiable based on availability Multiple family residence and mobile home parks per unit Cost negotiable based on availability  
The minimum collection cost for a small business shall be $30.00 per month per container for once a week pick up. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § III, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 17-08-248, 8-17-2017, eff. 10-1-2017) 
Sec. 30-4. - Containers provided by the city or the city's contractor. 
(a)  The city or its contractor will provide roll-type containers for the use by its citizens for the purpose of storing and transporting household garbage from the back yard of the homes to the curbside of the road. It is necessary that rules for the use of the containers be established in order to ensure the proper use, treatment, maintenance and security of the containers. Any person provided with a container shall be deemed to have entered into a contract for services with the city and agrees to the terms of the contract for services as set forth herein and/or on the set up form provided by the city. Containers for recyclables will be provided under the terms and conditions of a negotiated contract for recycling if and when available. 
(b)  A deposit of $55.00 for up to two sanitation containers will be charged to all customers who establish service after the passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. For accounts discontinued for failure to pay a past due bill a deposit of $55.00 plus the highest amount due will be required to re-establish service. This deposit will be in conjunction with any other deposits required (i.e., utility account deposits). 
(c)  From and after passage of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the deposit for sanitation containers will increase based on the cost of said containers. The deposit will be $5.00 over actual cost. 
(d)  Contract. This agreement is made and entered into by and between the city and the property owner and/or occupant of the address so stated on each contract. The property owner will be responsible for all containers so issued to any residence. The city or its contractor shall furnish a garbage roll-type container to each property owner subject to the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The city or its contractor shall be the sole owner of the containers. 
(2)  The property owner shall be responsible for the replacement cost of the container should the container be destroyed or stolen, due to neglect or abuse. If a container must be replaced more than one time per year, per property owner, a penalty shall be assessed in the amount of $55.00 in addition to the replacement cost. The city will hold the property owner responsible for making provisions for the replacement cost of containers prior to issuing a new container or resuming sanitation services. The minimum cost for a replacement container is $55.00 or the actual cost of a replacement, whichever is greater. 
(3)  On garbage pick up day, the container is to be placed within five feet of the curb and driveway. The sanitation collectors will not be allowed to proceed on residential property more than five feet from the curb for regular residential garbage pick up. Therefore, if the container is placed at a greater distance from the curb, garbage will not be picked up. 
(4)  Containers shall not remain on the curbside or in the front yard area over a 24-hour period surrounding pick up. This rule will be strictly enforced. Any violation shall be punishable as provided by this chapter. 
(5)  Containers shall be used for no other purpose than to contain garbage and household rubbish. Containers are not to be removed from the address stated on the contract for any reason. If the occupant moves to another address within the city, another container will be assigned. Containers are assigned by address, not occupant. If there is additional garbage, it must be placed in bags and placed on top or beside the city issued container. Collectors will not pick up unapproved cans. 
(6)  Citizens who are physically handicapped or disabled will receive back yard pick-up. Please contact city hall for further information. 
(7)  For accounts discontinued for failure to pay a past due bill a deposit of $55.00 plus the highest amount due will be required to re-establish service. This deposit will be in conjunction with any other deposits required: i.e., utility account deposits. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § IV, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 08-02-185, 2-5-2008; Ord. No. 13-10-210, §§ 2-4, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 30-5. - Special service pick up. 
(a)  All materials accumulated of a special nature shall be collected on a time and material basis as determined by the public works director or the city's contractor. Special service customers shall pay a fee which shall be the cost determined by the public works director or the city's contractor, unless such fee is otherwise specifically set forth herein. The customer shall be informed of such charges and the charges paid in advance of the provision of such service. Special service material shall include, but shall not be limited to, tree trimmings, limbs, grass trimmings, extra refuse containers and any material requiring utilization of personnel and equipment in addition to that used on regular route except as set forth elsewhere in this chapter. 
(b)  All special service collection will be on the first regular collection day following receipt of the special service collection fee or as soon thereafter as the sanitation crew can be reasonably scheduled unless the nature of the special service collection requires otherwise. 
Two cubic yards or less $  0.00 More than two, and up to 12 cubic yards (i.e., half-load)   75.00 More than 12, and up to 24 cubic yards (i.e., full-load)  150.00  
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § V, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 13-10-210, §§ 5, 6, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 30-6. - Special services; tire pick ups. 
(a)  As a service to the resident citizens, the city may pick up tires, at a charge of $3.00 per tire. 
(b)  Prior to the pick up of any tires, the resident must request such pick-up and pay the $3.00 fee per tire in advance. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to decline to pick up and/or remove more than five tires per household per month. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § VI, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 30-7. - Exemptions to special and/or regular garbage pick up. 
(a)  As a service to its individual resident citizens, the city or the city's contractor may pick up and remove from residential locations within the city certain used household appliances, including, but not limited to, washing machines, refrigerators, freezers, air conditioners, dishwashers, dryers, hot water heaters and stoves provided: 
(1)  All appliances containing chemicals, such as Freon, must be tagged by a certified technician that the contaminant (chemicals) have been removed according to EPA standards or such appliances will not be removed by the city or the city's contractor. (Expenses incurred for the removal of all such chemicals shall be the responsibility of the owner.) 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  All appliances must be in compliance with all city, state, and federal safety regulations prior to curbside placement on the customer's regularly scheduled sanitation pick-up day, to include, but not be limited to, removal of all doors. 
(4)  No appliance will be allowed to be placed on the curb prior to compliance with the above stipulations and shall not be allowed to be placed on the curb for over a 24-hour period. Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person or entity convicted for such violation shall be fined not less than $100.00 or more than $1,000.00 plus court costs or sentenced up to 90 days in jail or both. 
(5)  The city or the city's contractor reserves the right to decline to pick up and/or remove more than one appliance per household per month. 
(b)  The city or the city's contractor will not be responsible for picking up any building materials or renovation materials, to include, but not be limited to, old or used carpet, sheet rock materials, building materials, portable buildings, bricks, concrete or sand. The builder and owner, jointly, shall be responsible for removing all sand, dirt, concrete and/or building materials from the property, street, ditches, drains, and adjoining areas. 
(c)  Industrial wastes and noncombustible materials must be removed by the owner, operator or by the contractor performing the work which has caused such waste to accumulate with such removal to be in compliance with all local, state, and federal ordinances, rules, statutes and/or regulations. 
(d)  Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any person or entity convicted for such violation shall be fined not less than $100.00 or more than $1000.00 plus costs of court and cost of clean up or sentenced up to 90 days in jail or both. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § VII, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 13-10-210, § 7, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 30-8. - Miscellaneous rules and regulations. 
(a)  Containers are to be kept closed. Garbage and rubbish containers shall be kept covered at all times except when it is necessary to lift the cover to deposit or remove garbage or rubbish. It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit in any garbage or rubbish container any garbage, rubbish or other materials in such amounts that will not permit the lid of such garbage or rubbish container to fit tightly in place. 
(b)  No garbage, rubbish, trash or waste of any kind shall be buried within the city. 
(c)  No garbage, rubbish, trash or waste of any kind shall be burned on any premises within the city limits unless a written permit for such burning is first secured from the fire chief or his designated representative. 
(d)  No incinerators shall be installed or operated within the city limits. 
(e)  Disposing of any waste material by any manner shall meet or exceed all federal laws, state laws, city ordinances, and/or Environmental Protection Agency rules and regulations. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to deposit garbage, industrial waste, garden trash, tree trimmings, noncombustibles or rubbish upon the premises of another or upon any street, park or other public property, or in any canal, creek, water, waterway, rock pit, pool or lake within the city or in any garbage or rubbish container upon which any other person shall have paid collection fees as provided by the terms of this chapter, except that tenants of multiple family dwellings or commercial businesses or institutional establishments may deposit garbage or rubbish in container upon which the owner or manager of such dwellings or commercial businesses or institutional establishments shall have paid the collection provided herein and authorized the tenants to use such garbage or rubbish containers. 
(g)  Garden trash and/or tree trimmings may be placed on the curbside at any time, so long as the sidewalk and public way are not blocked. However, no garbage, rubbish, solid waste, or bulk waste shall be placed on the curbside, prior to the day before regular pick-up day. Any such garbage, rubbish, or solid waste capable of being bagged, shall be bagged and tied, and shall not block the sidewalk or public way. Any premises with continuous excess bagged garbage, rubbish, or solid waste may be provided with an additional container and billed for same. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § VIII, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 13-10-210, § 8, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 30-9. - Removal of tree trimmings and garden trash. 
(a)  Tree trimmings must not exceed five feet in length or a diameter greater than ten inches. Garden trash shall be bagged; bags shall be tied and shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
(b)  Any accumulation in excess of the measurements set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be considered a special services collection. 
(c)  Every nurseryman or other person who cuts trees or trims shrubs or grass as an independent contractor and not as a regular employee of the owner or occupant of the premises shall remove or cause to be removed all tree trimmings, garden trash, and other refuse from the premises serviced by the contractor. Any contractor failing to remove such tree trimmings, garden trash, or other refuse shall be cited for a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § IX, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 13-10-210, § 9, 10-15-2013) 
Sec. 30-10. - Prerequisites to removal by the city. 
    No removal of garbage or rubbish shall be made by the city from any premises unless such garbage or rubbish is deposited in the proper containers as provided by the terms of this chapter and upon which such container fee or collection fee has been paid. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § X, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 30-11. - Waiver of collection fees. 
    Any grievances or request for waiver of any fees established by this chapter shall be submitted to the mayor and board of aldermen in writing stating the grievance or request in detail. Only the mayor and board of aldermen have the right to waive any charges so established. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § XI, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 30-12. - Disasters or emergency conditions. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen may establish temporary measures during and after any disaster or emergency condition concerning the removal of any waste materials. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-174, § XII, 5-21-2007) 
Chapter 32 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority, MCA 1972, § 21-37-3 et seq.; authority of governing authority to regulate streets, MCA 1972, §§ 21-19-1, 21-19-31; use of streets for utilities' purposes, MCA 1972, §§ 21-27-3, 21-27-5, 21-27-7; power to exercise full jurisdiction over streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-3; power to construct and maintain sidewalks, MCA 1972, § 21-37-5; closing streets, MCA 1972, § 21-37-7; power to provide street lighting, MCA 1972, § 21-37-11. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter may be known and cited as the "Conduct and Regulations Ordinance of the City of Horn Lake Parks and Property." 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 1, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    City means the city and any and every place within the corporate limits of the city. 
    City property means any area owned or controlled by the city. 
    Director means the person designated by the mayor and board of aldermen to administer the daily operations of designated parklands within the city. 
    Park means any area of land designated by the mayor and board of aldermen that is to be used for the purposes of recreation. Further stated a park includes: a playfield, playground, pool, golf course, recreation center, or any other area or facility devoted to active or passive recreation. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, governmental unit, company or organization of any kind. 
    Police officer means a duly appointed and acting law enforcement officer of the city or other governmental unit acting under the authority and provisions of an intergovernmental agreement with the city. 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and transports persons or property or pulls machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, truck trailers, motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 2, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-3. - Facilities and property. 
(a)  Buildings and other property. 
(1)  Disfiguration and removal. No person shall willfully deface, disfigure, tamper with or displace or remove any buildings, bridges, tables, benches, barricades, fireplaces, grills, water lines, tractors, or any equipment, or other public utilities or parts, whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Restrooms and washrooms. No person shall fail to cooperate in maintaining restrooms and washrooms in a neat and sanitary condition. No person over the age of four years shall use the restroom and washrooms designated for the opposite sex. 
(3)  Smoking restrictions for park facilities. Smoking is prohibited in all parks of the city. An exception is allowed for persons of legal age who wish to smoke inside their vehicle and no debris is discarded on public property. 
(4)  Removal of natural resources. No unauthorized person shall dig or remove any beach sand, whether submerged or not, or any soil, rock, stones, trees, shrubs, or plants, down timbers, or other materials, or make any excavation by tool, equipment, blasting, or other means. 
(5)  Prohibited activity. No person in a park or on city property shall climb any tree or walk, stand, or sit upon monuments, vases, fountains, railing fences, or upon any other property not designated or customarily used for such purpose. 
(6)  Spray or disseminating of toxic substances. No unauthorized person shall spray or disseminate any toxic substance or fertilizer for pest control or other purpose. 
(7)  Model airplanes. No person shall operate a powered model airplane (either tethered, free flight, or radio controlled) on any park property except at designated places authorized by the director. 
(8)  Use of city's waters. No person shall operate or put into and ride on the waters of any park or city property; a boat, canoe, paddle boat, or any other conveyance used to travel on or used to transport a human on the water except where the director authorizes such activity. 
(9)  Skateboards. No person shall ride a skateboard or cause or permit same to roll or coast within any recreational area, parking lot, facility, or on any sidewalk or roadway in a park or on city property except in areas specifically designated for such activity and in accordance with such rules as prescribed and published by the city. 
(10)  Improper use of facilities. No person shall use park facilities for other than their intended use. 
(b)  Encroachments. No unauthorized person shall erect any structure, make any improvement, injure, disturb or alter, park or store any vehicles or place any property of any kind for storage or otherwise, or use any city property as a means of gaining access to or from private property without obtaining written permission from the director. 
(c)  Preservation of wild animals, birds, etc. 
(1)  No person while on park or city property shall hunt, molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot, throw missiles, destroy, capture, gig, spear, ensnare, or lure any animal, bird, fish, reptile, or amphibian, crayfish or mussel nor shall any person remove or have in their possession the young of any wild animal or the eggs nest or young of any bird, reptile, amphibian, crayfish, or mussel. 
(2)  No person shall fish in any body of water, located in any park or on city property, owned by the city except where designated by the director and official signs are in place giving notice of the designation. 
a.  In the case of special events, the director may issue a permit waiving this prohibition for a specific area and a specific period of time. 
b.  When a permit is issued under this section, a copy shall be transmitted to the office of the city's mayor and the chief of police. 
(3)  No person in a park or on city property shall hunt, trap, or pursue wildlife at any time. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 3, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-4. - Use or possession of firearms and dangerous weapons prohibited. 
(a)  No person except duly sworn law enforcement officers shall possess or carry, on their person or in a vehicle, any pistol, switchblade, hunting knife, dagger, metal knuckles, bludgeon, karate sticks, slingshot, or other dangerous weapon while in a park or on city property. 
(b)  No person shall use, carry or possess, on their person, air rifles, spring guns, bow and arrows, slings, paint ball guns, or other forms of weapons potentially inimical to wildlife and dangerous to human safety, or any instrument that can be loaded with or fire blank cartridges, or any kind of trapping device while in a park or on city property. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 4, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-5. - Sanitation. 
(a)  Pollution of waters. No person in a park or on city property shall throw, discharge, or otherwise place or cause to be placed in the waters of any fountain, pound, lake, stream, or other body of water in or adjacent to any park or city owned property or any tributary, stream, storm sewer or drain flowing into such waters, any substance, matter or thing, liquid or solid, which will or may result in the pollution of said waters. 
(b)  Trash and refuse. No person in a park or on city property shall have brought in or dump, deposit or leave any bottles, broken glass, ashes, paper, boxes, cans, dirt, rubbish, waste, garbage, or refuse or other trash. No such refuse or trash shall be placed in any waters in or contiguous to any park or city property, or left anywhere on the grounds thereof, but shall be placed in the proper receptacles where they are provided; where receptacles are not provided, all such rubbish or waste shall be carried away from the park or city property by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere. 
(c)  Dispending of liquids. No person in a park or on city property shall dispense liquids in glass containers to groups or individuals, but shall use paper cups, which must be provided by the dispensing parties. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 5, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-6. - Traffic. 
(a)  State motor vehicle laws and city ordinances. No person in a park or on city property shall fail to comply with all applicable provisions of the state motor vehicle traffic laws and city ordinances in regard to equipment and operation of vehicles. 
(1)  Obey traffic signs. No person in a park or on city property shall fail to obey any traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping, cross walk lanes, traffic lane markers, and all other signs posted by the director for proper control or safeguarding life and property. 
(2)  Operation confined to roads. No unauthorized person, in a park or on city property, shall drive any vehicle on any area except improved roadways or parking areas, or such other areas as may on occasion be specifically designated as temporary parking areas by the director. 
(3)  All terrain vehicles (ATV), motorcycles, mopeds, go carts, or snowmobiles. No person shall operate or have in a park or on city property any ATV, an unlicensed motorcycle or moped, a go cart, or snowmobile. All such vehicles shall not be on any part of park or city property unless being transported upon some other conveyance and not in operation. 
(4)  Parking. No unauthorized person shall park a vehicle in other than established or designated parking areas, and such shall be in accordance with the posted directions, markings, or directions of the director or a police officer. 
(5)  Congesting park roadways. No person shall park a vehicle upon a park roadway or entranceway. 
(6)  Riding outside vehicles. No person in a park or on city property shall ride upon, or hang onto, the fenders or any other outside part of any vehicle. 
(7)  All night parking. No person shall leave or park a vehicle on park property during the time the park is closed. 
a.  Any such vehicle in violation of this subsection (7) shall be towed from the park at the owners' expense. 
b.  The director may authorize by permit overnight parking under other than ordinary circumstances. 
c.  When a permit is issued for overnight parking, a copy shall be transmitted to the city's chief of police. 
(8)  Livestock. No horses or livestock shall be allowed to be in a park unless authorized for a specific function by the director. 
(b)  Stopping in specific places. No unauthorized person shall stop, stand, or park a vehicle in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or authorized attendant or traffic sign or signal: 
(1)  In an intersection; 
(2)  In a cross walk; 
(3)  Upon a bridge; 
(4)  At any place where the standing of any vehicle will block the use of any driveway, entrance or other through traffic; 
(5)  On any sidewalk; 
(6)  At any place where authorized traffic signs have been erected prohibiting stopping, standing, or parking. 
(c)  Operation of certain vehicles. No unauthorized person shall enter a park or city property with a passenger vehicle, truck, or any other vehicle carrying building materials, merchandise, or other materials except when delivering such materials or supplies for the use of the park or city and shall leave immediately upon delivering such materials. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 6, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-7. - Behavior and regulations. 
(a)  Fireworks, explosives, or rockets. No unauthorized person shall bring or have in his possession or set off or otherwise cause to explode or discharge, or burn, any firecrackers, torpedo, or other fireworks or explosives (as notated in chapter 16, article III) of inflammable materials, or any type of rocket or model rocket, or discharge, launch or throw them into any such areas from land or highway adjacent thereto. This prohibition includes any substance or compound, mixture, or articles that in conjunction with any other substance or compound would be dangerous from any of the foregoing standpoints in a park or on city property. 
(b)  Reservation of facilities. Reservations of park facilities shall be conducted through the director of parks and recreation. 
(1)  The director shall issue a permit to persons, whose application for reserved facilities has been approved, that describes the activities that are allowed for the reserved facilities and the date and time the reservation begins and ends. A copy of the permit shall be transmitted to the city's chief of police and the office of the city's mayor at least three days prior to the scheduled use. 
(2)  The director shall authorize the placement of signs giving notice to all other persons when any pavilion or park structure, property or section thereof has been reserved for use. 
(3)  No unauthorized person shall enter into or remain in any pavilion or park structure, or property or section thereof, which has been reserved and approved by the director. 
(4)  Application. A person or group seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application with the director. The application shall state: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant. 
b.  The name and address of the person or persons, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any. 
c.  A brief description of the activity for which the facilities will be used. 
d.  The beginning and ending date and time for which the reservation is requested. 
e.  The part or portion thereof for which such permit is desired. 
f.  A signed agreement to abide by rules and regulations as provided by the director for the facilities being requested and an acknowledgement that any required deposit may be held for damage to the facilities or litter left on the property. 
g.  Any other information which the director shall find reasonably necessary to make a fair determination as to whether a permit for reservation should be issued hereunder. 
(c)  Alms, solicitations and contributions. No person, group, or entity in a park or on city property shall solicit alms or contributions for any purpose whether public or private, unless so authorized by the director on park properties and by the mayor and board of aldermen for all other city property. 
(1)  Applications for permission will be submitted 14 days in advance, in writing, and submitted to the office of the director for park facilities or the office of the city's mayor for other city property. 
(2)  A permit shall be issued to any person who is authorized to use facilities under this subsection (c). The permit will state the beginning and ending date and time for use of the facilities or property. A copy of the permit shall be transmitted to the chief of police. 
(3)  Any person issued a permit for use under this section shall produce it for law enforcement upon request. 
(d)  Vending, peddling, and advertising. No person: 
(1)  In a park or on city property shall expose or offer for sale any article or thing, nor shall he/she station or place any stand, cart, or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article or thing. Exception is herein made as to any regularly licensed concessionaire or others, acting by and under authority and regulation of the director. 
(2)  Shall paste, glue, tack, or otherwise post any sign, placard, advertisement, or inscription whatsoever in a park or on city property, nor shall any person erect or cause to be erected any sign whatever on any public lands or highways or roadways adjacent to a park, except when prior authorization in writing is given by the director on park properties or by the mayor and board of aldermen for all other city property. 
(3)  In a park shall announce, advertise, or call the public attention in any way to any article, or service for sale or hire, except when prior authorization, is given in writing, by the director. 
(e)  Fires and grills in park areas. No unauthorized person in a park or on city property shall build or attempt to build a fire, start a grill (gas or charcoal) except in such areas and under such regulations as may be authorized by the director on park properties. No person shall drop, throw, or otherwise scatter lighted matches, burning cigarettes or cigars, tobacco paper, charcoal briquette ashes, or other inflammable material, within any park or on city property. 
(f)  Closed areas and park opening and closing times. 
(1)  All parks will be open at 7:00 a.m. and close no later than 10:00 p.m. everyday. An exception to these hours is granted for Maxey and Memorial Parks which shall be accessible to the public 24 hours a day for use of the walking trails. 
(2)  Signs shall be erected at the entranceway of all parks giving notice of operational hours. 
(3)  At such time as the gates at the entranceways of any park are closed and locked, the park is to be considered closed to the public. 
(4)  The director may close any park, or any area or facility of any park for maintenance of facilities or when any condition presents a hazard to the public. When any park or any area thereof is closed to the public, signs shall be placed giving notice to the public that such areas have been closed. 
(5)  No unauthorized person shall enter any area posted as closed to the public, nor shall any person use or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices. 
(6)  No unauthorized person shall enter upon any park property when it is closed for public use. Violations of this subsection (f) shall be deemed trespassing. 
(7)  The director may authorize, by permit, activities on park property outside of normal operational hours. When a permit is issued under this section, a copy shall be transmitted to the office of the city's mayor and the chief of police. 
(g)  Indecent, lewd, or obscene conduct. No person shall perform any of the following acts in a park or on city property: 
(1)  An act of sexual intercourse; 
(2)  An act of deviate sexual conduct; 
(3)  A lewd exposure of the body or any of its parts with the intent to shock another person or the intent to arouse or satisfy the sexual desires of any person; or 
(4)  A lewd touching, foundling or caressing of the body of another of either sex. 
(5)  Commit an obscenity nor solicit a sexual act from another. 
(h)  Other prohibited acts. 
(1)  Games of chance. No person in a park or on city property shall gamble or participate in or abet any game of chance, except for raffles with written permission from the director. 
(2)  Going onto ice. No person in a park or on city property shall go onto the ice on any of the waters. 
(3)  Loitering and boisterousness. No person in a park or other city property shall engage in loud, boisterous, threatening, abusive, insulting, or indecent language, or engage in any disorderly conduct or behavior tending to threaten a breach of the public peace. 
(4)  Entering waters. No person in a park or on city property shall, unless specifically authorized by the director to do so as part of maintenance or construction function, enter the waters of any fountain, pond, lake, stream or other body of water (whether natural or artificial, temporary or permanent), except for designated swimming or wading pools and must be in accordance with the specific operating regulations thereof relating to the hours of operation, the conduct, dress, etc., of that facility. 
(5)  Enticing another to commit offense. No person shall knowingly entice or induce another person to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(6)  Disobey signs or notices. No person shall disobey any sign giving notice of any rule or regulation or any specified safety equipment to be worn during any specific activity in any park. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 7, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-8. - Exceptions to prohibited acts. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit any city employee or official thereof, in the performance of official duties, from engaging in activity for maintenance purposes or responding to emergency situations on park or city properties. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 8, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-9. - Reservation, registration and other fees. 
    The board of aldermen shall approve, as regularly as deemed necessary, a schedule of usage fees, to include, but not be limited to, reservation of facilities, tournaments, registration fees for sports activities, use of equipment and the like. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 9, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-10. - Enforcement of provisions. 
(a)  Each department or division of services of the city has a duty to enforce the provisions of this article within the scope of their duties of employment. 
(b)  The director is authorized to suspend any person from using park facilities for violations of the rules or regulations. 
(1)  Any suspension shall be an administrative matter and may be in addition to any criminal liability. 
(2)  Any person suspended from using park facilities shall be advised in writing. The suspension notice shall state which park the person is suspended from. 
(3)  When any person is suspended from using park facilities, a copy of the suspension form shall be transmitted to the office of the mayor and the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 10, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-11. - Penalties. 
    Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-4. 
(Ord. No. 04-04-130, § 11, 4-13-2004) 
Sec. 32-12. - Sale of vehicles on public streets and properties. 
(a)  No person, corporation, company, association or other entity shall display, show or offer for sale, or allow, permit or suffer the display, show or offer for sale of vehicles on any street, curb, lot or other property, however zoned, located within the city unless the city has issued a privilege license for the sale of such vehicles on such specific location or property. 
(b)  The display of vehicles for sale in areas allowed by this article shall not violate off-street parking requirements and shall not occupy or take up required parking spaces in commercial areas of the city. 
(c)  No vehicle, whether offered for sale or not, shall be parked or displayed in the yard or lawn of a residential dwelling place in the city. 
(d)  This article shall not prohibit the: 
(1)  Sale of a single privately owned, properly licensed vehicle by the owner from the drive of the owner's private residence; 
(2)  Placement of a "for sale" sign in the window of a single, privately owned, properly licensed vehicle by the owner while the vehicle is being driven and parked in the city in the usual and normal course of use of the vehicle by the owner, so long as the vehicle does not remain parked in a public parking place overnight. 
(e)  For each violation of this article, the violator may be fined in an amount not exceeding $1,000.00 and/or imprisoned for a term not exceeding 90 days. Any violator found guilty of a second or subsequent violation of this article shall be fined a minimum of $250.00 for each such violation. Each day during which the offending party remains in breach of this article shall constitute a separate violation hereof. 
(f)  Violators shall include both the owners of vehicles parked or displayed as prohibited hereby and the owners of private property who allow vehicles to be so parked or displayed on their property. 
(g)  This article shall be enforced by the planning department, and the municipal court shall have jurisdiction of all cases arising hereunder. 
(h)  Any vehicle which has not been moved from a public street, curb or other public property after two days from the date of service of a citation of violation of this article on the owner, or which has been left unattended on a public street or other public property for more than five days, shall be towed and stored at the expense of the owner. If such vehicle is not reclaimed within the time set by MCA 1972, § 63-23-3(b), as amended, for reclamation of an abandoned vehicle, it shall be sold as provided by statute. 
(i)  A citation of this article may be served by personal service, or by United States registered return receipt or certified return receipt, postage prepaid mail addressed to the violator, or by any other commercial delivery service which can confirm delivery of the citation. If the addressee refuses to accept delivery and it is so stated in the return receipt of the United States Postal Service or commercial delivery service, the written return receipt, if returned and filed with the court, shall be deemed an actual and valid service of the citation. The United States Postal Service or commercial delivery service notation that a properly addressed citation is unclaimed, refused, or other similar notation, is sufficient evidence of the addressee's refusal to accept delivery. Service by mail or commercial delivery service is complete upon the addressee's receipt of the citation or the addressee's refusal to accept delivery. 
(Ord. No. 04-10-139, 10-19-2004) 
Secs. 32-13-32-42. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROHIBITED DONATION SOLICITATION 

Sec. 32-43. - Purpose. 
    The public health, safety, welfare and comfort of the citizens of the city demand the exercise of the police power of the city in the enactment and enforcement of an ordinance prohibiting persons from standing in the streets of the city for the purpose of soliciting money from passing motorists and related purposes and providing penalties for the violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 10-01-89, § 1, 10-3-1989) 
Sec. 32-44. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Contribution means and includes the words money, clothing, food, pledges, or anything of a monetary value. 
    Person means any individual, firm, corporation, association or any representative thereof, both profit and nonprofit. 
    Solicit means a request or an attempt to request directly or indirectly money, financial, assistance or other thing of value which will be used or personal profit or will be used for a charitable purpose. The term "solicit" shall also be defined as the act of a person, as defined herein, who disseminates published materials in any form, requesting motorists to consider accepting, whether or not actually accepted; said published materials. A solicitation shall be deemed completed when made, whether or not the person making the same receives a contribution or disseminates published material. 
(Ord. No. 10-01-89, § 2, 10-3-1989) 
Sec. 32-45. - Prohibited solicitation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or designated agent to walk within, stand, or locate himself on the asphalt, or paved portions of the streets of the city in order to "solicit" money, financial assistance or other articles of value or to distribute published materials or any other act to solicit contributions as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 10-01-89, § 3, 10-3-1989) 
Sec. 32-46. - Enforcement. 
    Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent, interfere, or prohibit any law enforcement official, fire department official, emergency vehicle personnel or any other official of the federal government or state and its political subdivisions from the faithful performance of said officials' duties. 
(Ord. No. 10-01-89, § 5, 10-3-1989) 
Secs. 32-47-32-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROHIBITED RECREATIONAL USES 

Sec. 32-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public way means any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys, coves, city rights-of-way, public parking lots, and other public ways, within the city. 
    Recreational structure means any structure which facilitates recreations such as, but not limited to, basketball goals, etc. 
(Ord. No. 05-08-149, § 1, 8-23-2005) 
Sec. 32-67. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person, lot owner, nor lessee, of any lot or real property within the city shall erect a basketball goal or other recreational structure on any public way. 
(b)  It is unlawful to allow any basketball goal or other recreational structure located on a public way to remain there after the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(c)  It is unlawful to play basketball or other recreational sports on any public way in the city. 
(Ord. No. 05-08-149, § 2, 8-23-2005) 
Sec. 32-68. - Violations. 
(a)  Violations of this article, or any provisions thereof, shall constitute a misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $250.00; imprisonment for not more than five days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Each day of the violation may constitute a separate violation of this article. 
(c)  The city may remove any basketball goal or other recreational structure located on any public way. 
(Ord. No. 05-08-149, § 3, 8-23-2005) 
Chapter 34 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Subdivision regulation, MCA 1972, § 17-1-23; acceptance for maintenance of subdivision streets before subdivision completed, MCA 1972, § 17-1-25. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 34-1. - Title and purpose. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited and referred to as the "Land Subdivision Ordinance of Horn Lake, Mississippi." The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the coordination of streets within subdivisions with other existing or planned streets or with other features or lots or tracts; for requirements of the preliminary and final plats: for minimum standards of physical improvements in new subdivisions; for adequate open spaces for traffic, utilities, firefighting apparatus, recreation, light and air, and for distribution of population and traffic; all of which are to improve the health, safety, and general welfare of the community. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. I, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alley means a street providing a secondary means of access to a property abutting it. 
    Building line means a line on a plat between which line and a street, no building or structure may be erected. 
    Comprehensive plan means the comprehensive plan made and adopted by the mayor and board of aldermen indicating the general locations recommended for the streets, parks, public buildings, land uses, zoning districts, and other public improvements. 
    Development contract means a contract between a land developer or subdivider and the city's governing authority that describes the improvements that are required of the land developer, specifies the standards under which the required improvements are to be constructed, specifies the time period the land developer shall have to complete the required improvements, specifies all applicable development fees, and delineates the responsibilities of each party with respect to the construction and acceptance of any public improvements. 
    Easement means authorization by a property owner for the use by another, and for a specified purpose, of any designated part of his property. The following are examples of easements: 
(1)  Utility. An easement reserving space for utilities. 
(2)  Access. For purpose of this chapter, a private way which is permanently reserved for as the principal means of vehicular access to abutting property, and the terms of use of which are of public record. 
    Engineer means the city engineer. 
    Governing authority means the mayor and board of aldermen for the city. 
    Land developer means any individual or business that causes changes to unimproved or improved real estate including, but not limited to, the preparation of raw land for the construction of buildings, redevelopment of improved real estate, filling, grading, paving, excavation, and storage of materials. 
    Lot means any parcel of land having ten acres or less or any parcel and land, regardless of size, not bordering a public road. 
    Lot of record means a lot recorded in the office of the chancery clerk in compliance with the laws of the city at the time of its recording. 
    Performance surety means a security that guarantees the satisfactory installation and completion of improvements required as part of an application for subdivision and/or development. An acceptable performance surety shall include cash or its equivalent, or letters of credit from a bank located in the county. 
    Planning commission means the city planning commission. 
    Plat means a map or drawing showing the lot and street arrangement or other features or details of the area being subdivided and is further defined as follows: 
    Plat, final, means a plat conforming to the requirements of article II of this chapter for final approval and recording in the office of the chancery clerk. 
    Plat, preliminary, means a plat conforming to the requirements of article II of this chapter for preliminary approval. 
    Plat, sketch, means a plat conforming to the requirements of article II of this chapter prior to filing a preliminary plat. 
    Reverse frontage lots means lots which face on and are served by one street and which back up to another street. 
    Right-of-way means the entire strip of land lying between property lines of a street or alley. 
    Streets means a right-of-way for vehicular traffic which is accepted for the public use, and is maintained by the city, county, or state, whether designated as a street, highway, thoroughfare, arterial, road, avenue, boulevard, land, place, or however otherwise designated. The term "streets" is further defined as follows: 
    Cul-de-sac means a permanent dead-end street or court culminated by a turnaround and not intended to be extended in the future. 
    Street, collector, means a street having the primary function of collecting and distributing traffic between local streets or areas and the major street and highway network and designated as a collector street in the current city transportation plan. 
    Street, local, means a street having a primary function of providing service and access to abutting land and not designated for high volumes of traffic but having sufficient width to serve occasional parking and traffic flow. 
    Street, scenic arterial, means a street having the primary function of connecting areas of principal traffic generation and designated as a scenic arterial in the city transportation plan (1992). It is different from an urban arterial in that its traffic volumes are normally of a lower magnitude and its location is through a somewhat unique natural setting. 
    Street, urban arterial, means a street having the primary functions of accommodating relatively large volumes of vehicular traffic and serving to connect areas of principal traffic generation and designated as an arterial in the city transportation plan (1992). 
    Subdivider means any person, individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, trust or any other group or combination acting as a unit, who undertakes the subdivision of land as defined herein. 
    Subdivision means any land, vacant or improved, which is divided or proposed to be divided into two or more lots, parcels, sites, units, plots, or interests for the purpose of offer, sale, lease, or development, either on the installment plan or upon any and all other plans, terms, and conditions, including resubdivision. The term "subdivision" includes the division or development of residential and nonresidential zoned land whether by deed, metes and bounds description, devise, intestacy, lease, map, plat, or other recorded instrument. 
    Subdivision, major, means all subdivisions not classified as minor subdivision including, but not limited to, subdivisions of four or more lots, or of any size subdivision requiring the construction of any new street or the extension of any municipal facilities or the creation of any public improvements. 
    Subdivision, minor. To qualify for consideration as a minor subdivision a subdivision must meet one of the following criteria: 
(1)  Any subdivision containing not more than three lots fronting on any existing public street, not involving any new public street or road, or the extension of any municipal facilities, or the creation of any public improvements, and not adversely affecting the remainder of the parcel or adjoining property, and not in conflict with any provision or portion of the city comprehensive plan, official map, zoning ordinance, or these regulations. 
(2)  Where a subdivision provides for the transfer of land between adjacent property owners, and does not involve the creation of any new building sites or lots. 
(3)  Where any number of lots of record are consolidated to create a lesser number of parcels and does not involve the creation of any new public streets or the extension of any municipal facilities or the creation of any public improvements, and would not, if approved, destroy, or adversely affect the rights of the mayor and board of aldermen in any existing, or previously approved rights-of-way, streets, facilities, or improvements. 
(4)  Where there is a need to make technical revisions to a record, final plat of any engineering or drafting nature or similar discrepancy, where, if approved, such change would not destroy or adversely affect the rights of the mayor and board of aldermen in any existing, or previously approved, right-of-way, streets, facilities, or improvements. 
(5)  All subdivisions of land which contain two or more lots which may be exempt from obtaining residential construction framing permits from the building inspector's office. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. II, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-3. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person being the owner, agent, or person having control of any land within the incorporated areas of the city to subdivide or lay out such land in lots unless by a plot, in accordance with the regulations contained herein. No lots shall be sold nor any plat recorded until a plat has been approved as herein provided. 
(b)  Any area hereafter annexed to the city, immediately upon annexation shall be no longer subject to the county subdivision regulations, but shall conform to the subdivision regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. III, 2-17-1994) 
Secs. 34-4-34-24. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATTING OF SUBDIVISIONS 

Sec. 34-25. - General procedure. 
(a)  Whenever any subdivision of land is proposed, before any recording of deeds, and before any permit for the erection of a structure in such proposed subdivision shall be granted, the owner or his authorized agent, shall apply for and secure approval of such proposed subdivision in accordance with the following procedure, which includes three steps for a major subdivision and two steps for a minor subdivision: 
(1)  Major subdivision. 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Preliminary plat. 
c.  Final plat. 
(2)  Minor subdivision. 
a.  Sketch plat. 
b.  Final plat. 
(b)  Prior to final approval of any lot in the city which does not have central collection and treatment for sewage, an application must be submitted to the county health department for notation that septic tanks will be approved and any conditions or limitations for such approval. 
(c)  No plat or replat subdividing land into lots shall be filed or recorded in the office of the chancery clerk for the county unless and until reviewed by the planning commission and approved by the mayor and board of aldermen and no lot shall be sold from such plat or replat until the plat is filed for record in the office of the chancery clerk for the county. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-26. - Major subdivision procedure. 
    The subdivider of a major subdivision shall submit a sketch plat and a preliminary plat, except where waived by the director of the planning commission, in accordance with the specifications of this article. Upon approval of the sketch and preliminary plats, in accordance with these regulations, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of construction plans and the final plat for the approval by the city engineer and planning commission in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-27. - Minor subdivision procedure. 
    Any subdivider whose division of property meets the criteria for classification as a minor subdivision shall submit a sketch plat and a final plat to the planning commission and the mayor and board of aldermen for approval in accordance with the requirements and specifications of this article. However, such minor subdivision shall be exempt from the requirements of a preliminary plat. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-28. - Sketch plat procedure. 
(a)  The purpose of the sketch plat is to provide the subdivider an opportunity to consult early and informally with the planning commission staff before preparation of a preliminary and/or final plat and submission of a formal application to the planning commission. The intent of this procedure is to assist the subdivider in preparing a plan which will meet the objectives of the comprehensive plan, the requirements of the planning commission and of other public agencies, the improvements and uses of the subdivision and other potential problems involved in the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  The subdivider shall submit to the planning commission staff a sketch plat showing the boundaries of the proposed subdivision, its relationship to surrounding properties, natural features and the proposed street and lot pattern. This step does not require a formal application or filing fee. Upon receipt of the sketch plat, the planning commission staff shall review the sketch plat, and notify the subdivider through consultation and/or writing that the sketch plat as submitted, or modified, meets the objectives of these regulations, or does not meet the objectives of these regulations and the reason therefor. If the proposed subdivision is to contain two or more lots whose dwelling structures will be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector, a note shall be affixed on the face of the plat stating, "This plat contains two or more lots whose dwelling structures may be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector." 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-29. - Preliminary plat application procedure. 
(a)  Five copies of the preliminary plat, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 100 feet, except where waived by the director of the planning commission, conforming to the requirements of section 34-30, shall be submitted to the planning commission. The plat shall be accompanied by an application form supplied by the planning commission and a filing fee to be fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen in a separate ordinance, resolution or order. Application must be made no later than the two weeks prior to the date of the next regularly scheduled meeting of the planning commission to be heard at that meeting. If the proposed subdivision is to contain two or more lots whose dwelling structures will be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector, a note shall be affixed on the face of the plat stating: "This plat contains two or more lots whose dwelling structures may be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector." 
(b)  If the planning commission after the recommendation of the city engineer finds that the preliminary plat satisfies the requirements of this article, it shall approve said plat. The subdivider or his agent must be present at the planning commission meeting scheduled to hear the submitted application unless otherwise advised by the director of the planning commission. 
(c)  If the planning commission finds otherwise, it shall specify the objections found to such plat and may either disapprove or approve the plat conditional upon specific changes being made to the plat prior to its submission to the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(d)  Within 90 days after submission of the preliminary plat and other required materials submitted in conformity to these regulations, the planning commission shall specify to the subdivider its approval and state the conditions of such approval, or in the event of disapproval, shall state its disapproval and reasons therefor. However, the subdivider may waive the time limitation requirements and consent to an extension of such period. 
(e)  The planning commission may attach additional conditions not specified in this article and reject a subdivision if it has been determined that the proposed subdivision is not in keeping with the general character of the development in the area; and that in the best interest of the public, the site is not suitable for the proposed development purpose. 
(f)  When requested, one copy of the proposed plat and findings of the planning commission shall be given the person offering the proposed plat, together with a certificate of approval or disapproval of the planning commission. Approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission does not constitute a final acceptance or approval of proposed subdivision. 
(g)  On the basis of approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider may proceed with the preparation of construction plans and the final plat with reasonable assurance that no major changes will be required or made at a later stage of the approval process; provided the final plat is approved within one year from the date of preliminary plat approval. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-30. - Data for preliminary plat. 
(a)  Required information of plat and accompanying documents. The preliminary plat and eight prints shall be at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet unless otherwise specified by the planning commission staff. The preliminary plat and accompanying documents shall show the following: 
(1)  The proposed lot lines, lot numbers and the lot layout for the subdivision. 
(2)  Minimum building setback lines. 
(3)  The location of all existing dimensions of right-of-way widths, street names. 
(4)  Easements, their location, width and purpose. 
(5)  Sites reserved for parks, public spaces, drainage area. 
(6)  The proposed use of all land in the subdivision including any reserved areas and acreage. 
(b)  General information. The preliminary plat shall show: 
(1)  The location of existing property lines, streets, buildings, watercourses, zoning classifications, and other existing features within the area to be subdivided and similar information regarding existing conditions of land immediately adjacent thereto. 
(2)  The acreage of the land to be subdivided. 
(3)  Areas which are subject to periodic inundation (100-year flood elevation). 
(4)  The proposals for sewer and water service shown as a note on plat and any accompanying documentation from appropriate agencies. 
(5)  The title under which the proposed subdivision is to be recorded, and the name and Mississippi registration number of the engineer, registered land surveyor, planner, and the subdivider platting the tract. 
(6)  Location sketch map showing relationship of subdivision site to area including township, range, section, and parts of section. 
(7)  The names and adjoining boundaries of all adjoining subdivisions and the names of recorded owners of adjoining parcels of unsubdivided land. 
(8)  Contours at vertical intervals of not more than two feet will be shown for property to be platted as school or park sites. 
(9)  North point, graphic scale and date. 
(10)  The subdivider's proposal to the mayor and board of aldermen for accomplishing the installation of improvements in accordance with article IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-31. - Final plat application procedure. 
(a)  Eight prints at a scale of one inch equals 100 feet and three prints at a scale of one inch equals 200 feet of the final plat, accompanied by an application form supplied by the planning commission, a filing fee to be fixed by the mayor and board of aldermen by separate ordinance, together with copies of any deed restrictions where such restrictions are too lengthy to be shown on the plat, shall be submitted to the planning commission. Application must be made no later than two weeks prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the planning commission to be heard at that meeting. 
(b)  Concurrent with the submittal of the final plat, the subdivider shall submit to the city engineer two complete sets of subdivision construction plans that shall include, but not be limited to, the following: grading and drainage plan; erosion control plan; utility plan; and plan and profiles of all proposed street improvements. The city engineer shall review and approve the subdivision construction plans and certify to the planning commission and mayor and board of aldermen that the submitted construction plans and final plat are in compliance with the approved preliminary plat. Additionally, the city engineer shall calculate and present to the mayor and board of aldermen the amount of any applicable performance surety. 
(c)  When the final plat conforms to the approved preliminary plat, and the requirements of this article have been accomplished, the final plat shall be approved by the chairman of the planning commission, and the plat thereupon submitted to the mayor and board of aldermen for its review and final determination. When the final plat does not conform to the approved preliminary plat, the planning commission shall submit its recommendations to the mayor and board of aldermen for approval or disapproval of the final plat. The subdivider or his agent must be present at the planning commission meeting scheduled to hear the submitted application unless otherwise advised by the director of the planning commission. 
(d)  After approval of the final plat by the mayor and board of aldermen and required improvements are installed or appropriate arrangements have been made therefor, a cloth-backed original plat shall be recorded in the office of the chancery clerk within one year and if not filed, such plat shall have no validity and shall not be recorded without concurrence of the planning commission. A cloth-backed copy of the recorded plat shall be provided to the planning commission for its official records. 
(e)  Any land dedicated to the city for park purposes in a subdivision shall be conveyed to the city free and clear of all encumbrances at the same time the plat of subdivision is filed, said deeds to be without restrictions or covenants except a requirement that the land be used for park purposes without reversion and with references to the subdivision, if any, on which the land is shown. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-32. - Data for final plat. 
(a)  Required information of plat and accompanying documents. The final plat and eight prints shall be at a scale of not more than 100 feet to the inch from an accurate survey and on one or more sheets whose dimensions shall be 18 inches by 24 inches. If more than two sheets are required, an index sheet of the same dimensions shall be filed showing the entire subdivision on one sheet and the component areas shown on other sheets. If the proposed subdivision is to contain two or more lots whose dwelling structures will be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector, a note shall be affixed on the face of the plat stating, "This plat contains two or more lots whose dwelling structures may be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the Horn Lake Building Inspector." The final plat and the accompanying documentation shall show the following: 
(1)  The boundary lines of the area being subdivided with accurate distances and angles, showing all relationship of the subdivision to section, township and range. 
(2)  The lines of all proposed streets and alloys with their widths and the names of all streets. 
(3)  The accurate outline of any portions of the property intended to be dedicated or granted for public use with a statement of dedication thereon. 
(4)  The lines of all adjoining property and the line of adjoining streets and alleys with their widths and the names of all streets within 100 feet of the proposed subdivision. 
(5)  All lot lines together with an identification of all lots which shall be numbered consecutively. 
(6)  The location of all building lines and easements provided for public use, services, or utilities. 
(7)  All dimensions, both linear and angular, necessary for locating the boundaries of the subdivision, lots, streets, alleys, easements, and other areas for public or private use. Linear dimensions are to be given to the nearest 0.01 foot. 
(8)  The radii, arcs or chords, points of tangency and central angles for curvilinear streets and radii for rounded corners. 
(9)  The location of all survey monuments and their descriptions as provided in section 34-88. 
(b)  General information. The final plat shall show the following: 
(1)  The name of the subdivision, a graphic scale of the plat, a north arrow oriented toward the top of the page, the date, and the name of the owner or owners or subdivider. 
(2)  Location sketch map showing relationship of subdivision site to area including township, range, section, and parts of sections. 
(3)  The certificate, state registration number and legal seal of a registered engineer or land surveyor attesting the accuracy of the survey and the correct location of all monuments shown. 
(4)  Private restrictions or trusteeships and their periods of existence. Should these restrictions or trusteeships be of such length as to make their lettering on the plat impracticable and thus necessitate the preparation of a separate instrument, reference to such instrument shall be made on the plat. 
(5)  Acknowledgement of the owner or owners of the plat, and restrictions including dedication to public use of all streets, alleys, parks or other open spaces shown thereon and the granting of easements required. 
(6)  Proper certificates for owner, notary public, registered engineer or land surveyor, planning commission, board of mayor and aldermen and chancery clerk, shown in that order. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-33. - Procedure for recording final plat. 
    After final approval is obtained from the mayor and board of aldermen and all conditions have been satisfied, two cloth-backed copies and two half-size prints shall be submitted for recording which shall contain the necessary signatures, certificates, and seals as specified in section 34-32(b), a recording fee as established by the office of the chancery clerk, and an attorney's certificate of title certifying title to the land subdivided valid as of the hour and day of recording. The final plat shall not be recorded until: 
(1)  All required improvements have been completed and inspected by the city, and a final resolution authorizing acceptance of the improvements as been acted upon by the mayor and board of aldermen; or 
(2)  A performance surety for the entire cost (i.e., full letter of credit) of required improvements has been posted. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-34. - Relation to planned unit development (PUD). 
(a)  Any portion or a tract zoned as a PUD district may be submitted for approval as a major subdivision; provided that the PUD district zoning regulations governing the approval of a preliminary site plan are met. In submitting any PUD subdivision for approval, the prior action of the planning commission and the appropriate legislative body in granting the zoning application shall be sufficient preliminary plat approval within the meaning of article IV. No preliminary plat specified in this article II shall be required. 
(b)  The basic purpose of PUD is to allow flexibility in the development of planned communities. PUD is intended to facilitate total density control as an alternative to regulation of individual lot size, harmonious development of mixed land uses, creative alternatives to traditional standards for minimum improvements, and development of attractive and functional common areas for recreational common areas for recreational and other purposes. Within the general limitations of the comprehensive plan, the intent of these regulations and the public interest, convenience, safety and welfare, the planning commission may consider this purpose and may waive or modify any requirements of article III and IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. IV, 2-17-1994) 
Secs. 34-35-34-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SUBDIVISION DESIGN STANDARDS 

Sec. 34-57. - Streets. 
(a)  The arrangement of streets in all new subdivisions shall make provisions for the continuation of the principal existing streets in the adjoining areas or their proper projection and for any streets or roads shown on the city transportation plan. 
(b)  All proposed street names shall avoid duplication of other street names in the county unless the proposed street is obviously intended as an extension of another existing or proposed street, in which case the streets shall bear the same name. 
(c)  The arrangement of streets and lots shall give due regard to topography and other physical features of the property. 
(d)  The right-of-way widths and location of major and collector streets shall conform to the right-of-way widths and locations of such streets designated on the transportation plan. However, the planning commission may consider any other proposed street a major or collector street and require comparable right-of-way widths. 
(e)  The minimum widths of street and road right-of-way, measured from lot line to lot line, shall be as shown on the transportation plan, or if not shown on such plan, shall not be less than the following: 
Street Type Right-of-Way 
(in feet) Urban arterial Six lanes with median (rural) 114 Six lanes with turn lane (curb and gutter) 108 Four lanes with median (rural) 106 Four lanes with turn lane (curb and gutter) 84 Scenic arterial Four lanes with median (rural) 106 Two lanes (rural) 60 Collector Four lanes (rural) 74 Four lanes, no parking (curb and gutter) 68 Two lanes with turn lane (rural) 62 Two lanes with turn lane (curb and gutter) 56 Two lanes with parking (curb and gutter) 60 Local Two lanes (rural) 50 Two lanes (curb and gutter) 50  
The minimum right-of-way width for local streets shall be 50 feet, except that in cases where the topography or special conditions make right-of-way of less width more suitable, the planning commission may waive the above requirement. 
(f)  The angle of intersection between streets should not vary by more than ten degrees from a right angle. 
(g)  The minimum corner radii at street intersections shall be 20 feet. 
(h)  Street jogs resulting from failure to align streets on either side of an intersection are prohibited, with a minimum offset of 150 feet between centerlines of parallel streets being required. 
(i)  Cul-de-sac streets may be provided if proper access is given to all lots from a dedicated street or court. All cul-de-sac streets shall terminate in a dedicated right-of-way space having a minimum radius of 50 feet, or other satisfactory arrangement for tuning of vehicles. A cul-de-sac street shall not exceed 500 feet in length. 
(j)  Minimum street grades of 0.5 percent will be required for adequate drainage; maximum street grades will be seven percent for all streets. Intersections will be a minimum feasible grade with sight distance of at least 100 feet in all directions. A minimum sight distance of 200 feet will be required in all curves. 
(k)  Alleys shall not be provided in a residential block. In industrial or commercial subdivisions, paved alleys or driveway easements assuring permanent rear access may be required with a minimum width of 20 feet. 
(l)  To ensure a continuous circulation system in an area when all the land is developed the planning commission may require extension of a street within a subdivision to the adjoining property, which street would be continued at the time the adjoining property would be developed. Temporary turnarounds with a 40-foot radius shall be provided at the termination of such streets unless waived by the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-58. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements of at least ten feet in width shall be dedicated on each side of all rear lot lines and at least five feet on each side lot line and at least ten feet on all lot lines adjoining a street, for poles, wires, conduits, storm and sanitary sewers, gas, water, or other utilities. The developer shall confer with all utility companies serving the property. Easements of greater width than normally required may be required as necessary. No side, rear or front yard easements will be required where the city zoning ordinance indicates no yard requirements. 
(b)  Whenever any stream or important surface drainage course is located in an area which is being subdivided, the subdivider shall provide an adequate easement along each side of the stream for the purpose of widening, deepening, sloping, improving, or protecting the stream or drainage course. The adequacy of the easement shall be determined by the engineer. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-59. - Blocks. 
    All new blocks created by any major subdivision of land shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  All blocks shall be sufficiently wide to allow two tiers of lots appropriate depth under the applicable zoning regulations, unless another length or width is approved by the planning commission because of special topographical or traffic considerations. 
(2)  No block shall be less than 250 feet nor more than 1,500 feet in length except as the planning commission considers necessary to secure efficient use of land or desired features of street patterns. 
(3)  Mid-block walkways, or crosswalks, not less than ten feet wide may be required where deemed essential to improve pedestrian circulations, or access to schools, shopping centers, parks, playgrounds or other community facilities. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-60. - Lots. 
(a)  The lot arrangement and design shall be such that all lots will provide satisfactory and desirable building sites, properly related to topography and to the character of surrounding development. 
(b)  The minimum lot area and lot width, measured at the building lines, shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance for the applicable zoning district. 
(c)  No lot shall have a depth in excess of four times its width, however this requirement may be waived by the planning commission if the subdivider can demonstrate this requirement is not appropriate for the type of development and use contemplated. 
(d)  All side lot lines shall be at right angles to straight street lines and redial to curved street lines except where a variation of this rule will provide a better street and lot layout as approved by the planning commission. 
(e)  Corner lots shall have a width sufficient to permit the establishment of front building lines on both the adjoining streets without reducing the buildable width below that of the average sized lot in the subdivision. 
(f)  Reverse frontage lots shall be prohibited except where essential as determined by the planning commission to provide separation of residential development from traffic arteries or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography. In such cases, additional depth including a planting screen reservation of a minimum of ten feet in width, and across which there shall be no right of access, shall be provided along the line of lots abutting such uses. A statement dissolving the right of access of lots to the major street shall be included on the final plat. 
(g)  Property line radii at street intersections shall not be less than 20 feet. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-61. - Public sites, facilities and open spaces. 
(a)  Adequate park, school, recreational space shall be provided at convenient locations throughout the subdivision and conform to the comprehensive plan. The amount, type and locations of such areas will depend on the size and type of development and shall be developed in accordance with the location, space and size requirements presented in the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  The planning commission may recommend that a proposed subdivision be assessed a fee in lieu of public land dedication at the rate of $300.00 per lot for development of 50 lots or less and $250.00 per lot for development of over 50 lots. 
(c)  All land to be reserved for dedication to the local government or acquisition for public use purposes shall be prior approval of the appropriate governmental agency and shall be shown on the plat: "Reserved for park and/or recreation and/or public use purposes."
