(d)  Where a subdivision contains sewers, sewage treatment plants, water supply systems, park areas, or other physical facilities necessary or desirable for the welfare of the area and of common use or benefit, which the mayor and board of aldermen does not desire to or cannot maintain, provision shall be made for the proper and continuous maintenance and supervision of such facilities by the lot owners in the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-62. - General suitability. 
(a)  The planning commission may reject a subdivision if it has been determined that the proposed subdivision is not in keeping with the general character of the development in the area; and that in the best interest of the public, the site is not suitable for the proposed development purposes. 
(b)  Where deed restrictions or covenants are proposed, they shall be included with the plat and made a part of such plat; provided, however, that such deed restrictions or covenants shall not contain reversionary clauses wherein any lot shall return to the subdivider because of a violation thereon of the terms of the restrictions or covenants. 
(c)  Land which is shown as within the flood control district on the official zoning district map shall not be platted for residential or any other use which may result in danger to health, life or property or increased flood heights; unless the subdivider submits to the planning commission that the area can be protected from inundation, by fill, levee, or other means, without undue interference either with the flow of any watercourse or with any necessary impounding basin, which evidence shall be verified by the city engineer. The elevation and extent of flooding in each drainage area shall be established by the city engineer and shall be indicated on both the preliminary and final plats. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-63. - Subdivision and street names. 
    The proposed name of the subdivision and street names shall not duplicate, or too closely approximate phonetically, the name of any other subdivision or streets in the county. 
Sec. 34-64. - Special design standards for subdivisions. 
    Any subdivision or portion of a subdivision, identified with a note on the plat as a subdivision which contains two or more lots whose dwelling structures may be exempt from obtaining a residential construction framing permit from the building inspector, shall be subject to the provisions of article V, section Q, found in appendix A of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. V, 2-17-1994) 
Secs. 34-65-34-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REQUIRED MINIMUM IMPROVEMENTS 

Sec. 34-85. - Final plat approved; installation of required improvements. 
    Receipt by the subdivider of the approval of the final plat by the planning commission and mayor and board of aldermen shall constitute authority for the subdivider to proceed with the installation of the required improvements in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Execution of development contract. A development contract shall be executed between the subdivider and the mayor and board of aldermen when improvements, as described in these regulations, are required. 
(2)  Performance sureties. To assure performance of the provisions of the development contract, the subdivider shall post one of the following performance sureties: 
a.  Full letter of credit. The subdivider shall submit an irrevocable/automatically renewable letter of credit for 100 percent of the costs of required improvements as computed by the city engineer, and approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
b.  Alternative letter of credit. The subdivider may submit an irrevocable/automatically renewable alternative letter of credit to cover the costs associated with the installation of the minimum public improvements. The city engineer shall determine the minimum public improvements to be installed and shall compute the amount of the alternative letter of credit, and the same to be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
The mayor and board of aldermen shall reserve the right to select the type of performance surety used to guarantee improvements based upon the scope and magnitude of the required and/or minimum public improvements. 
(3)  Authorization of construction, plans. Following the execution of the development contract, posting of any performance surety, and payment of all development fees, the city engineer may sign the construction plans and authorize construction of the required improvements. 
(4)  Required improvements subject to construction standards and plans of city. Required improvements shall be constructed in accordance with the city construction standards and specifications, and construction plans approved by the city engineer. 
(5)  Inspection of improvements. All improvements shall be inspected during the course of construction of the improvements. A schedule of inspections must be coordinated with the city engineer. 
(6)  Acceptance of constructed improvements. Any improvements constructed by the subdivider shall not be officially accepted until final inspection and approval has been made by the city, the appropriate warranty surety has been provided, and the mayor and board of aldermen has approved a resolution accepting the improvements. 
(7)  Warranty. Warranty of the all improvements shall be the responsibility of the subdivider until acceptance by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VI, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-86. - Procedures for posting, conversion or release of performance surety. 
(a)  Performance sureties for required and/or minimum public improvements shall be determined by the city engineer, and shall be a sum at least equal to the amount estimated to construct such improvements as provided in this article. 
(b)  Any development being improved under the alternative letter of credit procedure may be converted to a full letter of credit with the concurrence of the city engineer, and approval of the mayor and board of aldermen. The final plat, if applicable, may then be recorded in accordance with the provisions for recording final plats contained herein. 
(c)  When all of the required improvements have been constructed, the subdivider shall contact the engineer for a final inspection and shall provide certification that the final improvements have been installed according to city specifications. The engineer shall inspect the subdivision and make a written report, a copy of which is to be provided to the subdivider and the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(d)  The performance surety will be released by order of the mayor and board of aldermen when the subdivision receives an approved final inspection report from the engineer. The mayor and board of aldermen on recommendation of the engineer may reduce liability on the performance surety as work progresses and after acceptance may reduce the performance surety to such amount as the engineer deems sufficient to guarantee performance of the warranty. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VI, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-09-126, 9-16-2003) 
Sec. 34-87. - Installation of part of improvements. 
    The owner of a tract may prepare and secure approval of a preliminary plat for the entire tract and may install the required improvements in only a portion of such tract, but the improvements must be installed or provision made for their installation in any portion of the area for which a final plat is approved for recording. This is provided, however, that any gas mains, storm sewers, and any sewage treatment plants shall be designed and built to serve all the area owned by the subdivider or designed and built in such a manner that they can easily be expanded or extended to serve the entire area; and provided further that the requirements of section 34-61(b) have been met. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VI, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-88. - Survey monuments. 
    All subdivision boundary corners shall be marked with permanent monuments. A permanent monument shall be deemed to be a four-inch by four-inch concrete post at least 30 inches long with a one-half-inch steel rod center. Should conditions prohibit the placing of monuments on the line, offset marking will be permitted; provided, however, that exact offset courses and distances are shown on the subdivision plat. Iron pipes or steel rods shall be set at all lot corners. If survey monuments are removed during construction, they shall be replaced. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VI, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-89. - Minimum standards. 
(a)  Submission of plans. The owner shall submit to the engineer two complete sets of plans and profiles of road work to be constructed in the subdivision. The engineer may require the owner to lay grades and designate size of drains to be used before considering the same and may make any changes he deems necessary to conform to good engineering practice. 
(b)  Topographical map. The owner will furnish the engineer a topographical map of the area to be subdivided when required by him, so that he may be able to study drainage requirements. Contours on the map shall be on two-foot intervals from actual elevation. 
(c)  Street improvements. All existing and new roads, regardless of lot size must comply with these regulations before dedication is accepted and before the roads will be maintained by the city: 
(1)  Width and depth of compacted gravel: 
a.  Residential subdivisions shall be a minimum of eight inches of compacted gravel or measured before compaction, 12 inches of load measurement. 
b.  Commercial and industrial subdivisions shall have a minimum of 12 inches of compacted gravel over the entire width of the proposed gravel area or shall use a black base treatment in accordance with the state aid road specifications. 
c.  Width of compacted gravel: 
1.  50-foot right-of-way roads shall have 30 feet of compacted gravel. 
2.  60-foot right-of-way roads shall have 40 feet of compacted gravel. 
3.  All 68-foot and 80-foot right-of-way roads shall have 48 feet of compacted gravel. 
Where needed as an arterial road, the gravel thickness and width may be increased by the city engineer. 
(2)  Width of pavement: 
a.  50-foot right-of-way roads shall have 30 feet of pavement of 20 feet when there is no curb and gutter. 
b.  All other roads shall have pavement widths as specified in the cross sections shown in figure 1. 
(3)  All new roads must be paved by the developer before being accepted by the mayor and board of aldermen for maintenance. Two inches of plant mix surface, using the latest state highway specifications is required on all new roads in subdivisions. Any changes from these specifications must be approved by the engineer and tests may be required on all materials. The latest edition of the state specifications will govern construction. 
(4)  All bridges shall be constructed according to the state standard specifications for state aid road and bridge construction in effect at the time the subdivision is approved. 
(5)  The subdivider shall dedicate and construct all minor and collector streets for full width of right-of-way as defined in section 34-57(e). Where the developer is developing a subdivision that runs to the center of a major or arterial street, he will be required to dedicate and develop only one-half of said road. However, in no case shall less than 20 feet of wearing surface be required when one-half of the right-of-way is dedicated. 
(6)  Curb and gutter will be installed in all residential, commercial and industrial zoned subdivisions using the state highway specifications. The developer shall have material and compression tests of the concrete performed and the results submitted to the engineer. In residential, industrial, and commercial subdivisions in rural areas, curb and gutter requirements shall be of such character as is suitable for the expected traffic and in harmony with similar improvements in the surrounding area, as determined by the engineer. 
(7)  The developer's engineer must notify the engineer in writing when the subgrade is ready for gravel stating all culverts, subgrade width and firmness of subgrade are up to approved engineering standards before gravel is placed on the road. The owner shall notify the engineer when he plans to place gravel on the road. The engineer may have a representative present if load measurement is to be used. After the gravel is placed, the engineer will again certify that the gravel is of proper material thickness and width. When the road is to be paved, the engineer again will certify as to road bed being a proper condition for surfacing and that the materials used meet standards. The engineer or his representative will inspect the road one time after being notified at completion of each phase of this work at no cost to the owner. If another trip is made, there will be a per hour charge for time involved in all other trips. 
(8)  If these standards are not carried out, the mayor and board of aldermen will not accept the roads for maintenance. 
(d)  Drainage. The plat shall be laid out so as to provide proper drainage of the area being subdivided. Drainage improvements shall maintain any natural watercourse and shall prevent the collection of water in any low areas. (Also see subsection (k)(5) of this section.) 
(1)  All drainage pipes may be concrete, asphalt-coated metal pipes or plain galvanized coated metal pipes. The engineer must approve the gauge thickness of asphalt-coated metal pipes or plain galvanized metal pipes. All plain galvanized pipes approved the engineer for the sizes 21 inches through 96 inches in diameter shall be one gauge heavier than the approved gauge for asphalt-coated metal pipe. The developer's engineer shall provide the engineer with the shipping tickets showing the gauge of all pipes installed. 
(2)  The planning commission upon recommendation of the engineer may require paving of ditches or appropriate stabilization. Sufficient easements will be provided on subdivision plats for maintenance of large ditches for alignment and cleaning. Ditches shall be constructed on uniform grades sufficient for proper runoff. 
(3)  All underground drainage must be inspected and approved by the engineer. 
(4)  All driveway culverts and ramps shall be provided for by the subdivider. The cost of culverts and ramps shall be included within the performance bond for the subdivider, with the number of culverts and costs being approved and estimated by the engineer. Upon installation of any culverts or ramps by the subdivider, the performance bond may be reduced or a new bond substituted to secure the obligation with respect to culvert and ramp provision requirements. 
(e)  Sidewalks. Concrete sidewalks not less than five feet wide and four inches in depth shall be constructed along both sides of all major and collector streets with curbs and gutters in accordance with applicable standard specifications of the city. Sidewalks shall be constructed along at least one side of every minor street shown on the plat with the exception of cul-de-sac where sidewalks are not required. 
(1)  The mayor and board of aldermen may waive the above requirement for sidewalks provided that street rights-of-way are left unobstructed and graded in such manner that sidewalks may be constructed at a later date. 
(2)  Material and compression tests of the concrete shall be performed and submitted to the engineer. 
(3)  The mayor and board of aldermen may, in their discretion, require a minimum fee of $15.00 per linear foot to be paid to the city in lieu of complying with the requirement for sidewalks. Said fee to be determined at the time of each development, based on current rates and/or charges. Said funds are to be specified and designated for further development of sidewalks within the city and where deemed necessary by the mayor and board of alderment and in the best interest of the citizens. 
(f)  Water supply. All subdivisions shall have the proposed water system approved by the appropriate state agency. The water system shall have enough outlets and shall be large enough to furnish an adequate water supply and fire protection to every lot. 
(1)  Water mains, where possible, shall be located in street rights-of-way as approved by the engineer. 
(2)  The installation of the water system, including fire hydrants, shall be subject to the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen and engineer. 
(3)  Fire hydrants shall be installed in all subdivisions except where the water system serving that subdivision is not adequate. The hydrants shall be located not more than 500 feet as measured along a dedicated street from all lots within the subdivision. All fire hydrants will be served by a six-inch or larger water line. 
(g)  Sanitary sewer system. Centralized sewage collection and treatment facilities shall be provided on all lots in all subdivisions except as hereafter provided, and shall conform to all applicable state and local laws. 
(1)  Where centralized public sewage collection systems are not reasonably accessible to the subdivider and an individual centralized disposal system is provided by the subdivider, sewer lines shall be laid out so a future connection with the public sewer main shall be made. All plans shall be designed and approved in accordance with the rules, regulations and standards of the state board of health and the county health department. Necessary action shall be taken by the subdivider to extend or create a sanitary sewer district which will maintain the disposal system. 
(2)  Individual septic tanks may be used in subdivisions where central sewage is not available only if written approval is obtained from the state board of health acting through the county health department. 
(3)  All subdivisions hereafter filed for record in the office of the chancery clerk shall be approved only for use with central collection and treatment of sewage unless there is affixed to the plat a notation signed on behalf of the health department that septic tanks may be used on the lots. Developers contemplating use of central collection and treatment need not submit such plats to the health department but all approvals by the city will only authorize centralized collection and treatment and no building permit will be issued authorizing use of septic tanks on such lots. Notations authorizing use of septic tanks by the health department may be in substantially this form: 
"Septic tanks may be used on the lots shown on this plat of subdivision." 
Desoto County Health Department 
by Health Officer ___________ 
Date: ___________ 
(h)  Street lights and traffic signs. Street lights and traffic signs shall be required in accordance with design and specification standards approved by the engineer and utility company. Where street lights are required, the subdivider will confer with the electric utility company serving the property. 
(i)  Street signs. Street signs shall be installed at all intersections within and bordering the subdivision in accordance with city specifications. 
(j)  Care of area during construction. Builders and contractors shall be responsible for cleaning up all loose paper and material subject to be scattered by the wind each day and prevent such material from scattering through a subdivision or to adjoining property. 
(1)  The premises will be kept in a reasonably clear unlittered manner. Building permits may be withheld from builders and contractors who fail to maintain premises free of litter and loose paper after being warned by the building department. 
(2)  Builders and contractors shall not permit waste materials, dirt and debris to be placed or allowed to remain in a public street or road. Surplus dirt shall not be graded or pushed into a street. If a builder or contractor shall not immediately remove such material placed by him or his subcontractors in a street after being warned, no building permit shall be issued to him for a period of six months thereafter, and the violator may be prosecuted for unlawfully placing an obstruction in a public road. At the discretion of the building official, he may cause such material to be removed and the contractor shall be required to pay the cost of such removal. 
(k)  Erosion and sediment control. Installation of the above improvements shall be done in such a manner as to provide for the most effective control of erosion and sediment. The construction plan shall be accompanied by an erosion and sediment control plan which shall be submitted to the county soil and water conservation district for review and recommendations. Practical combination of the following technical principles shall be used: 
(1)  The smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any one time during development. 
(2)  When land is exposed during development, the exposure shall be kept to the shortest practical period of time. 
(3)  Temporary vegetation or mulching shall be used to protect critical areas exposed during development. 
(4)  Sediment basins (debris basins, desilting basins, or silt traps) shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters of land undergoing development. 
(5)  Provisions shall be made to effectively accommodate the runoff caused by changed soil conditions during and after development. 
(6)  Permanent final vegetation and structures shall be installed as soon as practical in the development. 
(7)  The development plan shall be fitted to the topography and soils so as to create the least possible erosion. 
(8)  Whenever feasible, natural vegetation shall be retained and protected. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VI, 2-17-1994; Ord. No. 03-02-120, 2-18-2003) 
Secs. 34-90-34-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - REVISION OF RECORDED PLATS 

Sec. 34-107. - Errors. 
    Errors on recorded subdivision plats may be corrected by the subdivider by making a written request to the mayor and board of aldermen to have such correction made. The mayor and board of aldermen may direct that the correction be made directly on the existing recorded plat, or they may direct that a complete new plat be filed as required in section 34-108. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VII, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-108. - Revision of plats. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen on such terms and conditions as it imposes, may authorize revision of recorded plat combining lots, changing lot lines or calls, correcting errors and other revisions on application by the owners of the lots being changed. The corrected plat shall be filed as a separate revision of the subdivision to include a notation attached to the originally recorded plat showing revisions made and location of corrected plat; and title certificate may be required on the corrected plat. 
(b)  On commercial and industrial subdivisions, lot lines are recognized for reference purposes only. Any redivision of a lot previously shown on a recorded plat must be submitted to the planning commission and mayor and board of aldermen so as to determine if the changes in lot lines conform to these regulations. Any vacation or relocation of utilities must have the concurrence of the utility company serving the property. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VII, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-109. - Vacation of plats. 
(a)  Any recorded plat or portion thereof may be vacated by the subdivider at any time before the sale of any lot therein, by written request to the planning commission with a copy of such plat attached. Such written request shall be approved by the planning commission and mayor and board of aldermen and recorded in the office of the chancery clerk. The mayor and board of aldermen may reject such request which destroys any public rights in any of its public uses, improvements or streets. The recorded vacation of plat shall destroy the effect of the recorded plat and shall divest all public right in streets, public grounds and all dedications provided in such plat. 
(b)  When lots have been sold, the recorded plat may be vacated in the manner described in subsection (a) of this section; provided all the owners of lots in such plat join in the execution of such written request. A title certificate shall be included with the written request to the planning commission, along with a copy of the recorded plat. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VII, 2-17-1994) 
Secs. 34-110-34-131. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - COMPLIANCE 

Sec. 34-132. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Whenever the tract to be subdivided is of such unusual size or shape, or in the interest of the preservation of existing trees and other natural beauty, or is surrounded by such development or unusual conditions that the strict application of the requirements contained in this article would result in real difficulties or substantial hardship or injustice, the mayor and board of aldermen, after report by the planning commission, may vary or modify such requirements so that the subdivider may develop his property in a reasonable manner, but so that at the same time the public welfare and interests of the city are protected and the general intent and spirit of this article are preserved. 
(b)  If a major subdivision lies within one mile of a municipality, the application shall be referred to the mayor and board of aldermen thereof for a recommendation prior to final approval. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. VIII, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-133. - Amendments. 
    Any regulations or provisions of this article may be changed and amended from time to time by the mayor and board of aldermen in accordance with applicable state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. X, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-134. - Penalty. 
    It shall be illegal to sell, or offer to sell, any lot, tract, or property which does not conform to the requirements and regulations of this article. In the case of any violation of this article, the mayor and board of aldermen, in addition to other remedies, may institute any appropriate action or proceedings to prevent such unlawful acts. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. XI, 2-17-1994) 
Sec. 34-135. - Conflicts. 
    These regulations are not intended to interfere with, or annul any other ordinance, rule of regulation, statute, or other provision of law. Where any provision of these regulations impose restrictions different from those imposed by any other provision of these regulations or any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of these regulations or any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provisions are more restrictive shall control. 
(Ord. No. 94-2-35, art. XII, 2-17-1994)

ARTICLE III. - MOTOR VEHICLE AD VALOREM TAX 

Sec. 36-42. - Purpose. 
    The city is hereby authorized and empowered to collect motor vehicle ad valorem taxes on all motor vehicles within the incorporated limits of the city. Motor vehicles shall be assessed uniformly according to value and such assessed value shall be determined by an assessment schedule which shall be prepared and made of minute record by the state tax commission. 
(Ord. No. 94-10-43, § I, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 36-43. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Citizen means any person who is a resident or inhabitant of the city. 
    Motor vehicle means any device and attachments supported by one or more wheels which is propelled or drawn by any power other than muscular power over the highways, streets or alleys of this state. Provided, however, that mobile homes which are detached from any self-propelled vehicles and parked on land in the state are hereby expressly exempt from the motor vehicle ad valorem taxes, but house trailers which are actually in transit and which are not parked for more than an overnight stop are not exempted. 
    Public highway means and includes every way or place of whatever nature, including public roads, streets and alleys of this state generally open to the use of the public or to be opened or reopened to the use of the public for the purpose of vehicular travel, notwithstanding that the same may be temporarily closed for the purpose of construction, reconstruction, maintenance, or repair. 
(Ord. No. 94-10-43, § II, 10-4-1994) 
Sec. 36-44. - Payment of tax. 
(a)  All citizens of the city shall pay a motor vehicle ad valorem tax as provided for in MCA 1972, § 27-51-1 et seq., in the amount of the mills so established each year by the tax levy for the city. The vehicle's assessed value is set forth by the state tax commission. 
(b)  The city has previously entered into an agreement with the county tax collector to collect the motor vehicle ad valorem tax as in accordance with MCA 1972, § 27-51-29. Proof of payment of said ad valorem motor vehicle tax will be evidenced by proper and/or current license tags. 
(Ord. No. 94-10-43, § III, 10-4-1994) 
Chapter 38 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Uniform Highway Traffic Regulation Law-Rules of the Road, MCA 1972, § 63-3-1; authority to adopt traffic regulations not in conflict with state law, MCA 1972, § 63-3-209; traffic regulation enforcement powers of municipalities specified, MCA 1972, § 63-3-211; parking violations, MCA 1972, § 21-23-19; parking prohibited in specified places, MCA 1972, § 63-3-901. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Failure to maintain control of vehicle. 
(a)  Any action of a vehicle, either while in motion or having been involved in an accident, that would cause a reasonable person to believe that the operator of said vehicle does not or did not have complete control of that vehicle, while observed moving or did not have control of said vehicle at the time of an accident the operator shall be charged with "failure to maintain control." 
(b)  If the conditions in subsection (a) of this section are observed, the operator of said vehicle will be charged with failure to maintain control. 
(Ord. No. 8-1-87, 8-6-1987) 
Sec. 38-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial trailer means any flatbed, box van or other trailer designed to be drawn by a ten-wheel commercial tractor. 
    Commercial vehicle means any vehicle that meets one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  Trucks with ten wheels, registered as a commercial vehicle in any state, primarily used for commercial business and commonly used as an 18-wheel truck and trailer combination. 
(2)  Commercial box van vehicles commonly used in construction, electrical or other commercial business type work. 
(3)  Any vehicle with a gross weight of more than 15,000 pounds. 
    Hard surface means concrete or asphalt continuously poured or applied to form a paved surface consistent with that of a driveway. 
    Junk appliances means, but is not limited to, the following: ice boxes, refrigerators, stoves, washing machines, hot water tanks, or other similar items that are in a state of disrepair. 
    Junk vehicle means any motor vehicle which meets one or more of the following conditions: 
(1)  The vehicle is inoperable. 
(2)  The vehicle is dismantled, partially dismantled or severely damaged. 
(3)  The vehicle does not have a valid license plate. 
(4)  One or more of the vehicle's tires are flat and have remained flat for a period of 24 hours. 
(5)  The vehicle is leaking oil or other fluids. 
    Property means any real property within the city which is not a street or highway. 
    Rubbish means, but is not limited to, the following: used articles or used pieces of iron, scrap metal, automobile bodies or parts of machinery or junked or discarded machinery, used lumber which may be used as a harborage for rats, ashes, industrial by products or waste, empty cans, food containers, bottles, crockery, utensils of any kind, boxes, barrels, weeds, glass, building rubbish, dead trees, garbage, and all other articles customarily considered trash or junk and which are not housed in a building. 
    Street or highway means the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel and shall include any right-of-way associated with that street or highway. 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transports persons or property or pulls machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Sec. 38-3. - On-street parking. 
    On-street parking is restricted to private passenger vehicles not routinely used for commercial business to include cars, trucks, sport utility vehicles, vans and motorcycles. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Sec. 38-4. - Off-street parking. 
(a)  Parking or storing of a recreational vehicle, camper trailer, boat or boat trailer, utility trailer less than 16 feet, any piece of equipment or any vehicle authorized in residential areas must be off-street on private property, in good repair and parked on a hard surface as defined in section 38-2, unless the property owner has a permit issued by the planning department for a limestone driveway. (Hard surface only does not apply to AR district.) 
(b)  A camping or travel trailer shall not be occupied permanently, over 14 days, while it is parked or stored in any area within the incorporated limits. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to allow raw sewage to drain onto open land, as this shall constitute a health hazard. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005; Ord. No. 06-06-164, 6-6-2006) 
Sec. 38-5. - Location or presence of junk or abandoned vehicles within the city deemed public nuisance; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall abandon any vehicle within the city or leave any vehicle at any place within the city for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle to reasonably appear to have been abandoned. 
(b)  No person shall leave a junk vehicle on any street or highway within the city. 
(c)  No person shall perform maintenance on a vehicle while parked on a street unless such is of a minor nature to get a disabled vehicle moving again. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to store or keep any junk vehicle on any property within the city unless the vehicle or any part thereof is completely enclosed within a building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the street or other public and private property; or the vehicle or part thereof is stored on property that is maintained in such a manner so that it does not constitute a health hazard and is screened from ordinary public view. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Sec. 38-6. - Location or presence of appliances and rubbish within the city deemed public nuisance; remedies. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of a residential or commercial building or property to utilize the premises of such property for the open storage of any junk appliances or rubbish. Such prohibition includes the storage of any junk appliance or rubbish in an open carport. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005; Ord. No. 09-07-192, § 1(A), 8-18-2009) 
Sec. 38-7. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent any of the following activities: 
(1)  The operation or parking of any vehicle or piece of equipment owned or operated by the city, or any other governmental entity, while in the performance of official business. 
(2)  The operation of commercial vehicles and/or equipment owned or operated by the persons who are performing a service for the city. 
(3)  The operation of commercial vehicles and/or equipment that are engaged in servicing either public or private utilities or performing some legitimate business service. 
(4)  The use of junk vehicles by educational institutions to promote awareness programs. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Sec. 38-8. - Enforcement authority. 
    The police department and the planning department shall have the authority to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Sec. 38-9. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any owner, operator or other person who violates any provision of this article may receive a traffic citation or summons to court. 
(b)  Any vehicle, equipment or trailer may be towed at the expense of the owner for a violation of this article in addition to a citation or summons to appear in court. 
(c)  A citation or summons of this article may be served by personal service, or by United States registered return receipt or certified return receipt, postage prepaid mail addressed to the violator, or by any other commercial delivery service which can confirm delivery of the citation or summons. If the addressee refuses to accept delivery and it is so stated in the return receipt of the United States Postal Service or commercial delivery service, the written return receipt, if returned and filed with the Court, shall be deemed an actual and valid service of the citation or summons. The United States Postal Service or commercial delivery service notation that a properly addressed citation is unclaimed, refused, or other similar notation, is sufficient evidence of the addressee's refusal to accept delivery. Service by mail or commercial delivery service is complete upon the addressee's receipt of the citation or the addressee's refusal to accept delivery. 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005) 
Secs. 38-10-38-36. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKING 

Sec. 38-37. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Fire lanes shall be provided for all buildings which are set back more than 150 feet from a public road or exceed 30 feet in height and are set back more than 50 feet from a public road. 
(b)  Fire lanes shall be at least 20 feet in width with road edge closest to the building. Any dead end more than 300 feet long shall be provided with a turnaround at the closest end at least 90 feet in diameter. 
(c)  The designation use and maintenance of fire lanes on private property shall be accomplished as specified by the fire marshal. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park motor vehicles on, or otherwise obstruct, designated fire lanes. 
(Ord. No. 7-1-88, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 38-38. - Parking by the disabled; handicap zone. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stop or stand any vehicle in violation of any sign installed or area designated as a handicap zone. 
(Ord. No. 7-1-88, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 38-39. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Vehicle means a machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and transports persons or property or pulls machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, tractor trailers (including, but not limited to, 18 wheelers), motorcycles, tractors, buggies and wagons. 
(Ord. No. 99-04-88, § I, 4-20-1999) 
Sec. 38-40. - Purpose. 
    This article prohibits parking of vehicles on any street or highway or adjacent to any street or highway when official signs are present. 
(Ord. No. 99-04-88, § II, 4-20-1999) 
Sec. 38-41. - Authority to place official signs. 
(a)  Official signs, prohibiting parking of vehicles, may be posted at the direction of the chief of police after a determination that parking of vehicles upon or adjacent to a street or highway constitutes a hazard for other motorists. 
(b)  Official signs may be posted by the state department of transportation upon state and federal highways within the city pursuant to a determination by the department that a need exists to prohibit parking upon or adjacent to a state or federal highway within the city. 
(Ord. No. 99-04-88, § III, 4-20-1999) 
Sec. 38-42. - Exception to obedience to official signs. 
    The operator of a vehicle would not be in violation of this article for parking a vehicle in an area where official signs prohibit parking if the vehicle is disabled and the driver notifies the police department of the following information: 
(1)  The location of the vehicle. 
(2)  The description of the vehicle. 
(3)  The name, address, and telephone number of the driver, owner or individual responsible for the vehicle. 
(4)  The date and time that the vehicle will be removed. 
(Ord. No. 99-04-88, § IV, 4-20-1999) 
Sec. 38-43. - Prohibited parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for an operator of a vehicle to park a vehicle on or adjacent to a street or highway within the city where official signs prohibit parking. 
(Ord. No. 99-04-88, § V, 4-20-1999) 
Secs. 38-44-38-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL AND OTHER HEAVY VEHICLES 

Sec. 38-80. - City commercial vehicle route established. 
(a)  All commercial vehicles defined in section 38-2 must travel only on the designated commercial routes established in this section except when making a verified pickup or delivery. 
(b)  Commercial vehicles making a verified delivery or pickup must travel the designated commercial route to the nearest point of the pickup or delivery before turning onto other streets not designated as part of the designated commercial route. 
(c)  Commercial trailers as defined in section 38-2 shall be allowed in residential areas only for a verified pickup or delivery and shall not remain overnight for any reason. 
(d)  The commercial vehicle route is established as follows: 
(1)  Highway 51 (city limits north to city limits south). 
(2)  Highway 302 (city limits east to city limits west). 
(3)  Nail Road (from Highway 51, west to Hurt Road). 
(4)  Hurt Road (from Highway 302, south to Nail Road). 
(5)  Highway 301 (city limits north to city limits south). 
(Ord. No. 05-03-145, 3-1-2005; Ord. No. 06-06-164, 6-6-2006) 
Secs. 38-81-38-109. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 98-01-73, § I, 1-6-1998)

(Ord. No. 98-01-73, § III, 1-6-1998)

Chapter 40 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 40-1-40-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 40-19. - Cross connection control program; purpose. 
(a)  The mayor and board of aldermen deem it necessary to protect the public potable water supply served by the city, from the possibility of contamination or pollutions by isolating, within its customers' internal distribution system, such contaminants or pollutants which could backflow or back-siphon into the public water system; to promote the elimination or control of existing cross connection, actual or potential, between its customers' in-plant potable water system and non-potable systems; and to provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross connection control which will effectively prevent the contamination or pollution of all potable water systems by cross connection. 
(b)  The city, as hereinafter defined, will operate a cross connection control program, to include the keeping of necessary records, which fulfills the requirements of the state department of health's cross connection regulations and is approved by the department of health. Such records to be maintained by the city shall include records of the type, size and location of each backflow preventer installed in the system, when each backflow preventer is due to be tested, and the results of each test. Records shall be maintained for five years from date of test and inspections. The owner shall allow his property to be inspected for possible cross connections and shall follow the provision of the city's program and the state department of health's regulations if a cross connection is permitted. If the city requires that the public supply be protected by containment, the owner shall be responsible for water quality beyond the outlet end of the containment device and should utilize fixture outlet protection for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § I, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-20. - Authority. 
    It shall be the duty of the city and his/her designated representative to implement a cross connection control program to enforce this article and to prevent any person from violating this article in order to protect the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollution due to the backflow or back-siphonage of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. If, in the judgment of the city an approved backflow device is required at the city's water service connection to any customer's premises, the city or their designated representative, shall give notice in writing to said customer to install an approved back flow prevention device at each service connection to his premises, and failure to comply with this or other notices shall subject said customer to all penalties provided herein or as set forth in any other applicable laws. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § II, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms, phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Air gap means a physical separation sufficient to prevent backflow between the free-flowing discharge end of the potable water system and any other system. The term "air gap" is physically defined as a distance equal to twice the diameter of the supply side pipe diameter but never less than one inch. 
    Approved means accepted by the city as meeting an applicable specification stated or cited in this article, or as suitable for the proposed use. 
    Atmospheric vacuum breaker means a device which prevents back-siphonage by creating an atmospheric vent when there is either a negative pressure or sub-atmospheric pressure in a water system. 
    Auxiliary water supply means any water supply, on or available, to the premises other than the city's approved public potable water supply. 
    Backflow means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances, under positive or reduced pressure in the distribution pipes of a potable water supply from any source other than its intended source. 
    Backflow preventer means a device or means designed to prevent backflow or back-siphonage and is most commonly categorized as air gap, reduced pressure principal device, double check valve assembly, pressure vacuum breaker, atmospheric vacuum breaker, hose bibb vacuum breaker, residential dual check, double check with intermediate atmospheric vent, all of which terms are elsewhere defined herein. 
    Backpressure means a condition in which the owner's system pressure is greater than the supplier's system pressure. 
    Back-siphonage means the flow of water or other liquids, mixtures or substances into the distribution pipes of a potable water supply system from any source other than its intended source caused by the sudden reduction of pressure in the potable water supply system. 
    Containment means a method of backflow prevention which requires a backflow preventer at the water service entrance. 
    Contaminant means a substance that will impair the quality of the water to a degree that it creates a serious health hazard to the public leading to poisoning or the spread of disease. 
    Cross connection means any actual or potential connection between the public water supply and a source of contamination or pollution. 
    Department of health means the state department of health, division of water supply. 
    Double check valve assembly means an assembly of two independently operating spring loaded check valves with tightly closing shut-off valves on each side of the check valves, plus properly located test cocks for the testing of each check valve. 
    Double check valve with intermediate atmospheric vent means a device having two spring loaded check valves separated by an atmospheric vent chamber. 
    Fixture isolation means a method of backflow prevention in which a backflow preventer is located to correct a cross connection at an in-plant location rather than at a water service entrance. 
    Health hazard (high hazard) means contamination with the potential to endanger the health and well-being of the water customers or owners. 
    Hose bibb vacuum breaker means a device which is permanently attached to a hose bibb and which acts as an atmospheric vacuum breaker. 
    Non-potable water means water not acceptable for human consumption or of unknown quality. 
    Non-health hazard (low hazard) means not harmful to health, but would still be objectionable. 
    Owner means any person who has legal title to, or license to operate or habitat in, a property upon which a cross connection inspection is made or upon which a cross connection is present. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, company, public or private corporation, political subdivision, department, agency or instrumentality of the state or the United States or any other legal entity. 
    Permit means a document issued by the city or its designated representative, which allows the use of a backflow preventer. 
    Pollutant means a foreign substance that, if permitted to get into the public water system, will degrade its quality so as to constitute a high hazard, or impair the usefulness or quality of the water to a degree which does not create an actual hazard to the public health but which does adversely and unreasonably affect such water for domestic use. 
    Potable water means water that is acceptable for human consumption. 
    Pressure vacuum breaker means a device containing one or two independently operated spring loaded check valves and an independently operated spring loaded air inlet valve located on the discharge side of the check or checks. Such device includes tightly closing shut off valves on each side of the check valves and properly located test cocks for the testing of the check valve. 
    Reduced pressure principal backflow preventer means an assembly consisting of two independently operating approved check valves with an automatically operating differential relief valve located between the two check valves, tightly closing shut-off valves on each side of the check valves plus properly located test cocks for the testing of the check valves and the relief valve. 
    Residential dual check means an assembly of two spring loaded, independently operating check valves without tightly closing shut-off valves and test cocks, generally employed immediately downstream of the water meter to act as a containment device. 
    Water service entrance means that point in the owner's water system beyond the sanitary control of the city; it is generally considered to be the outlet end of the water meter and is always located before any unprotected branch. 
    Water system means the public water system of the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § III, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-22. - Backflow prevention assembly requirements. 
(a)  Elimination and protection of cross connections. Cross connections occurring within the city shall be eliminated or protected with the appropriate backflow preventer. Cross connections are eliminated by establishing an air gap between the potable and non-potable sources. Cross connections are protected by installing the appropriate backflow preventer. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the cross connection to eliminate the cross connection or protect the cross connection with a backflow preventer approved by the city. 
(b)  Connection to sewer. Direct connections, permanent or temporary, between the water system and a sanitary sewer are prohibited. 
(c)  Home wells. Connection to any source of water other than that provided by the water system, including home wells, is prohibited per the city Code. 
(d)  Approved backflow prevention assemblies. Only backflow prevention assemblies approved by the department of health shall be installed on the water system to comply with this article. 
(e)  Installation requirements. Reduced pressure principal assemblies, double check valve assemblies and pressure vacuum breakers shall be installed in a manner and location that provide adequate access for testing and repair of the assembly. Reduced pressure principal assemblies and double check valve assemblies shall not be subject to possible flooding. Reduced pressure principal assemblies and double check valve assemblies shall not be installed in a pit or enclosure below ground level. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § IV, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-23. - Requirement and responsibilities. 
(a)  City or its designated representatives. 
(1)  On new installations, the city will provide on-site evaluations and/or inspection of plans in order to determine the type of backflow preventer, if any, that will be required, will issue permits, and perform inspections. In any case, a minimum of a dual check valve will be required in any new construction. 
(2)  For premises existing prior to the start of this program, the city will perform evaluations and inspections of plans and/or premises and inform the owner by letter of any corrective action deemed necessary, the method of achieving the correction, and the time allowed for the corrections to be made. 
(3)  The city will not allow any cross connection to remain unless it is protected by an approved backflow preventer for which a permit has been issued and which will be regularly tested to ensure satisfactory operation. 
(4)  The city shall inform the owner, by letter, of any failure to comply, by the time of the first reinspection. The city will allow an additional 15 days for the correction. In the event the owner fails to comply with the necessary correction by the time of the second reinspection, the city will inform the owner by letter, that the water service to the owner's premises will be terminated within a period not to exceed five days. In the event that the owner informs the city of extenuating circumstances as to why the correction has not been made, a time extension may be granted by the city, but in no case shall such extension exceed an additional 30 days. 
(5)  If the city determines at anytime that a serious threat to the public health exists, the water service may be terminated immediately. 
(6)  The city shall have on file a list of private contractors who are certified backflow device testers. All charges for these tests will be paid by the owner of the building or property receiving water service. 
(7)  The city will begin initial premises inspections to determine the nature of existing or potential hazards, following the approval of this program by the department of health, during the calendar year 2001. Initial focus will be on high hazard industries and commercial premises. 
(b)  Owner. 
(1)  The owner shall be responsible for the elimination or protection of all cross connections on his premises. 
(2)  The owner, after having been informed by a letter from the city, shall at his/her expense, install, maintain, and test or have tested, any and all backflow preventers on his premises. 
(3)  The owner shall correct any malfunctions of the backflow preventer which is revealed by periodic testing. 
(4)  The owner shall inform the city of any proposed or modified cross connections and also any existing cross connections of which the owner is aware but has not been found by the city. 
(5)  The owner shall not install a bypass around any backflow preventer unless there is a backflow preventer of the same type on the bypass. Owners who can not shut down operations for testing of the device must supply additional devices necessary to allow testing to take place. 
(6)  The owner shall install backflow preventers in a manner approved by the city. 
(7)  The owner shall install only backflow preventers approved by the city or the department of health. 
(8)  In the event the owner installs plumbing to provide potable water for domestic purposes which is on the city's side of the backflow preventer, such plumbing must have its own backflow preventer installed. 
(9)  The owner shall be responsible for the payment of all fees for permits, annual or semi-annual device testing, retesting in the case that the device fails to operate correctly, and second reinspections for noncompliance with the city or department of health requirements. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § V, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-24. - Testing of backflow prevention devices. 
(a)  Right to enter. The city shall have the right to enter any nonresidential building, during reasonable hours, to inspect the plumbing system installed in any such building or premises provided prior notification of the inspection is given. The city shall first obtain consent of the owner to enter any residential dwelling. 
(b)  Tests required. Each reduced pressure principal backflow prevention assembly, double check valve assembly, and pressure vacuum breaker installed shall be tested after installation, after repairs of any kind, and annually. Any backflow preventer found to be nonfunctional shall be repaired and retested within 14 days of the initial test. 
(c)  Certified testers. Only backflow preventer testers certified by the department of health shall test backflow preventers located in the city. 
(d)  Failure upon testing. Any backflow preventer which fails during a periodic test will be repaired or replaced. When repairs are necessary, upon completion of the repairs the device will be retested at owner's expense to ensure correct operation. High hazard situations will not be allowed to continue unprotected if the backflow preventer fails the test and cannot be repaired immediately. In other situations, a compliance date of not more than 14 days after the test date will be established. The owner is responsible for spare parts, repair tools, or a replacement device. Parallel installation of two devices is an effective means of the owner ensuring that uninterrupted water service during testing or repair of devices and is strongly recommended. 
(e)  Circumstances justifying increased testing frequency. Backflow prevention devices will be tested more frequently than specified in subsection (b) of this section, in cases where there is a history of test failures and the city feels that due to the degree of hazard involved, additional testing is warranted. Cost of the additional tests will be borne by the owner. 
(f)  Notification of testing. The city shall notify the owner of each backflow preventer 60 days prior to the date that the backflow preventer is scheduled to be tested. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § VI, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-25. - Degree of hazard; classification of hazard. 
(a)  The city recognizes the threat to the public water system arising from cross connections. All threats will be classified by degree of hazard and will require the installation of approved reduced pressure principal backflow prevention devices or double check valves. Each cross connection found will be classified by high hazard or low hazard by the city. 
(b)  If a connection is found to be a high hazard cross connection, the owner of the connection shall be notified in writing within ten days that the cross connection shall be eliminated or protected by the installation of a backflow preventer approved by the city within 90 days of notification. 
(c)  If the connection is found to be a low hazard cross connection, the owner of the connection shall be notified in writing within ten days that the connection shall be eliminated or protected by a backflow preventer approved by the city within one year of notification. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § VII, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-26. - Permits. 
(a)  Cross connection permits that are required for each backflow prevention device shall be obtained from the city. A fee of $25.00 will be charged for the initial permit and $15.00 for the renewal of each permit, or in amounts as may be established by resolution or order of the governing authority, whichever is greater. 
(b)  Permits shall be renewed every year and are non-transferable. Permits are subject to revocation and become immediately revoked if the owner should so change the type of cross connection or degree of hazard associated with the service, in addition to any other applicable penalties. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § VIII, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-27. - Existing, in use backflow prevention devices. 
(a)  Any existing approved backflow preventer shall be allowed by the city, if it meets the department of health's standards, to continue in service unless the degree of hazard is such as to supercede the effectiveness of the present backflow preventer, or result in an unreasonable risk to the public health. 
(b)  Where the degree of hazard has increased as in the case of a residential installation converting to a business establishment, any existing backflow preventer must be upgraded to a reduced pressure principal device, or a reduced pressure principal device must be installed in the event no backflow device was present. 
(c)  Any existing backflow preventers will be tested within 90 days of their identification. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § IX, 12-5-2000) 
Sec. 40-28. - Other violations and penalties. 
(a)  Refusal of inspection. If the owner refuses to allow the city to perform the necessary inspections to determine if a cross connection exists, the city shall require that reduced pressure principle backflow prevention assembly be installed at that service connection. 
(b)  Refusal to eliminate hazard. If the owner, after having been informed that a cross connection exists at his property, refuses to eliminate or protect the cross connection though the use of the appropriate backflow preventer within the department of health regulations time limits, 90 days for high hazard and one year for low hazard, water service to the connection shall be terminated until such time as the owner complies with department of health regulations. 
(Ord. No. 00-12-103, § X, 12-5-2000) 
Secs. 40-29-40-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES AND CHARGES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-60. - Water and sewer rates and charges. 
(a)  The rates and charges for the use and services of the water and sewer system are hereby established, shall be made and collected against each consumer who shall directly or indirectly receive water and sewer service from the system, and shall be based upon the quantity of water used by each consumer, as measured by the water meter designated for that purpose. 
(b)  Charges shall be computed on a monthly basis as described in divisions 2 and 3 of this article.

Sec. 40-115. - Sewer collection system; stronger than normal discharge. 
    In the event the customer discharges wastewater into the sewer collection system that is stronger than normal or contains chemicals or materials that make treatment more expensive or difficult, the sewer department may require special action to be taken by the customer or additional payment by customer as defined by city ordinance. 
Sec. 40-116. - Sewer maintenance; interceptor sewer; commercial and industrial. 
    A charge of $50.00 will be billed if the need for a sewer cleanout at a residence is needed. This special service will only be performed after the owner of the property has signed a waiver of liability, protecting the city and any authorized representatives for the city for outside maintenance of the utility system, from any damages incurred as a result of the procedure. 
Sec. 40-117. - County regional utility authority. 
    An amount equal to each customer's proportionate part of the amount charged by the county regional utility authority for the same month plus a two percent administrative fee shall be assessed. Said charges will not be assessed to those residents receiving sewer service through the Horn Lake Creek Basin Interceptor Sewer District. 
Sec. 40-118. - Wastewater system development and capacity availability assessment. 
(a)  The city hereby establishes, approves and agrees to collect development and capacity availability assessments in the amount of $1,000.00 for each new equivalent single-family construction occurring within the geographic boundaries of the city but outside the boundaries of the Horn Lake Creek Interceptor District, and the amount of $500.00 for each new equivalent single-family construction occurring within the geographic boundaries of the city and inside the boundaries of the Horn Lake Creek Interceptor District. From each assessment, $300.00 will be considered a supplemental development and capacity availability assessment. Such assessment will be charged and collected upon the issuance of any new building permit issued by the city. 
(b)  Any monies collected as development and capacity availability assessments will be provided to the county regional utility authority. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 1, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-119. - Exceptions. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen reserve the right to impose rates and charges when water and sewer is furnished in circumstances which make the rates in divisions 2 and 3 of this article unjust, inadequate or inequitable, and to fix and impose special charges where interruptible service is given. 
(1)  Temporary water service. Temporary water service may be set up for a maximum period of two weeks (14 days) with an advance payment of an amount as set by ordinance, resolution, and/or order of the governing authority. Temporary water service will only be allowed once per property, per year. In emergency situations an extension of an additional week or an exception may be granted provided a detailed written explanation is submitted and an additional payment is paid in an amount as set by ordinance, resolution, and/or order of the governing authority. 
(2)  Temporary water service; real estate brokers. A real estate broker may set up temporary water service for a period of six weeks with an advance payment of an amount as set by ordinance, resolution, and/or order of the governing authority for any property being listed for sale by said broker; provided documentation (satisfactory to the city) is presented reflecting the property is uninhabited, owned by HUD, and/or was recently foreclosed. The temporary water service will be established in the broker's name, but the broker may provide a written list of approved real estate agents who may establish service in the broker's name. The broker shall pay for any services of the system for the six-week period that exceeds the initial amount paid based upon current water and sewer service rates. Any penalty provided for in this article shall be added to any bill for excess consumption not paid by the due date. A broker (or an approved agent) may extend the temporary water service for any such property for an unlimited number of six-week periods with an advance payment of an amount as set by ordinance, resolution, and/or order of the governing authority for each period; provided no payment is due for any excess consumption referenced herein. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 2, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 11-06-203, § 1, 6-7-2011) 
Sec. 40-120. - Monthly reading of meters. 
    Water shall be supplied only through a meter, which shall be read monthly by the city. Bills shall be sent out by the city within the first ten days of the month following the reading of the meter and shall be collected immediately thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 3, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-121. - Penalty for late payments; tampering. 
(a)  For any bill not paid on or before the 15th of each month, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of such bill shall be added thereto and collected therewith. Additionally, if any such bill is not paid on or before the 20th of each month, water and sewer service shall be disconnected and shall not be reconnected until payment in full is received on said account. A disconnect charge of $50.00 may be charged in each instance where service is discontinued for failure to pay past due balance. 
(b)  An additional $300.00 fee will be charged if it becomes necessary to remove the meter as a result of tampering of any form. In addition, a $500.00 fee will be charged for any locking device that is pried, damaged, or removed by anyone other than an authorized agent of the city utility system. Tampering will also result in charges being filed in accordance with section 40-131. 
(c)  In case of a change of ownership of any premises, the new owner shall not be charged with the delinquencies of the prior owner. Proof of change in ownership will be required. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 4, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 09-01-191, § 1, 1-20-2009) 
Sec. 40-122. - Deemed provision of services. 
(a)  The services of the system shall be deemed to be furnished to the owner of the premises receiving such services and shall be deemed an obligation to the owner of any such premises. The services of the system shall be given to any premises only upon written application therefor, made by the owner. Such application shall be to the city upon a form supplied by it, accompanied with all required documents. Each property owner shall be responsible for notifying the city of the current occupant's name of said property. This notification shall be maintained current. 
(b)  Commercial property owners shall be required to meet same the requirements as residential homeowners. 
(c)  Alternatively, services of the system may be established by a real estate broker for any property being listed for sale by said broker; provided documentation (satisfactory to the city) is presented reflecting the property is uninhabited, owned by HUD, and/or was recently foreclosed. The service will be established in the broker's name, but the broker may provide a written list of approved real estate agents who may establish service in the broker's name. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 5, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 11-06-203, § 2, 6-7-2011)

(a)  Service connections to the system shall be constructed only after the issuance of a permit thereof by or on authority of the mayor and board of aldermen.

For accounts disconnected for failure to pay a past due bill, the deposit plus the highest amount due will be required to reestablish service, plus the service connection fee. 
(c)  The following fees shall apply:

Sec. 40-124. - Sprinkler tap fees. 
    Taps for sprinkler connections to city owned mains will be made by the city with actual cost assessed to the developer. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 6, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-125. - Violations. 
(a)  Any user of the system without a permit will be in violation of this article. A $500.00 water and/or sewer tap per dwelling penalty will be assessed against all violators of this article. 
(b)  In the event that any individual or responsible party fails to comply with any of the provisions of this article, no further water and/or sewer taps will be approved for said developer or landowner until all penalties and fees are paid. In the event the development is outside the corporate limits and the city has no control over building permits, the city may file a claim against the developer or responsible party in the appropriate court. 
(c)  The penalty as described in this section shall be in addition to any other charges, which may be charged in accordance with this article or state statute. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 6, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-126. - Water and sewer specifications. 
(a)  Water. The following shall apply: 
(1)  All water line construction shall be performed in compliance with the standard construction specifications of the city, latest revision. 
(2)  The contractor is to furnish a meter box with a cast iron lid. 
(3)  An individual tap shall be provided for each residence, with no two homes on one tap. 
(b)  Sewer. The following shall apply: 
(1)  An individual tap shall be provided for each residence, with no two homes on one tap. 
(2)  The sewer cleanout shall be stubbed up to a level two to three feet above the ground on the front yard easement line. 
(3)  All sewer line construction shall be performed in compliance with the standard construction specifications of the city, latest revision. 
(c)  Builder. The following shall apply: 
(1)  The builder shall be responsible for the maintenance of all utilities during construction (repair, grade adjustments and/or replacement of damaged meter boxes, etc.). 
(2)  The city will require a utilities inspection of each lot before the subdivision is turned over to them. 
(3)  The builder will be responsible for moving any water or sewer lines from the original stub out locations. 
(d)  Developer. The following shall apply: 
(1)  The developer shall ensure that water and sewer utilities are installed as per the city utility system specifications and he shall supply the city with as built drawings. 
(2)  The developer shall permanently mark the location of water and sewer taps on the concrete curb (by either chiseling or stamping the wet concrete). 
(3)  The city will require a utilities inspection of each lot before the subdivision is accepted. 
(e)  Homeowner. The following shall apply: 
(1)  Water. The homeowner shall be responsible for the line from the meter to the house. 
(2)  Sewer. The homeowner shall be responsible for the line from the house to the city's supplied tap. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 6, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-127. - List of premises and properties receiving services. 
    It is hereby made the duty of the city clerk to prepare or cause to be prepared, a complete and accurate list of all premises and properties receiving the services of the system, showing the name and address of the occupant or owner of the same. This list is kept up to date and shall be corrected from time to time, to show changes of the occupancy or ownership of any such property or premises. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 7, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-128. - Duties of clerk. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to have set up and maintained a proper system of accounts and records separate from all other accounts and records, showing the amount of revenues received from the water and sewer system and the application of such revenues and all financial transactions in connection therewith. Such accounts shall annually be audited properly by an independent certified public accountant. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 9, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-129. - Duty to collect. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the officials of the city to diligently collect the charges imposed by this article and to employ the proper means for the collection thereof. 
(b)  Any increases in charges or taxes that may be levied in the future by the state or any other public bodies, against the sale or consumers of water and sewer, will likewise result in an automatic and immediate increase in the retail rates of an equal and like amount. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 10, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-130. - Connection to sewer and water lines. 
(a)  Property owners of wells, septic tanks, or other individual on-site wastewater disposal systems operating in compliance with the MCA 1972, § 41-67-1 et seq., and existing in the city on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, shall have the option of connecting to public water and sewer lines, when said lines are available to them. However, no new or replacement wells, septic tanks, or other individual on-site wastewater disposal system shall be approved for use in the city, where public water and sewer lines are available to the property owners. This subsection shall apply to both residential and commercial property owners. 
(b)  Property owners shall have an election period of 180 days from the date the city engineer certifies a water/sewer expansion project complete and/or public water or sewer lines are available, in which to elect to connect to the public water and sewer lines and pay such connection fees in accordance with this article. Those owners electing to connect after the expiration of the 180-day election period must pay an additional fee of $100.00 over and above the normal connection fee. 
(c)  That the city will make the tap or connection into the water or sewer main and bring the service line to the main property line of each owner. A connection fee to defray the cost of construction of system will be charged each customer not previously served by the system. The connection fee will be paid in advance by the property owner on demand of the city, when it is ready to make the connection into the mains. However, in hardship cases, on application of the property owner, the city will permit connection fee to be paid in 24 equal monthly installments, at six percent interest added to the monthly bill for water and sewer service where the owner occupies the dwelling house being served. 
(d)  No property owner (customer) may be connected to the public water/sewer lines (system) and have a well, septic tank, or other individual on-site wastewater disposal system operating on his property. 
(e)  Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the continued use of existing water well used in legitimate farming operation or the installation of any new water well for any reasonable purpose associated with a legitimate farming operation; provided such well is in compliance with applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 11, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-131. - Violation. 
    Anyone and/or any act or acts which results in violation of any section or sections, portion or portions of this article or which result in the theft of public utilities and or destruction of city property shall be punishable by any and/or all of the provisions herein added or any other additional charges as may be charged in accordance with state statute: 
(1)  Meters; tampering with. Punishable as in accordance with MCA 1972, § 97-25-3; and/or 
(2)  Destruction of city property; malicious mischief. Punishable as defined under MCA 1972, § 97-17-67; and/or 
(3)  Theft of public utilities. Punishable as defined under MCA 1972, § 97-17-70, receiving of stolen property. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 12, 5-21-2007) 
Sec. 40-132. - Automatic increase of rates. 
(a)  There will be an automatic increase in the water and sewer rates, (including minimum and maximum amounts of bills) hereafter of three percent each year effective with the January 1, 2008, billing beginning for the next five years. 
(b)  There will be an automatic increase in the water and sewer rates (including minimum and maximum amounts of bills) of three percent on December 1 each year, effective with the December 1, 2013, billing and continuing for five years. 
(c)  There will be an automatic increase in the water and sewer rates (including minimum and maximum amounts of bills) of three percent on December 1 each year, effective with the December 1, 2018 billing, and continuing for five years. 
(Ord. No. 07-05-175, § 13, 5-21-2007; Ord. No. 13-10-212, 10-15-2013; Ord. No. 18-10-253, 10-9-2018) 
Secs. 40-133-40-160. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER CONTROL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 40-161. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish minimum stormwater management requirements and controls to protect and safeguard the general health, safety, and welfare of the public residing in watersheds within this jurisdiction. This article seeks to meet that purpose through the following objectives:
